But critics of the aid package fear the money will only cause the fighting to escalate, and may even spread political and drug-related violence throughout the region. Human rights While some US aid will go to development programmes and an overhaul of Colombia's legal system, most will be spent on equipment and training for security forces, despite persistent concerns over the military's human rights record. Monitoring groups regularly accuse the Colombian army of standing by while rightwing paramilitaries massacre unarmed civilians they accuse of helping leftist rebels. Last week Mr Clinton waived strict human rights conditions imposed by Congress and authorised the aid package, arguing that Colombia's situation was a matter of US national security. But a White House memorandum justifying the decision acknowledged that "there remain disturbing, credible allegations that individual Colombian military officers continue to collaborate with paramilitaries". The waiver provoked criticism from human rights groups. "It gives a clear message that from the US point of view, human rights are not important. What matters for them is the war on drugs," said Jorge Rojas of the Consultancy for Human Rights and Displacement, a Bogota-based monitoring group. There are signs that US aid has already led to an escalation of Colombia's civil war. In March, the country's largest guerrilla group, the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia (Farc) said it would step up kidnappings for ransom in order to raise funds equal to the US military aid. The guerrillas have also increased their attacks against isolated police stations, part of a long-term strategy to strengthen their control of rural Colombia. Although they have been involved in peace talks since last year, no ceasefire has been signed and, since January, the rebels have attacked 50 such stations. Sixty officers and dozens of civilians have been killed. "Farc is accelerating its plans for territorial control, but the guerrillas are not the only ones getting stronger. State forces are improving, as are the paramilitaries. Inevitably there will be an escalation," said defence analyst Alfredo Rangel. In early August, 83 US Green Berets arrived in the country to train the second of three counter-narcotics battalions con templated in Plan Colombia. These units will lead a campaign into the rebel-dominated southern jungles of Colombia, where most of the world's cocaine is made. "Our aid is strictly limited to anti-narcotics activities. It is not directed towards supporting counter-insurgent operations," Mr Clinton told the Colombian magazine Cambio this week. But Colombian military commanders recognise that a push in the region will inevitably bring troops into combat with several thousand Farc guerrillas who protect drug installations in return for "war taxes". Attack "We will attack anyone in the drugs trade - Farc, paramilitaries or whoever," said General Mario Montoya, commander of the army's southern task force. It is still unclear how a military strike against drug plantations will tally with the second component of Plan Colombia: a package of social development to help wean locals from growing drug crops. According to Mr Pastrana, investment in education, infrastructure and services will play a key part in establishing the rule of law in the southern regions of Putumayo and Caqueta. Traditionally, Colombian governments have paid little attention to these remote Amazon regions, allowing both rebel columns and drug plantations to grow unchecked. In the past, Colombia has focused on spending "to prevent drugs reaching the streets of the US, instead of investing in education, sewage systems, housing", said Mr Pastrana. "We want to work hand in hand with the communities, instead of concentrating on the policing aspect". But funding for social development programmes remains in doubt. At a conference in Madrid last month, European countries failed to pledge the $1bn (£667m) Mr Pastrana had hoped for. Meanwhile, Farc is reported to be giving weapons training to peasants in Putumayo, and refugee groups fear that up to 200,000 people will flee their homes if widespread fighting breaks out. Neighbouring countries have expressed concern that the plan may cause Colombia's civil war to spill across its borders. Ecuador and Brazil have reinforced security along their jungle frontiers. Peru's president, Alberto Fujimori, said last week that an anti-narcotics drive could threaten the stability of the entire region. "How can you strengthen democracy in the midst of a war?" said Mr Rojas. His organisation and 36 more Colombian human rights, Indian and development groups have said they will not participate in projects funded under the plan. Farc chiefs say Mr Clinton's approval of Plan Colombia was timed to coincide with the US election campaign. Speaking from a stronghold in southern Colombia, Commander Andres Paris said: "They want to spill Colombian blood to help their presidential candidates." 50 years of Conflict 948 Assassination of popular liberal politician leads to rural unrest which claims 300,000 lives over next decade 1953-57 Military seize power, before returning it to coalition rule by liberal and conservative parties 1964 Colombian military launch US-backed Operation Laso, to destroy leftist guerrillas. It fails and marks foundation of the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia (Farc), a communist guerrilla movement 1966 Creation of rival, smaller guerrilla group, Army of National Liberation (ELN) 1980s Emergence of right-wing narco-paramilitaries who target guerrilla groups and their supporters. Farc's political wing loses 4,000 people killed by drug-traffickers 1990 US president George Bush announces war on drugs 1992 US says it will stop aid to Colombian army amid claims that the army used the cash to fight Marxist rebels 1993 Medellin drug baron Pablo Escobar is shot dead by Colombian police after a US-backed search 1994 Allegations that Colombian president-elect Ernesto Samper's election campaign was funded by $6m from a Cali drug cartel lead to him losing his US travel visa. 1997 First US civilian pilot, working under a state department contract, is killed on a drug crop fumigation flight in south-east Colombia 1998 Farc is granted a 15,000 square mile demilitarised zone to encourage peace talks June 2000 US Senate gives final approval to record $1.3bn package of military aid to help fight drugs and Marxist guerrillas

fields.headline: Time loves a hero
fields.standfirst: The late, great Lowell George is making his comeback. By  Adam Sweeting
fields.trailText: The late, great Lowell George is making his comeback.
fields.body:
The Eagles sold more records and Steely Dan went down better with intellectuals, but the best American band of the 1970s was Little Feat, led by Lowell George until a year before his death in 1979. A songwriter, studio innovator, bluesman, crooner and slide guitar ace, George was one of rock's most brilliant stars. He always surpassed the supposed limitations of rock music; Jackson Browne described him as "the Orson Welles of rock".

Now George is getting a memorial of sorts, in the form of a four-disc box set on Rhino records, Hotcakes & Outtakes: 30 Years of Little Feat. The package is not an unmixed blessing. An entire disc is devoted to the band's mediocre post-George output, and the compilers should be lowered into boiling oil for some of the glaring omissions from the Feat's first four Warner Brothers albums. But at least the collection is a valuable reminder of George's oblique genius, with a disc of outtakes, demos and alternative versions that throw new light on George and his working methods.

Featophiles will also be intrigued by the anecdote-crammed essay by former Rolling Stone writer Bud Scoppa. However, Scoppa strikes a bum note when he seeks to equate the present-day Feat with the original article. Today's band is "a tribe, a touchstone, a system, a sanctuary, an ongoing act of affirmation," he blathers tearfully, when he must know it is only a sorry pastiche of its former glories.

Lowell George welded a penetrating intelligence to a deadpan humour. An absurdist's view of the world is a running theme through his songs, from the dazed freaks-against-the-world saga of Strawberry Flats (from the debut album) to Rocket in My Pocket (from 1977's Time Loves a Hero). He could Lowellise other people's songs too, for example with his droll rendition of the Leiber & Stoller tune Framed, or the previously unheard take of Allen Toussaint's Brickyard Blues, which is one of the great discoveries on the Rhino box.

Writer and arranger Van Dyke Parks first met George when he was an employee at Warner Brothers and Little Feat came looking for a record deal. "I think he had the audacity of a schizophrenic, which I associate with great work, whether it's Van Gogh or Ravel," Parks observes. "I think Lowell had a madness in his work that he wanted to explore, and he had the integrity to do it." Parks singles out the song Fat Man in the Bathtub. "You see the physical comedy in Lowell George that you get from Buster Keaton. It's the tragicomedy of man in crisis - that's what Lowell did for me."

George's colourful background appears to have given him the confidence to pursue his particular vision, oblivious to the incomprehension of onlookers. He was steeped in Hollywood history and folklore, as anyone might be if their family home was just up the hill from Grauman's Chinese Theater. His father was a furrier who numbered many of the movieland aristocracy among his clientele, and went duck-shooting with Tinseltown veterans such as Wallace Beery and WC Fields. Although prone to weight problems, Lowell, sputtering around the Hollywood hills in a battered Morgan sports car, projected a magnetic charm that worked equally well on record companies, women and equipment suppliers.

While his brother Hampton joined the paratroopers and went to Vietnam, Lowell studied martial arts and a variety of instruments, including the shakuhachi (a Japanese flute) and the saxophone. Another of the early rarities exhumed by Rhino is a rare and frankly dismal piece called Jazz Thing in 10, in which George tries to be Archie Shepp on sax.

The point, however, is that behind the skewed vision of Little Feat's songs lay some unusually advanced musicianship. George served for a time with Frank Zappa's Mothers of Invention. The first version of Little Feat - almost named Lyle Gleep - included Mothers bassist Roy Estrada alongside classically trained pianist Bill Payne, with whom George had briefly played in the Brotherhood of Man, the same place he found the Feat's long-serving drummer, Richie Hayward. The Mark 2 Little Feat, who debuted on 1973's Dixie Chicken, saw the arrival of guitarist Barrere, grandson of a famous flautist who taught at the Juilliard School in New York, plus bassist Kenny Gradney and percussionist Sam Clayton, a pair of seasoned R'n'B veterans.

George's infuriating stubbornness was as great as his talent. His made his fellow musicians bristle by adopting Frank Zappa's autocratic bandleading style; his eccentric methods of writing and recording, meanwhile, were time-consuming and calamitously costly. The results, at least, were worth it. Rock and Roll Doctor, the opening track from 1974's Feats Don't Fail Me Now, took an age to complete because the band had to build it from a crude demo George had assembled by splicing together chunks of several different cassette tapes. George's objective was to create a song with as many awkward chord changes and rhythmic eccentricities as possible, what he liked to call the "cracked mosaic". Its crowning glory is George's slide guitar solo, a screaming miracle of sonic architecture.

George's approach to his work often seemed to have more in common with jazz or classical composition: he would spend years reworking the same material, edging his way towards some imagined ideal result. The process was already evident in Little Feat's existing catalogue. The Rhino box offers several more specimens, with very early versions of The Fan, Easy to Fall (which became Easy to Slip on Sailin' Shoes), Texas Rose Cafe and a raw demo of Two Trains, featuring just George and his crude Donca Matic drum machine. It's a testament to their commercial unworldliness that the band left so many excellent tracks off their original albums. Versions of High Roller and All That You Dream from the new collection are decisively superior to the previously issued takes. Lowell's widow Elizabeth discovered the tapes of Lonesome Whistle, issued on the 1981 Hoy-Hoy! compilation, at the back of their garage in a brown paper bag.

George was at his creative peak at a time when rock bands were still allowed to make outrageous records, and in Warner Brothers Little Feat found a label that gave its artists more creative rope than most. He also fell foul of the post-psychedelic lifestyle considered desirable in the 1970s, when etiquette dictated that one should be permanently blasted. His fondness for cocaine-and-heroin "speedballs" was notorious, his appetite for junk food and liquor unassuagable. An Australian journalist told me how he had interviewed Lowell over lunch in Sydney, during which George put away a bottle of Courvoisier. When he died in June 1979, aged 34, he had ballooned to an Elvis-like 22 stone and was a medical emergency waiting to happen. His attitude towards the brain-dead, body-beautiful record business of the 21st century would not be hard to imagine.

Rhino Records release the Hotcakes & Outtakes box set next month.

fields.headline: Court circular
fields.standfirst: Who's up in front of the judge
fields.trailText: Who's up in front of the judge
fields.body:
Things just aren't getting any better for Eminem, who's now managed to get himself sued by both his mother and his wife.

The legal icing on the cake came when Kim Mathers, his recently estranged spouse, stuck the pallid rapper with a hefty defamation lawsuit days after her husband filed for divorce. Indeed, barely had the paperwork for the separation hit Mathers' lawyer's desk before she retaliated by formally alleging her other half was an unfit father (and therefore ineligible for joint custody of the couple's daughter) and that his numerous lyrical outbursts against his sweetheart had defamed her reputation. The cost? $10 million should the suit go Kim's way, the exact same amount as Debbie Mathers-Briggs is currently demanding from her errant son over accusations of bad parenting made in both lyrics and interviews. Attorney Paul Rosenberg, acting for Eminem, immediately announced that his client would "go to the mat" for joint custody. "This changes the tenor," Rosenberg went on. "Em's not going to be happy. Everybody on our side wanted to keep things low-key and work things out amicably."

Meanwhile, Woody Harrelson finally walked on longstanding charges of marijuana possession, after the pro-dope activist's arrest during the ceremonial planting of four hemp seeds in Lee County, Kentucky, back in 1996. Prosecutors had originally offered Harrelson the option of a 30-day jail sentence or a guarantee to stay away from hemp in Kentucky for a year - however, in his ardour for the versatile plant, the actor refused, turning up to court last week in a hemp suit. Following a declaration of support from former Republican governor Bill Nunn, the six-person jury spent 25 minutes deliberating, before promptly delivering a not guilty verdict. Harrelson, perhaps understandably, then thanked the jury, before signing autographs in the courtroom. Aww ...

fields.headline: Too hot to handle
fields.standfirst: Nigella Lawson's new Channel 4 cookery show isn't really about food at all - it's about lifestyle. The irony is that, unlike some of her predecessors, she really does know what she's doing in the kitchen. By  Jacques Peretti
fields.trailText: Nigella Lawson's new Channel 4 cookery show isn't really about food at all - it's about lifestyle. The irony is that, unlike some of her predecessors, she really does know what she's doing in the kitchen.
fields.body:
'What I want is a soft chunky texture", Nigella Lawson says, pummelling some out-of-focus guacamole into a shape acceptable for a dinner party in London's Holland Park. "Oh, that's just how I like it", she says, smoothing her Morticia hair and pouting - oh cruel and terrible beauty - into the camera.

Many people - but not me, oh no, not me - are mildly obsessed with Nigella Lawson. It began with her book, How To Eat, a fantastically glamorous glimpse into A1 Georgian-house luxury-living, packaged as a fashionably utilitarian cook book.

There were Nigella's all-too-fleeting appearances on TV, as rare for her fans as outings to the supermarket by JD Salinger. But now she has her own show, Nigella Bites, starting tonight on Channel 4. Grrrrrrr! And her fans can get to see inside that beautiful Holland Park house at last. And what perfection. No sign of the kids but we see some fridge magnets. Salad and books and brushed steel pass in a blur across the immaculate Noughties interior, the selective clutter of an overly tweaked set. Gleaming pans segue seamlessly to bottles of champagne popping and the sound of clever dinner-party laughter.

Nigella is cooking, somewhere, but who cares about her? We want to know who all these sparkling people are? It's rude not to be introduced.

Pace Jamie, Nigella later takes us out to her local butcher's (fans know this to be Lidgate on Holland Park Road, where the staff wear uniforms from Upstairs Downstairs). Nigella is the Mistress of her house, and Queen of the Holland Park dinner party scene.

"I am mad for jellies!" she says, preparing afters, or should I say, dessert. "A proper jelly needs a proper mold, one with lovely crenellations, something bulging and old-fashioned." I couldn't help comparing Nigella's kitchen with Ruby Wax's, glimpsed in chat with Victoria Beckham a couple of months ago. Nigella's is far superior. Much bigger.

"I am not a chef," Nigella says in her forward to How To Eat, "my qualification is as an eater... I wanted to make my slavering passion for food the starting point. I have nothing to declare but my greed."

Yes, but think of Jamie Oliver at the top of the bestseller list for months on end. Greed is good, and not just for ganneting down the leftovers of the guacamole when all the witty guests have gone home.

When one thinks of the incredible fortunes to be made from celebrity cooking, one thinks wistfully back to a time BD (Before Delia). To the culinary pioneers who - like George Bests of the same era - were paid a weekly wage of thruppence.

The irony is that Nigella and Jamie, icons of two very particular kinds of mod-urban lifestyle (the young and older end of the Elle Deco reader, respectively) are both very good cooks. Their underpaid predecessors, on the other hand, were charlatans.

Fanny and Johnnie Cradock, who opened the eyes of a Britain just emerging from rationing and austerity, to the possibilites of roasting a peacock for a medieval banquet, actually lived in near-squalor.

On screen, Fanny's camp pretensions were a bizarre mixture of continental Campari-drinking aspiration and making do with the grim shortcomings of the 50s diet. Fanny's philosophy was akin to spraying whipped cream on corned beef. In reality, Fanny and Johnnie ate baked beans cold from a tin in a filthy kitchen.

Fanny and Johnnie never made the kind of serious money that Jamie or Nigella can make from their multi-front offensives on the loft-dwelling middle class, keen to get the dinner party right just so.

But I have a fantasy that there's a discrepancy between the fantasy and reality of Jamie and Nigella, every bit as great as the one between the fantasy and reality of Fanny and Johnnie's worlds.

In my fantasy, Jamie Oliver is not really a happy-go-lucky gee-e-zer with a fireman's pole in his flat, but an outrageous snob, who eats fois gras with a fork; Delia is not a Norwich City-supporting dominatrix with a stern approach to boiling an egg, but a slacked-out fast-food junkie, who can't be bothered to wash up.

As I say, it's just a fantasy. In fact, I have a terrible feeling that Jamie and Nigella are not putting it on at all. They really do live just as they appear to live in their programmes. Only probably a little bit more so.

Cookery is about sex, of course, as much as lifestyle; and this is why the greatest cookery writer of them all, Nigel Slater, is barely allowed on television. His enthusiasm for devouring a Toffee Crisp with the leftovers from last night's take-away curry is positively pornographic.

Slater's approach is actually very close to the way we eat - probably a little too close for comfort. It also raises a fundamental philosophical problem for the TV chef. How far can you go in deconstructing cooking? So far that it ceases to be cooking at all. Nigella has sidestepped the issue by reviving food as social entertainments. Not so far from Fanny after all.

Nigella Bites, 8.30pm, Channel 4.

Only probably a little bit more so. Cookery is about sex, of course, as much as lifestyle; and this is why the greatest cookery writer of them all, Nigel Slater, is barely allowed on television. His enthusiasm for devouring a Toffee Crisp with the leftovers from last night's take-away curry is positively pornographic. Slater's approach is actually very close to the way we eat - probably a little too close for comfort. It also raises a fundamental philosophical problem for the TV chef. How far can you go in deconstructing cooking? So far that it ceases to be cooking at all. Nigella has sidestepped the issue by reviving food as social entertainments. Not so far from Fanny after all. Nigella Bites, 8.30pm, Channel 4.

fields.headline: Hear this
fields.trailText: Twin Cities/The Ocean Planet
fields.body:
Anyone who has visited Mestre in north-eastern Italy will recall it as Dagenham-on-the-Adriatic. It does, however, have one huge advantage over its more illustrious neighbour: it is built on terra firma. The neighbour, of course, is Venice, with water lapping higher up its crumbling palazzi and the inhabitants leaving in droves. As Jonathan Glancey discovers in Twin Cities (11.0am, Radio 4), Mestre is suddenly the coming place.

If you had doubts about the crisis in the world's fishing industry, Professor Jacquie McGlade may convince you in The Ocean Planet (9.0pm, Radio 4). At present we get one-sixth of our animal protein from the sea, but the available quantity is declining sharply. Now the professor has discovered that a laudable, if naive, American attempt to control overfishing has so increased the value of East Coast clams and lobsters that the Mafia has taken over the business. Soon it will be looking for bigger fish.

fields.headline: Prisoner's dilemma
fields.standfirst: Last night's TV:  Rupert Smith
fields.trailText: Britain's Hardest Man/Smart Hearts/EastEnders
fields.body:
Mae West was right about most things in life, but when she said "a hard man is good to find" she had clearly never met Charles Bronson, or any of his ilk. Bronson - Michael Peterson to his friends, if he has any - is, according to last night's profile, Britain's Hardest Man (Channel 5). In a crackly interview recorded a few years ago at Hull Prison, he claimed "I've done nothing to be ashamed of. I'm a criminal, and proud of it."

Unsurprisingly, even the most sympathetic prison governors decided there was nothing that could be done for Bronson - and that was before he took a teacher hostage and started demanding a helicopter to Cuba. This little escapade was captured on CCTV, adding a hilarious new dimension to the "you've been framed" genre of cheap television. Bronson paced his cell, looking, according to his captive, like "Fred Flintstone on ecstasy", brandishing a home-made spear. Now he's locked up for good, or at least till 2010, by which time he will doubtless have done something else to ensure his continued incarceration. There was some talk of the system having "failed" Charles Bronson, but if anything the story was one of outstanding success. Bronson has achieved 26 years of almost continuous porridge - not bad for a botched armed robbery. We were left with the unavoidable conclusion that this is what he wants.

How the producers of Smart Hearts (Channel 4) must have kicked themselves when they woke up to the fact that Big Brother had stolen their thunder. In the first of four episodes we were introduced to artist Brendan, his spurned wife Claire, and new girlfriend Lisa, who unaccountably agreed to have their messy private lives recorded for all to tut over. Webcams and hand-held video allowed us to see far more than we could ever have wished, particularly of the married couple, of whom the kindest that can be said is that they richly deserved each other.

Artist Brendan, a loose-featured, wet-mouthed blond, sank into a morass of boozy self-pity, occasionally lashing out and generally acting up for the cameras. Model Claire looked like Faye Dunaway at her most severe, and kept telling us how glad she was that Brendan had dumped her. Lisa sensibly kept out of range, but lost any shred of sympathy by agreeing to marry Brendan at the end of the programme.

What should have been entertaining voyeurism - what, after all, is juicier than someone else's romantic disasters? - became, after ten minutes, grim and repetitive. Eight weeks flashed by in half an hour, and we were no nearer resolution; how on earth director Victoria Mapplebeck endured six months with this gruesome threesome boggles the imagination.

Erotic triangles abounded in EastEnders (BBC1), which started off with the boys at one end of the playground, the girls at the other, before exploring a number of variations. Peggy, Pat and Irene basked in the Spanish sun, looking for all the world like Bananarama in the autumn of their years. They sighed and pined over their marital problems, ignoring the obvious solution in the shape of three nubile toyboys playing volleyball nearby. Instead of dragging them off to some cool cabaña, they paired up in the most disastrous ways imaginable.

Pat encountered Frank by the poolside, and if there was any doubt as to the outcome we heard R Kelly crooning If I Could Turn Back The Hands Of Time on the radio. Minutes later the hands had been well and truly turned back, and the guilty ex-marrieds could only await the discovery that faces all soap adulterers. Peggy, in Chanel shades and a Sophia Loren headscarf, teetered around Alicante with Irene, picking up dodgy blokes, drinking them under the table and pretending to be a lesbian.

"Frank's the one for me", she confided, little knowing that the man of her choice was getting Pat on her back. Irene, meanwhile, began to realise that there might be more to life than Terry, and gazed wistfully across a landscape of beach umbrellas and overstuffed swimwear. "I want a fresh start", she said, speaking, as she often does at moments of crisis, through her nose. Terry, in a moment of freak articulacy, claimed that "I can't visualise any part of my life that doesn't include you." I'd start visualising pretty hard if I were you, Tel, my old son.

webTitle: What Rich Hall fans are watching on television

fields.headline: Random views
fields.standfirst: What Rich Hall fans are watching on television
fields.trailText: What Rich Hall fans are watching on television
fields.body:
George Rosen: "I seriously don't understand Big Brother. We have Survivor in the US and the stakes are a lot higher. $1m you win. I hear you're all talking about Big Brother all the time. Are you? Get a life! You don't know those people! What do I like? Seinfeld, The Simpsons... we had your Ainsley Harriot in the US but he went down very badly. No one could understand him."

David Barnes: "I like Robot Wars and comedy. I've just been to see Rich Hall. I thought he was... all right. I'm not sure. I saw Johnny Vegas and I was amused. He had a TV programme a year or so ago. That was OK. I do like Davina McCall as a personality. I think she's very good at her job. Do I fancy her? I think she's all right."

Richard Hepburn: " I'll tell you who I hate on TV. Bloody Sean Hughes. I've seen some comedians here and they did COMEDY. Sean Hughes (pictured) seems to do non-comedy. Misery. Yeah, misery is what he does. I've seen Never Mind The Buzzcocks on TV and Mark Lamarr is just as bad. They all are. I'd hang them all."

Jennifer Lawes: "My cousin was on Big Brother and she hated it. Which one was she? I'm not going to tell you - I can't stand the publicity. Ha ha ha. Honest, though. She told me she hated it. Did I watch it? Of course! Who do I want to win? None of them. I don't like any of the ones left."

Sidney Young: "Just a load of nonsense, TV. In my day, it was a rarity. It was for something special. Do I watch Last Of The Summer Wine? What's that? Oh, no. I prefer to read the paper."

Philip Wallace: "I'll watch anything. I have no critical faculties whatsoever. We've got OnDigital at home. Fantastic. I was watching Sid James in Bless This House on one of the retro channels the other day. Sheer genius. They don't make 'em like they used to."

Sin Pattenden spoke to people at the Rich Hall show in Edinburgh.

fields.headline: Senior French minister quits
fields.trailText: The man dubbed the gentleman rebel of French politics resigned from a senior cabinet post for the third time in his career yesterday.
fields.body:
The man dubbed the gentleman rebel of French politics resigned from a senior cabinet post for the third time in his career yesterday.

Jean-Pierre Chevènement, a longstanding friend and ally of the prime minister, Lionel Jospin, stood down as interior minister in a move that could throw the ruling Socialist-led coalition badly off balance.

He said his departure was "the logical consequence" of a profound disagreement with Mr Jospin over plans to offer limited autonomy to Corsica.

He will be replaced by the government spokesman and minister for parliamentary relations, Daniel Vaillant, who managed the prime minister's 1997 election campaign.

Ahead of local polls next year and presidential and parliamentary elections in 2002, Mr Chevènement's resignation deprives Mr Jospin not only of one of his most popular ministers but of a key component in the loose leftwing coalition of socialists, greens, communists and radical republicans that has run France for three years.

Mr Chevènement's departure leaves the radical Mouvement des Citoyens, without a voice in government and could increase cabinet tensions between traditional leftwingers and the reformist finance minister, Laurent Fabius.

"It is a source of great regret that he has decided to go," said one Socialist MEP, Marie-Noëlle Lienemann. "I think Jean-Pierre's voice was more useful inside the government than outside, particularly as an expression of republican thought which he is not alone in espousing."

Mr Jospin has now lost four of the heavyweight ministers he appointed to his first 1997 cabinet through resignations. In a brief but warm statement, the prime minister expressed his regret at the minister's departure and praised his efforts over the past three years.

Mr Chevènement, an outspoken radical republican, has warned for several months that Mr Jospin's proposal for limited self-rule for Corsica would inevitably lead to the break-up of the Republic.

But while politicians praised Mr Chevènement as a man of principle, the influential newspaper Le Monde criticised the basis of his stance on Corsica, saying Britain had made progress in Northern Ireland by opening talks without preconditions.

The paper also said Mr Chevènement was hiding his real ambitions. "He is leaving because he would like to be the spokesman, if not the presidential candidate, of a large strain of opinion on the right and the left which does not feel comfortable with the economic and European choices of today's France," it said.

The maverick: Chevènement's record

At the heart of the French left for nearly 40 years, Jean-Pierre Chevènement has managed to remain a man apart.

His Mouvement des Citoyens is the contemporary expression of Jacobinism, a philosophy espoused by a small club of 18th-century French republicans who believed in a centralised democracy.

Believing that France's national integrity and the unity of the Republic should override any European or international ties, he has argued ferociously against European monetary union, and has attacked the devolution plans for Corsica, declaring that "one cannot fight against ethnic nationalism in the Balkans and allow it on French soil".

His two ministerial resignations on matters of principle have won him widespread respect, and he remains highly popular.

A narrow escape from death in 1998, when he went into a coma after a routine gall-bladder operation, led to his being dubbed "the miraculous survivor of the Republic". But at 61, he may find a third resignation rather more difficult to come back from.

fields.headline: Workers' rights 'abused in US'
fields.trailText: The American "economic miracle" of the past eight years has been built partly at the expense of workers' rights, which are feebly enforced by the government and routinely violated by employers, according to a report published yesterday by Human Rights Watch.
fields.body:
The American "economic miracle" of the past eight years has been built partly at the expense of workers' rights, which are feebly enforced by the government and routinely violated by employers, according to a report published yesterday by Human Rights Watch.

The report says employers are taking advantage of immigrant workers, and the increasing number of part-time and contract workers produced by the new technology-driven economy, to deny employees the right to organise. Unions now represent less than 14% of the US workforce.

One of the firms singled out for criticism is the software giant Microsoft. Of the 20,000 workers at its headquarters in Redmond, Washington state, 6,000 are not directly employed by Microsoft, but by temporary employment agencies.

Many of these employees have worked for Microsoft for years and have come to be known as "perma-temps". Although they are well paid, they do not benefit from health insurance provisions, pension plans or paid holidays.

The "perma-temps" formed a union, the Washington Alliance of Technology Workers (WashTech), but its recruitment efforts have been hindered by Microsoft's claim that it is not the workers' legal employer. The employment agencies say they will not negotiate with the union unless it includes other agency employees, not just those at Microsoft.

"We had no way of knowing who they were or how to reach them. Besides, they had nothing to do with our problems at Microsoft," Barbara Judd, a WashTech organiser.

The report also discusses immigrant workers on US farms, who are threatened with investigation by immigration authorities and deportation if they try to set up a union.

In other cases, private sector employees have been fired for attempting to form unions. Many have won court cases ordering their reinstatement and guaranteeing the right to organise, but the employers are able to prevent the rulings being enforced by appealing.

"Employers can resist union organising by dragging out legal proceedings for years," the report's author, Lance Compa, said. "Labour law is so weak that companies often treat the minor penalties as a routine cost of doing business, not a deterrent against violations."

"The cards are stacked against workers in the United States," Kenneth Roth, HRW's executive director, said. "The US government cannot effectively press another country to improve labour standards while violating them itself."

fields.headline: Philippine rebels seize American
fields.trailText: The hostage crisis in the southern Philippines took a fresh twist yesterday when the Muslim separatist kidnappers seized a young American man they accused of being a spy just as it appeared they were about to release the last remaining six foreign prisoners.
fields.body:
The hostage crisis in the southern Philippines took a fresh twist yesterday when the Muslim separatist kidnappers seized a young American man they accused of being a spy just as it appeared they were about to release the last remaining six foreign prisoners.

As six westerners freed this week after more than four months in captivity celebrated in Tripoli with the Libyan leader, Muammar Gadafy, who facilitated their release by paying a $1m (£680,000) ransom per captive , the Abu Sayyaf guerrillas announced they had captured Jeffrey Schilling, who had been staying with his Filipino girlfriend in the southern city of Zamboanga.

Rebel spokesman Abu Sabaya said in a radio interview that Mr Schilling, 24, from San Francisco, had contacted Abu Sayyaf members in Zamboanga, on Mindanao island, saying he was a Muslim convert and wanted to visit the rebels' local camp.

But the separatists, a splinter group of the main Abu Sayyaf force, suspected he was a CIA agent when it transpired he knew little about Islam. So they abducted him and took him to the main Abu Sayyaf stronghold on the island of Jolo, 30 miles southwest of Zamboanga, Mr Sabaya said.

There they are still holding six foreigners and 12 Filipino evangelists who were captured when they went into the Jolo jungle to pray for the hostages.

Mr Sabaya appeared to be gloating. "We have been trying very hard to get an American because the Americans may think we are afraid of them," he said. "[Those holding him] will not hesitate to execute this American guy if the Philippine government and the US will not listen to our demands."

The rebels will announce their demands in three days, he said. It is thought they will include the release of several Arab terrorists imprisoned in US jails. Earlier this year Abu Sayyaf killed two Filipinos they had seized after the Americans refused to release several terrorists.

Six officials from the US embassy in Manila flew to Zamboanga yesterday to investigate the incident.

Mr Schilling's girlfriend, Ivi Osani, who is also a Muslim, gave a different version of the abduction. She said Mr Sabaya, who is related to her mother, had been pressurising the couple to visit the rebels on Jolo. They finally agreed, and went by boat from Zamboanga on Sunday, she said.

Unable to hold back her tears, Ms Osani said Mr Schilling had told her to return alone to Zamboanga, and she had not discovered until her arrival on Tuesday that he had been kidnapped.

The Philippine government's chief negotiator, Robert Aventajado, insisted that Mr Schilling's capture had nothing to do with the payment of $6m for the release of the six prisoners this week and $5.5m for 10 others freed in July.

"It is not open season on kidnapping of tourists now," he said. "From what I heard the American was seized because he made the Abu Sayyaf angry by asking too many suspicious questions."

Rajab Azzarouq, the leading Libyan intermediary in the negotiations, denied that the money had been paid directly to Abu Sayyaf, saying: "We gave the money to the local people for humanitarian projects, economic projects and social projects. It was not a ransom."

He was speaking just before the six freed hostages were paraded in front of the world's media. The ceremony took place at a bombed-out barracks that was destroyed in an American raid in 1986. Among those killed in the attack was one of his adopted daughters.

The French and German governments, who had nationals among those freed, have heaped praise upon Libya for its role in the crisis. Analysts say Mr Gadafy is using the crisis to alter his image as a sponsor of international terrorism.

Five of the the hostages freed this week were among 21 people seized from a Malaysian diving resort on the island of Sipaden on April 23.

The sixth is one of three French journalists seized on July 9 while covering the crisis. Her two colleagues are still being held.

Unable to hold back her tears, Ms Osani said Mr Schilling had told her to return alone to Zamboanga, and she had not discovered until her arrival on Tuesday that he had been kidnapped. The Philippine government's chief negotiator, Robert Aventajado, insisted that Mr Schilling's capture had nothing to do with the payment of $6m for the release of the six prisoners this week and $5.5m for 10 others freed in July. "It is not open season on kidnapping of tourists now," he said. "From what I heard the American was seized because he made the Abu Sayyaf angry by asking too many suspicious questions." Rajab Azzarouq, the leading Libyan intermediary in the negotiations, denied that the money had been paid directly to Abu Sayyaf, saying: "We gave the money to the local people for humanitarian projects, economic projects and social projects. It was not a ransom." He was speaking just before the six freed hostages were paraded in front of the world's media. The ceremony took place at a bombed-out barracks that was destroyed in an American raid in 1986. Among those killed in the attack was one of his adopted daughters. The French and German governments, who had nationals among those freed, have heaped praise upon Libya for its role in the crisis. Analysts say Mr Gadafy is using the crisis to alter his image as a sponsor of international terrorism. Five of the the hostages freed this week were among 21 people seized from a Malaysian diving resort on the island of Sipaden on April 23. The sixth is one of three French journalists seized on July 9 while covering the crisis. Her two colleagues are still being held.

fields.headline: Corrections and clarifications
fields.trailText: A leader on digital TV, page 15, August 28, erred when it said that decoders (at present usually set-top boxes) "convert analogue signals into digital ones". People's eyes recognise analogue transmissions only. Hence a digital decoder is one that receives digital signals and converts them to analogue for viewing on the screen. Digital TVs simply have the box inside.
fields.body:
A leader on digital TV, page 15, August 28, erred when it said that decoders (at present usually set-top boxes) "convert analogue signals into digital ones". People's eyes recognise analogue transmissions only. Hence a digital decoder is one that receives digital signals and converts them to analogue for viewing on the screen. Digital TVs simply have the box inside.

Editing of a story on French cabinet divisions over Corsica resulted in Martine Aubry being assigned the justice portfolio, page 12, August 29. She is employment minister.

In (correctly) characterising the Serbian information ministry's website as much given to propaganda, an item on page 10, the Editor, August 25 was wrong in casting doubt on the site's reference to ethnic Albanian terrorists lobbing explosives at a playground near Obilic in Kosovo. The August 18 incident was seen by a UN policeman and reported by Reuter. Nine Serb children were hurt. Albanian men were strongly suspected.

A factbox (page 32, Finance, August 26) said that British racing driver Stirling Moss won his first grand prix race in a Mercedes at Silverstone in 1955. It was Aintree.

The mother of golfer Tiger Woods is Thai, rather than Malaysian as a column said on page 13, August 28.

Two publications co-founded by Lord Vernon were misnamed in Obituaries, page 20, August 25. They should have been Soviet Analyst and Africa Confidential.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Car bomb rocks Cape Town
fields.body:
Car bomb rocks Cape Town

A car bomb blew up in the centre of Cape Town yesterday, but no one was injured and there was no damage to buildings.

It was the 18th bomb blast to hit Cape Town in the last two years.
Reuters, Cape Town

Victims of mass execution found

Fifty-six bodies have been exhumed so far from a mass grave in Bosnian Serb-controlled territory, the Muslim Commission for Missing Persons said yesterday.

The bodies were found in a deep pit near the Serb-held village of Kalimanici, 20 miles east of Sarajevo. They are believed to be Bosnian Muslims executed by Serb soldiers at the beginning of the 1992-1995 war.
Reuters, Sarajevo

Children flee Japan volcano

A volcano on the Japanese island of Miyakejima spewed a huge column of steam, smoke and ash yesterday, forcing authorities to speed up the evacuation of schoolchildren.

Some 139 children boarded a boat at the island's pier as many parents choked back tears. They were being accommodated at a boarding school in Tokyo, 113 miles to the north.
Reuters, Tokyo

Baby boy joins Gandhi dynasty

Priyanka Vadra, the daughter of the Congress party president, Sonia Gandhi, gave birth to a boy yesterday. Both mother and baby were reported to be fine.

Ms Vadra, the 28-year-old daughter of the assassinated prime minister Rajiv Gandhi, had campaigned vigorously for her mother in the 1998 parliamentary elections and wields considerable influence in the Congress party.
AP, New Delhi

Police quell Australian riot

Police regained control of a detention centre in the Australian outback, 800 miles west of Sydney, yesterday after a riot by illegal immigrants left 13 security staff injured.

About 80 immigrants, angry at the rejection of their Australian residency applications, torched six buildings and threw stones and makeshift spears at staff. Police and security guards responded with teargas and water cannon.
AP, Woomera

webTitle: Letters: A new agenda for Ireland

fields.headline: A new agenda for Ireland
fields.trailText: Tom Paulin is right to draw attention to racism in Ireland (Frozen out by the Irish, August 29). But his sweeping generalisations risk a different form of stereotyping. Many Irish people are active anti-racists and belong to campaigning organisations. There is widespread condemnation of racist attacks. Recent equality legislation bans racial discrimination and the new Equality Authority is charged with promoting equality objectives.
fields.body:
Tom Paulin is right to draw attention to racism in Ireland (Frozen out by the Irish, August 29). But his sweeping generalisations risk a different form of stereotyping. Many Irish people are active anti-racists and belong to campaigning organisations. There is widespread condemnation of racist attacks. Recent equality legislation bans racial discrimination and the new Equality Authority is charged with promoting equality objectives. To be sure there is little support here - or in Britain - for a radical equality agenda which goes beyond "equal opportunities" to tackle the real, structural causes of racism. But the strength of anti-racist resistance should also be acknowledged.
John Baker
Equality studies centre,
University College Dublin
John.Baker@ucd.ie

 No doubt you will receive letters from my countrymen spinning the line that we are no different to the British (or any other nation). However, this is simply a denial of an uncomfortable truth, namely that in the light of the novel phenomenon of immigration into Ireland, the Irish nation has become the proverbial slave turned slave owner.

Whereas even the tabloid press in the UK would no longer dare to follow an overtly racist agenda, the Irish press have treated immigration and race issues with an appalling slant. Reading the popular press in Ireland, the "immigrant-as-criminal-and-social-welfare-fraudster" has been the single most common theme in the treatment of the immigration issue.
Stephen Lane
Clonee, Co Meath

 On a visit to a cousin's family celebration in Dublin last October, I was taken aback by our taxi driver's vicious verbal attack on the recent influx of Kosovan refugees into Ireland. The Irish should have a greater empathy with exiles, as their own recent history is of a people coerced from their own land. Or does this only apply to the Irish, who, just a generation ago, were able to read in the windows of boarding houses here in Britain "No Irish or blacks here"?
Robert Ganley
Manchester
robertganley@hotmail.com

 Jon Moore (Letters, August 29) rhetorically demands why [Irish] "republican violence can be explained by... repression but loyalist violence is always... plain thuggery". Maybe this is because republicans have been repressed and their call is for equality, while loyalists are attempting to defend their privileges in jobs, housing, and control of the Northern Ireland state. The republicans will always hold the moral high ground. There is a strong analogy with apartheid South Africa; some may argue differences in degree, but none can argue differences in kind.
Charli Langford
London
charli.barbara@btinternet.com

 It is, I suppose, perfectly possible that "Name and address supplied" (Letters, August 26) grew up in a part of Ireland where all the men were drunk, the women and children raped, and Jews, gays, and English lynched. But one does wonder where it might be. The clue is in the word vow: he comes from good old traditional Irish melodrama. The vow usually goes: "I'll not return to this place till I've avenged the man who stole my land, nor sorrowed the wife who died in childbirth, nor mourned my three fine sons who died of starvation while fishing in the currach... Well, I won't return until there's a bloody good party." Meanwhile, others think the place is a good financial risk and invest heavily.
Eola Dillon
Dublin

fields.headline: Selective secrecy
fields.trailText: I strongly support your views on the intelligence services and the public interest (Leaders, August 22). Of course you cannot have a secret service unless it is secret. But if the rule of law is to prevail, there must be circumstances in which a breach of confidence is at least excusable, if not wholly justified. If a member of the secret service were instructed to commit a crime and reported it to the police and no action was taken, surely the overriding importance of the freedom of the press should prevail and the right of the public to be informed?
fields.body:
I strongly support your views on the intelligence services and the public interest (Leaders, August 22). Of course you cannot have a secret service unless it is secret. But if the rule of law is to prevail, there must be circumstances in which a breach of confidence is at least excusable, if not wholly justified. If a member of the secret service were instructed to commit a crime and reported it to the police and no action was taken, surely the overriding importance of the freedom of the press should prevail and the right of the public to be informed?

In an address to the Dicey Conference in 1987, I referred to breach of confidence as one of the constraints on the press, but it is well established, by a number of decisions, and in particular, by the late Lord Denning, not only that exposure of "iniquity" justifies a breach of confidence, but that term was merely an instance of "just cause or excuse" for breaching confidence (Fraser v Evans 1969) "that it would be proper to disclose a crime to the police". That decision concerned a breach of confidence by an employee.

To contend that a member of the secret service is barred from exposing a threat to murder a head of state against which we are not at war would be to put one part of the community above the law of the land. To conspire, however, to eliminate a head of state with whom our country is at war would seem not only to be excusable but justified. It is a terrible irony when, apparently, it is considered to be entirely excusable, if not justified, to bomb, kill and maim from the air innocent civilians who are not responsible for their country going to war, and yet to leave unharmed (as in the case of Milosevic and Hussein) the heads of state responsible for involving their citizens in military activity.
Peter Carter-Ruck
London peter-carter-ruck@ dial.pipex.com

webTitle: Letters: Middle East: it's our turn

fields.headline: Middle East: it's our turn
fields.trailText: The impasse in the Middle East peace process (Israeli troops killed in bungled raid, August 28) provides the European Union with an opportunity to demonstrate the potential of the common foreign and security policy as it emerged from the Helsinki summit last December. The EU is uniquely placed to take an initiative.
fields.body:
The impasse in the Middle East peace process (Israeli troops killed in bungled raid, August 28) provides the European Union with an opportunity to demonstrate the potential of the common foreign and security policy as it emerged from the Helsinki summit last December. The EU is uniquely placed to take an initiative. First and foremost, it has shown that by pooling sovereignty in certain specific fields and by working together for the common good, nations can put aside the enmities of centuries and live in harmony. Second, unlike the US, the member states are perceived throughout the Middle East as neutral in this dispute.

Michael Adams (Comment, August 22) has put forward a sensible suggestion for the future of Jerusalem. The condominium he proposes might include a representative committee whose task would be to ensure respect for the Judaic, Christian and Muslim holy places in the city. In 1967, the characteristically vigorous diplomacy of the then foreign secretary, George Brown, during the debate at the UN following the Six Day war, provided the kernel of the security council resolution 242, which remains the only basis for peace in the Middle East. It would be entirely appropriate for the British government to stimulate a European initiative today.
Sir Donald Maitland
Bath

webTitle: Leader: Local museums must make their case

fields.headline: Collect and survive
fields.standfirst: Local museums must make their case
fields.trailText: Not everything that has found its way into a museum is worth conserving. Not every collection has a permanent claim on public support. Tastes change. Public interest waxes and wanes. In the internet age, objects can be appreciated virtually as well as in (dusty) situ.
fields.body:
Not everything that has found its way into a museum is worth conserving. Not every collection has a permanent claim on public support. Tastes change. Public interest waxes and wanes. In the internet age, objects can be appreciated virtually as well as in (dusty) situ. "Heritage" is not some fixed bill of goods. Each generation sifts and revalues what its predecessor bequeathes. But conquering time is one of the purposes of museums; they exist to ensure the passage of significant things through history. But at the moment when some national collections are enjoying huge popularity and making imaginative use of the windfall of capital from the National Lottery, a number of local museums are suffering. Our special report presented a compelling picture of cuts and decline among local authority collections. It is, necessarily, far from exhaustive. Valuable objects are looked after for public benefit by churches (mainly the Anglicans) and charities - which can also make a case for support. But it will need to be selective.

Making the case for extra assistance for all local museums is impossible; they are too diverse. And curators need to make up their minds about a matter of high political, maybe even constitutional moment: how free should councils be to decide their own service priorities.

Some collections have regional or even national significance and should be paid for accordingly - the new regional bodies have a role here; the move to use lottery money to help with running costs will help. But local collections must ultimately remain the responsibility of local people, who respond at the ballot box for their custodianship. Museums are not often high priorities and more could be done to promote them, linking them with commercial attractions, heritage centres and the like. This will involve "marketing" - for unless these local museums can teach local minds and lift local hearts, their future is grim.

fields.headline: Horse trade
fields.trailText: The last horse meat butcher in Britain did not close in 1938 (Where the horse is harnessed a la carte, August 25). My grandfather sold "super quality horse flesh" as "cheval viande" in Doncaster, from 1941 until his death in 1951, and the shop continued until 1955.
fields.body:
The last horse meat butcher in Britain did not close in 1938 (Where the horse is harnessed a la carte, August 25). My grandfather sold "super quality horse flesh" as "cheval viande" in Doncaster, from 1941 until his death in 1951, and the shop continued until 1955. Horse meat was not rationed during the war, although a butcher required a licence to sell it and it had to be stamped fit for human consumption. It was not to be sold on the bone and all cuts retailed at the same price per pound. My grandfather was a master butcher and often had to refuse emergency ration coupons when people mistook the meat on sale for beef.
Margaret Miles
Malpas, Cheshire

fields.headline: Restoring teacher pride
fields.standfirst:
Conditions are as important as pay

Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: London is not the only place with a teacher recruitment problem but it is by far the most severe. Horror stories in the capital multiply: a rising number of vacancies, a falling number of trainees, and a reliance on temporary supply teachers that resulted in pupils in one inner-city secondary school having 13 maths teachers in one 12-month period.
fields.body:
London is not the only place with a teacher recruitment problem but it is by far the most severe. Horror stories in the capital multiply: a rising number of vacancies, a falling number of trainees, and a reliance on temporary supply teachers that resulted in pupils in one inner-city secondary school having 13 maths teachers in one 12-month period. So much for continuity, an essential ingredient in successful education. The future looked even bleaker, with one research study earlier this year suggesting 40% of teachers are expected to leave London in the next five years. It is not just the difficulty of buying a home on a teacher's low pay, it can be just as difficult to find a home at an affordable rent. All of which makes David Blunkett's initiative yesterday in doubling London's "on the job" teacher training places extremely welcome.

Unlike college-based training courses, on-the-job schemes have attracted more recruits than vacancies. The 180 places currently available in the capital, under the excellence in cities programme, is to be doubled for the next four years. The scheme has proved particularly successful with mature applicants, eager to switch careers and attracted by the £13,000 salary that is paid. The education secretary is hoping to add two other perks: a bonus to trainees who go on to teach in the capital, plus some form of financial help to find a home. Both will be needed.

If this relieves the most acute problem, Mr Blunkett faces a more fundamental challenge: restoring the status of teachers so that the profession once again is an attractive option for graduate students across the country. Pay has to play a key part in this exercise, but other factors will also have to be addressed. A Guardian poll of teachers earlier this year, which showed half intending to quit within 10 years, showed 75% pointing to the increased workload and extra paperwork compared with 20% blaming low pay.

One reason why private schools have far fewer recruitment problems is not their higher salaries - only 10% more than state schools - but the extra staff that allow proper preparation time for classes and marking homework. In these conditions, teaching becomes much more satisfying. Renovating dilapidated schools will also play a part. But the main lesson is that both higher pay and higher staff numbers are needed to resolve the recruitment crisis.

In these conditions, teaching becomes much more satisfying. Renovating dilapidated schools will also play a part. But the main lesson is that both higher pay and higher staff numbers are needed to resolve the recruitment crisis.

webTitle: New phone link to monitor patients

fields.headline: New phone link to monitor patients
fields.trailText: Britain's biggest nursing agency, Nestor Healthcare, is planning a new service allowing doctors to monitor the pulse, blood pressure and temperature of convalescing patients over the telephone.
fields.body:
Britain's biggest nursing agency, Nestor Healthcare, is planning a new service allowing doctors to monitor the pulse, blood pressure and temperature of convalescing patients over the telephone.

Details of Healthwatch, likely to go live later this year, emerged as the company announced a 4% rise in interim pre-tax profits to £7.9m. It predicted booming business with the national health service.

Justin Jewitt, Nestor's chief executive, said Healthwatch could save time and money as patients would be able to stay at home, without round-the-clock care: "It's all under test at the moment - it will provide either intensive or sporadic support to patients without them leaving home."

Healthwatch will work through an electronic link attached to patients' phone lines. Doctors will be able to monitor heart rates either constantly or at regular intervals during the day.

Nestor's main business is supplying healthcare workers to hospitals and residential homes - the company has 113,000 nurses and carers on its books. First-half profits were affected by a withdrawal from the US last year - the company's UK profits rose 33% to £7.9m.

Mr Jewitt seemed confident of the future, predicting that the government's promise of more funds for the NHS would mean extra demand for staff.

He said: "It's a very good, very challenging review that the government has carried out. It's all about the velocity and volume of activity that the government's looking to deliver."

The chancellor has pledged to increase healthcare spending by 50% over five years. Mr Jewitt added that Nestor would benefit from the government's apparent willingness to contemplate more private sector involvement in the NHS.

fields.headline: City briefing
fields.trailText: Informa plans £50m spend
fields.body:
Informa plans £50m spend

Informa, the publications and conferences group, expects to spend £50m on a number of acquisitions over the next six months after a strong financial performance in the first half of the year.

Chairman Peter Rigby said Informa historically had bought small companies with pre-tax profits around the £1m mark but in future it would be concentrating on ones 10 times this size.

It is examining the possibility of purchasing titles for the drugs sector to fill a gap in its existing portfolio. Informa is already strong in telecoms, media and shipping where it owns the daily maritime paper Lloyds List.

Profits before tax and exceptional items in the first six months rose 28% to £20.6m, with adjusted earnings per share up 29% and a dividend of 2.53p proposed. The shares, which have already outperformed the sector by 6% this year, rose a further 29.5p to 749.5p.

fields.headline: David Edelstein
fields.standfirst: Judge who tackled the Teamsters
fields.trailText: Judge who tackled the Teamsters
fields.body:
America's longest-serving federal judge, David Edelstein, has died at the age of 90, still actively presiding over one of the Justice Department's most contentious cases - its 12-year battle to prise the Teamsters union from the hands of organised crime.

Earlier in his long career, the judge had set something of a world record, spending 43 years adjudicating the government's mammoth anti-trust case against IBM (the most important such action until the case against Microsoft).

Edelstein's increasingly short fuse during the endless hearings with IBM eventually provoked the company to successfully seek his removal from the case in 1995. In its judgment, the appellate court upheld the company's complaint, ruling that it was "manifestly clear that a reasonable observer would question the judge's impartiality".

The most recent example of Edelstein's robust judicial style came on June 16 this year when he was presented with the Teamsters' proposed new rules for next year's leadership elections. The government had already accepted them as sufficiently stringent to stop the widespread corruption that has characterised the union's voting for decades.

But Judge Edelstein would have none of it. "The submissions are a farrago of ill advice and misguided, inept, controversial and confused argots," he declared. "Their programme has the potential of bringing grief, strife, controversy and corruption."

He was well accustomed to controversy, which had hit him from the moment President Truman nominated him for the federal bench in 1951. Though his family was comfortably off, Edelstein had to pay his own way through college as a stock exchange page boy (where he witnessed the 1929 market crash first hand). After a period of private practice, until after the war, he eventually opted for a steady income and began climbing the department of justice ladder as attorney for various federal government departments.

He was not Truman's first choice when a vacancy arose on the New York federal bench, and his nomination was strongly opposed by three separate bar associations. They were concerned about his lack of trial experience, but Truman's presidency was coming to a close and, amid the election fever which brought the Republican Dwight Eisenhower to the White House, the Senate confirmed Edelstein's appointment.

The case against IBM came to his court almost as soon as he took his seat in 1952. After four years of argument, the company formally agreed to modify its business practices. However, as is usual in such cases, the details proved endlessly complicated and contentious. Time and again, year after year, IBM was brought back to court for alleged breaches of its undertakings. The paperwork eventually reached millions of pages, but Edelstein refused to let the Justice Department withdraw the case. Finally, to everyone's relief, the appeal court's ruling against him brought in another judge.

While the IBM case was still on his calendar, Edelstein was also assigned to the government's action against the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, which controls much of the nation's road transport and was notorious for being in the hands of the mafia. The federal government had been trying to take effective action since the union was expelled from the main trade union federation in 1958. President Eisenhower brought in special legislation in 1959, but the mysterious disappearance (and presumed murder) of the Teamsters's president, Jimmy Hoffa, in 1975 showed that little had changed.

The finding by a 1986 presidential commission that the union had been "firmly under the control of organised crime since the 1950s" finally brought charges in June 1988 under the Racketeer Influenced and Corrupt Organisations Act (RICO), an extremely wide-ranging law which even mafia lawyers have found difficult to circumvent. Faced with such drastic measures, the union surrendered unconditionally within months, and Judge Edelstein was appointed to supervise its electoral affairs until satisfied they were in order.

Though initially there were significant improvements, further problems soon came to Edelstein's courtroom, including allegations of gerrymandering, corruption, and embezzlement. Once again the hearings in the case went on for years. Eventually, the judge approved the removal of the union's president (which brought Jimmy Hoffa's son James to the post) and, as his last contribution to this long-running drama, finally accepted the union's revised electoral rules.

The Teamsters case had only come before Edelstein because he had flatly refused to retire in 1980 when he reached the customary age of 70. He knew, of course, that Article III of the constitution stipulates that federal judges "shall hold their offices during good behaviour" - in other words, for life. If that was the express wish of the founding fathers, Edelstein apparently reasoned, who was he to argue?

He is survived by his wife Florence and their two sons.

David Norton Edelstein, jurist, born February 16 1910; died August 19 2000

webTitle: Stately home crisis: Heir struggles to keep estate in the family

fields.headline: Stately home crisis: Heir struggles to keep estate in the family
fields.trailText: Visitors to a stately home this weekend will pay £4 to see fine furniture, learn a little history and watch a falconry demonstration.
fields.body:
Visitors to a stately home this weekend will pay £4 to see fine furniture, learn a little history and watch a falconry demonstration.

But visitor income alone will not save Leighton Hall, Lancashire, built in 1763, listed Grade II* and long connected with the Gillow family, the renowned Lancaster furniture makers.

Nor will the handsome cheque handed over for permission to shoot scenes for a film version of AS Byatt's novel Possession.

And nor will fees from wedding receptions. "There are not enough Saturdays in the year," said Richard Gillow Reynolds, who inherited the estate in 1977.

He has since sought ways to boost the maintenance fund and had pinned his hopes on a time-share development based on farm buildings. But ministers turned down the scheme after a public inquiry.

A crisis loomed. This year Mr Reynolds announced he would take no more bookings for weddings or corporate events. His wife, Suzie, warned that after showing round visitors for 25 years she could soon be giving estate agents the full tour.

Mr Reynolds admitted that selling up would relieve him of a lot of worry and leave him comfortably off. "But when you live in a house and on land for long enough it gets a grip on you. I have a responsibility to maintain, improve and hand on the estate to my daughter. I'm also concerned for the jobs of 60 people."

He has had to deal with an annual cash shortfall which now runs at £25,000. He had thought the time-share plan, with 55 upmarket units, was a winner. English Heritage approved, and Lancaster council gave planning permission. But villagers in Yealand Conyers objected, claiming that lanes would be clogged with traffic and the new buildings would be an eyesore.

After the public inquiry, the Department of the Environment inspector ruled against the estate. It seemed inevitable that the "for sale" boards would go up. But now there is a glimmer of hope: a scheme for offices.

"The house will not now go on the market next year, and we have started taking bookings once more," said Mr Reynolds. "But we will have to go through the planning process again."

fields.headline: The best masseur scene: Timecode
fields.trailText: LA. Outside the offices of the Red Mullet film company, an athletic man carrying a folded massage chair (Julian Sands) approaches a receptionist.
fields.body:
LA. Outside the offices of the Red Mullet film company, an athletic man carrying a folded massage chair (Julian Sands) approaches a receptionist.

"Hi, I'm Quintus. From Roman Springs. People call me Q."

The receptionist looks up.

"Hm-hm."

"I'm here to do the massage."

"Oh! Wonderful! What kind of massage do you do?"

Quintus puts down his chair and begins to mime various massage treatments.

"Ah, I gently caress the soft tissue - Swedish technique. For deeper penetration, I use a Shiatsu technique. I massage auras, I hover chakras,whatever makes you come."

"Excuse me?"

The phone rings.

"Red Mullet, hello?... I'll put you through."

The receptionist gets up from her desk. Quintus moves his chair into a corner.

"I can leave that here. Mostly I just need a workspace."

The receptionist beckons him into the office.

"Well, OK. They've all just gone into a meeting right now..."

"Oh, that's excellent! I can attack the motherlode."

"Ah, OK. But you'll have to just be subtle."

"Oh, I am subtle. And discreet."

She directs him into a meeting room, where a number of executives are in conference.

"Ah, hi. This is Q. From Roman Springs."

Quintus raises his arm.

"Hail! Ego sum Quintus, your friendly gladiator. People call me Q. I come from Roman Springs, and I say to your tension - Veni, Vidi, Vici."

The executives stare at him blankly.

See also: Pulp Fiction, After Hours, Barton Fink

Don't see also: 8 Women

Pointless trivia: Julian Sands was author Anne Rice's first choice to play Lestat in Interview With A Vampire, before the role was given to Tom Cruise.

fields.headline: Edith Körner
fields.standfirst:
She was a pioneering NHS expert and he was an outstanding philosopher. They chose to die together

Special report: the future of the NHS
fields.trailText: She was a pioneering NHS expert and he was an outstanding philosopher. They chose to die together
fields.body:
Edith Körner, who has died of cancer aged 79, was an influential figure in the development of the information and statistics system used by the National Health Service. Edith also played a significant role as chair of the magistrates' bench in Bristol. Edith was one of that band of remarkable people who came as refugees to this country from eastern Europe and who have contributed so much and in so many ways to its wellbeing.

Born in Znojmo, Czechoslovakia, the daughter of a prosperous corn miller, she arrived in the United Kingdom as a schoolgirl in 1939, alone, and never again to see her parents or 40 other relatives who perished in the Nazi extermination camps. She spoke no English but was fluent in Russian, German, Italian and French. These skills, allied with her intelligence and determination, enabled her to earn a living monitoring enemy military and civilian radio traffic; at the same time she obtained, in two years, an honours degree in economics at the London School of Economics.

During the war, she met her husband Stephan, also from Czechoslovakia, who was doing a PhD in philosophy at Cambridge University. When the war ended, she went with him to Bristol, where he had obtained a chair at the university. There, they brought up their two children and she began her involvement in public life.

Perhaps it was natural with her background that she should first support the weakest and most vulnerable people. In the 1950s, patients with mental illness in large institutions were the often conveniently forgotten part of the NHS. Edith realised that with modern drug treatment and support many patients could live at home or in the wider community. She exerted a crucial influence in the restructuring of this sector, showing how this might be achieved through the work she supported at the long-stay Barrow and Glenside hospitals in Bristol.

This led to appointments in the regional health service - she became chair of the south western regional health authority in 1976 - where she established a national reputation for clear thinking, innovation and the ability to speak with knowledge on a range of issues.

No one was surprised when she was chosen in 1980 by the then secretary of state for social services, Patrick Jenkin, to chair a full-scale review of health service information. The Körner committee sat for four years and produced six reports, all of which were, unusually, accepted and acted upon within deadlines. It was the first major examination of the way the NHS collected and used its data and set the way forward for a comprehensive computerisation of the health system. For her work on the committee, she was awarded a CBE.

Her energies, however, were not contained only in this field. In 1966, she was appointed a magistrate on the city bench in Bristol. Her proudest moment came when she was elected its first chairwoman. She was sharp with those who she felt did not appreciate the need to separate the judiciary from the executive as the lynchpin in our democratic government. She had experienced the breakdown of this in her childhood and was only too aware of the vigilance necessary to maintain it - and how easy it was to take it for granted.

In support of this, she co-wrote a paper entitled Reducing Delays in Magistrates Courts: A Practical Guide. It was a sorrow to her that her suggestions were not heeded in the same way as her work for the NHS. It could have saved millions and provided for much quicker and fairer treatment of defendants.

The leadership of this distinguished and highly intelligent woman reached its peak during the so-called "poll tax" disturbances. In Bristol, 20,000 people refused to pay; and in spite of the fact that her political persuasion made her equally against the tax, she chaired the majority of the hearings.

For that we salute her, for the courage shown in her life and in the manner of her going. She and her husband chose to die together in their home. She is survived by their son and daughter.

webTitle: Irish take stake in Budgens for £89m

fields.headline: Irish take stake in Budgens for £89m
fields.trailText: Irish food group Musgrave yesterday revealed it was paying £89.4m for a stake worth up to 43.5% in the Budgens convenience store chain.
fields.body:
Irish food group Musgrave yesterday revealed it was paying £89.4m for a stake worth up to 43.5% in the Budgens convenience store chain.

Musgrave, which operates 500 stores across the Irish Republic and Northern Ireland, is initially buying a 28% holding together with loan stock from German retailer ReWe, which can be converted into shares.

Analysts last night branded the deal "nothing but good news" and predicted it could result in a full merger within three years.

Philip Dorgan of WestLB Panmure said: "They speak the same language and there's a clear overlap between the two businesses."

Privately-owned Musgrave has agreed not to make a bid for the remaining Budgens shares for at least 12 months - unless a third party comes into the frame. Any subsequent offer, it promised, would only come with the blessing of the Budgens board.

The announcement lifted Budgens' shares 8.5p to 79p. Budgens has about 200 shops in the south-east of England and reported pre-tax profits of £14.6m on sales of £451m in its most recent financial year.

ReWe acquired the Budgens stake in 1993 but its expansion strategy has recently focused away from Britain and on to southern and eastern Europe.

Clive Clague, chairman of Budgens, said: "We are very pleased that Musgrave has invested in Budgens and we believe it underpins our own confidence in this thriving business and its future."
