Privately-owned Musgrave has agreed not to make a bid for the remaining Budgens shares for at least 12 months - unless a third party comes into the frame. Any subsequent offer, it promised, would only come with the blessing of the Budgens board. The announcement lifted Budgens' shares 8.5p to 79p. Budgens has about 200 shops in the south-east of England and reported pre-tax profits of £14.6m on sales of £451m in its most recent financial year. ReWe acquired the Budgens stake in 1993 but its expansion strategy has recently focused away from Britain and on to southern and eastern Europe. Clive Clague, chairman of Budgens, said: "We are very pleased that Musgrave has invested in Budgens and we believe it underpins our own confidence in this thriving business and its future."

fields.headline: Average home costs more than £100,000
fields.standfirst:
Despite breaking the psychological barrier prices have flattened out in fastest growing areas

More about house prices
fields.trailText: The average price of a home in England and Wales has passed £100,000 for the first time, according to figures released today. Data from the Land Registry shows that the average home cost £103,115 in the period April 1 to June 30, compared with £99,295 in the period from January to March.
fields.body:
The average price of a home in England and Wales has passed £100,000 for the first time, according to figures released today. Data from the Land Registry shows that the average home cost £103,115 in the period April 1 to June 30, compared with £99,295 in the period from January to March.

But the figures also provide further evidence of a slowdown. Some of the London areas that have notched up the strongest price growth in the last two years have slowed down markedly and some locations, including Derby, Middlesbrough and Merthyr Tyd fil, have seen prices fall since the start of the year.

A Land Registry spokeswoman said: "If you exclude sales of under £10,000 and over £1m - which we have done - this is the first time the average property price in England and Wales has broken the £100,000 barrier."

The figures show the average home is worth 14.5% more than a year ago. But this disguises wide regional variations. Greater London continues to lead the way, with a typical property costing £177,182 - up 23.3% on an annual basis. This is more than four times the 5.1% annual price growth achieved in the north of England, where the average property now costs £61,798. Close behind London is the south west, which has seen price growth of 20.3% over the year. There, the average property costs £101,750.

Areas outside the capital which have seen the largest increases include Reading - where prices have risen 34.8% in a year, from £101,460 to £136,753, nearby Wokingham, Berkshire, which was up 26.2% from £144,414 to £182,299, and Bath and north-east Somerset, up 33.7%, from £101,478 to £135,649.

Prices in London as a whole have increased by 8.5% between the first and second quarter this year, but in some of the capital's most desirable locations, such as Kensington and Chelsea and Islington, the increases are - 4.3% and 5.3% respectively - indicating these areas are now flattening out in the wake of the record growth achieved in the last two years. In these two boroughs the average price of a home is now £358,899 and £234,066 respectively.

The volume of sales increased by 6.5% - from 218,393 in April to June 1999 to 232,548 in the same period this year.

The figures also reveal that the number of homes sold worth £1m or more has doubled - from 198 in the second quarter of 1999 to 394 in the second quarter of this year. Some 107 properties worth more than £2m changed hands during the latter period, almost half of which were in the London borough of Kensington and Chelsea.

The Land Registry figures are regarded as providing the most accurate picture of the housing market because they are based on the vast majority of all property sales.

However, the latest figures only concern the period up to the end of June, so observers will be waiting for the latest monthly house price data from the Nationwide and Halifax, due out in the next few days, to see how the market fared in August. Nationwide said the cost of an average home fell 0.2% in July, while Halifax said it increased by 0.3%.

fields.headline: BAT dismisses WHO plans
fields.standfirst: Special report: smoking
fields.trailText: British American Tobacco yesterday went on the offensive against the World Health Organisation, describing plans for a global framework to limit smoking as "fundamentally flawed" and simplistic.
fields.body:
British American Tobacco yesterday went on the offensive against the World Health Organisation, describing plans for a global framework to limit smoking as "fundamentally flawed" and simplistic.

The company, which makes Rothmans, Benson & Hedges and Lucky Strike cigarettes, called instead for "a climate of genuine cooperation", demanding that the world's big tobacco companies be involved in any attempts to regulate the industry.

Chief executive Martin Broughton said: "Our framework will relieve the WHO of the cost and bureaucracy in volved in its wish to become a single global tobacco regulator, leaving it free to do what it should be doing - policy orientation."

BAT offered to support independent research on the reasons teenagers take up smoking. It proposed an "agenda for action on health", concentrating on measures to inform the public of the risks of tobacco, encourage people to switch to low tar products and prevent children from picking up the habit.

BAT admits that there are "serious health risks" associated with its products. However, it stressed the importance of ensuring that tobacco markets remain orderly and that regulations on smoking in public places took into account the wishes of both smokers and non-smokers.

Mr Broughton said: "The WHO's proposal for a prescriptive 'one-size-fits-all' convention and protocols overlooks the diverse social, economic, cultural and political priorities in different countries around the world."

The WHO, under the leadership of the former Norwegian prime minister Gro Harlem Brundtland, has made campaigning against smoking one of its top priorities.

It says cigarettes could kill a billion people this century, at a rate of 10m a year by 2030, a forecast which BAT rejects.

webTitle: Italian food boom reaches new heights

fields.headline: Italian food boom reaches new heights
fields.standfirst:
The British will soon be eating three times as many pizzas as they do now

Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: When the Russian Proton rocket bound for the International Space Station launched into space in July with a Pizza Hut logo splashed across its side, you could almost feel the collective cringe.
fields.body:
When the Russian Proton rocket bound for the International Space Station launched into space in July with a Pizza Hut logo splashed across its side, you could almost feel the collective cringe.

Metaphorical references to a business smashing through the stratosphere aside, the pizza business in Britain is literally taking off. As the pizza and Italian food sector as a whole has modernised, and with the advent of stylised, and affordable outlets such as Pizza Express expanding across the country, the sector appears to be attracting a new customer base.

Asher Svirsky, a former hotel chef, and Russell Allen, ex- food and beverage manager at a Thistle hotel in London, spent the best part of a year researching the restaurant trade with the aim of setting up an eaterie in South London. It wasn't long before they had abandoned the idea and launched a pizza delivery service. Their London-based, up-market operation Basilico, which sells top-of-the-range (ie pay more for quality) takeaway and delivery pizzas, launched at the end of 1998 and its two units have an annual turnover in excess of £1m. The two entrepreneurs have lofty ambitions.

"We decided on pizzas because the sector is growing at a faster pace than any other," Svirsky says. When we first spoke to people in the sector they said there was no point because it was saturated. But we did research and, put simply, we have a different proposition."

He sees no reason not to have more than 40 units in London and beyond within a few years. The business is, he says, virtually recession-proof. "Even if people stop eating out during a recession, the one thing they will allow themselves is takeaways." Surveys increasingly indicate that frenetic modern lifestyles are forcing us towards the convenience of take away or restaurant-cooked food.

It is estimated that 30% of disposable income in Britain is spent on eating out. Research company, Mintel values the market for eating out in Britain at £24.3bn per year whilst Taylor Nelson forecast that this will rise to £31bn by 2005. The UK pizza delivery's estimated market is worth around £360m.

Whilst the fashion for trendy, high-price eateries may have had its day, the more established pizza and Italian food sector appears to be undergoing something of a renaissance. Pizzas may not be as glamorous or as pricy as the recent wave of modern European cuisine, but they're popular and profitable.

Perfect Pizza, one of the largest pizza delivery firms in Britain says it expects the market to grow by at least a third in the next few years. The company, which was bought for £20m earlier this year by US Pizza group Papa Johns, is aiming for 370 outlets, 100 of which are expected to open in the next five years to meet expected increase in demand. Managing director Tony Sherriff said: "Our research indicates that if, as expected, we follow the American trend in eating and lifestyle, the British will soon be eating three times as many pizzas as they do now."

Chris Moore, marketing director of Domino's Pizza, which has 21% of the delivery market in the UK, says that demand is "insatiable". The industry has benefited from the rapid growth of home entertainment such as Playstation and Digital television, which explains the company's deals with cable companies so that customers can order pizzas over the internet or via their television sets. "We have been doing very well but there is still a huge chunk of the market untapped."

The appeal of Italian restaurants is no less significant. Belgo, owners of the Belgian mussels and beer restaurants in London and smaller theme restaurants, Bieradrome have recently gone Italian with the launch of three London pizza restaurants called Strada. Chairman of Belgo group, Luke Johnson came to the group from Pizza Express and it would seem that he has brought his interest in the sector with him. Belgo's chief Andy Bassadone says the group is filling a gap in the market between the mid-range operations such as Pizza Express and "independent, up-market Italian restaurants."

He estimates that there is room for at least 30 Stradas in London alone because they offer a more traditional, but slightly more expensive alternative to the cheaper chains. "This is a growth area. The Italian market is saturated with choice for a reason. There's demand."

He expects a total of ten London operations by early next year and says the city, which was concerned by the group's profit warning earlier this year, will start to take this arm of the business seriously once the roll-out of restaurants gains momentum.

Analysts have been nervous about the restaurant trade following recent disappointing results from high-profile chains such as Conran. One analyst said that a significant reason for the success of the Italian sector is that it has consistently attracted good management teams. "What's important in all of this is, whatever the market forecasts, is that the concept is right, and the management needs to be the best. Without this no sector will thrive." He said Pizza Express, which has an annual turnover in excess of £60m and was one of the first chains to capitalise on the demand for pizza, is a good example of how this can work.

Pizza Express chief executive Ian Eldridge warns: "The restaurant industry is hugely fragmented by nature. There are, very strong independent operators in the pizza sector, but there will be some consolidation among the chains eventually. As is always the case, the strong will survive. The trick is not to be complacent."

webTitle: Oftel warns BT of line cost curb

fields.headline: Oftel warns BT of line cost curb
fields.trailText: British Telecom was dealt another blow yesterday when watchdog Oftel said that the embattled telecoms company was overcharging the wholesale fixed line market and stifling competition.
fields.body:
British Telecom was dealt another blow yesterday when watchdog Oftel said that the embattled telecoms company was overcharging the wholesale fixed line market and stifling competition.

Oftel said that it would consider regulating the wholesale fixed line market for four years and assume responsibility for pricing after that period. It had earlier emerged from its review that BT's charges were "significantly higher" than those of its European peers.

The review's timing was poor for BT which has recently suffered a credit downgrade by Standard & Poor and criticism from institutional shareholders over its foot-dragging in undertaking partial flotations of some of its divisions. Shares in BT were up 3p at 825p yesterday.

Ann Lambert, Oftel's director of operations, said that the regulator was concerned about the lack of competition in retail leased lines. This was because BT did not offer a wholesale leased line product to other telecoms operators, according to Ms Lambert, thereby creating a barrier for competitors.

Instead, she said BT was selling leased lines to competitors at retail prices, making it more expensive for the end customers. "If competition is not effective then we have no hesitation in regulating," said Ms Lambert.

Leased lines are permanently connected communication links. They are bought from BT by telecom, mobile and internet service providers who want to provide voice, data and internet services to large corporations.

Oftel began its review of the leased line market last No vember. It is expected to make a decision on its draft recommendations after the consultation period which ends in October.

The regulator estimated that BT's profits on retail leased lines was as much as 31%.

BT yesterday questioned Oftel's findings. "We do have some concerns about Oftel's analysis and conclusions on the price comparison study," a BT spokesman said. "The fat lady has not yet sung." The spokesman added that BT supported the idea of other operators building their own infrastructure as a way of encouraging competition.

Oftel has already said that the market for leased lines, estimated to be worth around £1.4bn, is expensive for BT's competitors to enter.

Sir Peter Bonfield, chief executive of BT, has said that the UK group is considering splitting its retail and wholesale fixed line division and may make a partial public offering of the latter.

Serafino Abape, of telecoms consultant Ovum, said the Oftel's review would "be negative and affect BT's business". "The market for leased lines is where competition is becoming increasingly important because of the explosion of demand for broadband." Broadband lines allow the delivery of high speed internet and other data services.

Ms Lambert said a drop in the wholesale leased line price could eventually lead to lower charges by internet service providers.

BT yesterday launched its high speed internet service. It was also listed as one of the 10 bidders in the Swiss government's auction of four third generation mobile licences.

fields.headline: Perk practice
fields.standfirst:
A subsidised bar, 'duvet days', free fruit, a leisure zone, a mention in your boss's will ... Anita Chaudhuri on the increasingly desperate ploys companies use to keep their staff

Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: A subsidised bar, 'duvet days', free fruit, a leisure zone, a mention in your boss's will ... Anita Chaudhuri on the increasingly desperate ploys companies use to keep their staff.
fields.body:
So, you think that you get along well with your boss? Maybe they compliment you on a job well done, send you a birthday card or invite you to spend the weekend at their country retreat. But how much do they like you really? Think ahead, as far as 30 years. When your boss dies, will he like you enough to remember you in his will?

It sounds highly unlikely in today's frantically insecure workplace, yet earlier this month, that is what happened to 15 long-serving employees of the late Tory MP Michael Colvin. When he and his wife died in a fire at their home, recipients of their bequests included the gardener Bernard Taylor, who received £6,700, and the laundry lady, the farm manager, the butler and the butler's wife, all of whom received £1,000.

While most employers might not go quite this far, there is evidence that an increasing number of firms are keen to foster a similarly paternalistic culture of loyalty. One recent example of this came from management consultants Arthur Andersen who announced that they are to hand out £10,000 "golden hellos" to welcome all new graduate trainees, claiming that rather than wanting to trap them into a job for life, they were doing it because they wanted to help the recruits pay off their student debts.

Elsewhere, particularly in the City, where the dot.com brain drain is hitting staffing levels, companies are trying to hang on to people by introducing supermarket-style reward points. These are accumulated and cashed in for benefits covering everything from paid sabbaticals to in-house yoga sessions. Nowhere is this loyalty culture more evident than at the west end offices of TBWA, the advertising agency, whose clients include the Labour Party. Staff can chill out in a leisure zone equipped with two Sony Playstation pods and all the latest games, video screens and a pool table. At six o'clock every evening the reception area is transformed into a subsidised bar and twice a week there's a happy hour where all drinks are free.

The company is one of many who now offer two "duvet days" a year, where workers get permission to skive off, presumably very popular on mornings after happy hour. "People work long hours here, and we want to reward them for that," explains Neil Christie, chief operating officer. "One way is by letting them have a drink at the end of the day, it's kind of like everyone meeting up in the village square. Very often staff will then go back to their desks and work several hours in the evening, so it's like a tea break with booze. We like to make our staff feel part of something, to try and give something back."

Increasingly, companies are falling over themselves to remind stressed-out workers that, yes, they may be working 12-hour days, but don't think for a minute that the boss doesn't care. "The traditional concept of the loyal, wise boss who handed down universal benefits from on high is dead," says Nick Page, adviser on pay and conditions for the Chartered Institute of Personnel Development. "That all disappeared during the high white-collar unemployment of the early 1980s; employees became disillusioned and more demanding.

"Now bosses are having to wake up to the fact that their staff are both individuals, and customers. In practice, that means companies are having to address the diversity of lifestyles among their workforce - in a creative business with a young staff, for example, it's not appropriate only to offer childcare and pension plans. By contrast, pet insurance is very popular in those types of firms - and 3% of firms we surveyed now offer that. Another way companies are trying to create loyalty is by giving something back, especially when staff work very long hours. That's why we're seeing 'concierge' benefits - grocery shopping, laundry and even on-site evening classes - becoming very popular."

In the quest to nurture stressed-out employees, firms are resorting to increasingly desperate measures. Law firm Mischon de Reya experimented with a company poet. Management consultants Ernst and Young offer a confidential counselling line for staff to sort out their personal lives. Credit Suisse First Boston now offers honeymoon leave, and elsewhere in the City, Saloman Smith Barney has taken to providing gourmet meals, fresh underwear and free toothbrushes to staff working past 7pm.

"If you want to keep staff then you have to look after them," says Hilda Barrett, group human resources manager at Microsoft. "That's why we try and create a campus atmosphere at our office. We have top quality gourmet food always available and in the evenings we even run cookery classes. Oh yes, and you also get Waitrose Direct, a grocery shopping service. Who wants to waste their spare time pushing a supermarket trolley?" Every morning Microsoft workers are offered free fruit with breakfast, a nice touch, but one which might feel annoyingly prescriptive. At their headquarters there is an area called "the anarchy zone" where stressed out workers can play pool, watch a 54-inch cable TV screen, lounge around on squashy sofas, play video games, drink top quality lattes or read all the latest magazines. Despite the fact that writer Douglas Coupland branded the firm's workers Microserfs in a recent book, the staff turnover in the UK is only 8%. "We must be doing something right," says Barrett.

It's not surprising that the most far-reaching loyalty programmes are being introduced by American firms, where staff benefits are far more sophisticated. Ford provides its assembly line workers with free home computers, while it's rumoured that New York restaurants are resorting to pension plans in a bid to recruit dish washers. Recently, Seattle software company Aventail was so desperate to hire one 19-year-old graduate that it relocated two of her friends from Ohio and found them jobs too.

As we all spend more and more of our lives at work, many employers are attempting to redress the balance by making office life more like home, often with the boss cast as surrogate parent. Business development agency The Fourth Room, for example, has offices which are designed like a house. Each morning the kitchen table is set for breakfast and a family lunch is held twice a week. British Airways' new head office near Heathrow takes the concept a stage further, featuring a Big Brother style corporate village with its own high street and TV station BA TV. More worrying still, staff are no longer known as employees but as residents.

"I don't think company loyalty is dead," says Lin Arigho, who runs design consultancy Aricot Vert. She was voted Britain's best boss in a recent competition of worker-friendly employers. Trisha King, media researcher

I'm only here until I can get a break in the field I want. I know that and the company knows that - it even gives me time off for interviews. It's a small firm and we all get along brilliantly; there is constant banter in the office and we have regular staff nights out. I'll miss them but not enough to stick around.

Ben Andersen, urban regenerator

I'm new to the company so my loyalty is at its all time high. At the moment it's inconceivable to see myself being tempted away. Elizabeth Coates, financial journalist

I'll be loyal to this publication as long as it continues to provide me with opportunities - I don't want to get stuck in a rut. The magazine has a really good working environment, as well as an impressive reputation. I travel abroad frequently and the money's good. I wouldn't change jobs for a pay rise alone - it would have to be something which interested me.

I'm totally loyal to the pub I work in because I'm treated well. They pay me decent money, give me lunch when I work and days off when I want, so I work hard. fields.headline: Of loss and longing
fields.standfirst:
Czech Philharmonic Orchestra/ Charles Mackerras
***
Usher Hall, Edinburgh
fields.trailText:
Czech Philharmonic Orchestra/ Charles Mackerras
***
Usher Hall, Edinburgh
fields.body:
The music of Josef Suk is now a genuine rarity in the orchestral repertoire. Sir Charles Mackerras and the Czech Philharmonic showcased Suk's most ambitious work, the Asrael Symphony, in the first of their Edinburgh international festival concerts, but while this may have been a festival event in name, there was nothing particularly festive about a half-full Usher Hall. Maybe it is because Edinburgh is steadily emptying itself of tourists, thanks to the unsynchronised starting times of the fringe and international festivals. Even so, it is strange that the lure of Mackerras, who has been a firm favourite in festival director Brian McMaster's era, did not entice a larger audience for the adventure of the Asrael Symphony.

Composed between 1904 and 1906, and widely considered to be Suk's masterpiece, the Asrael Symphony is dedicated to Dvorak, Suk's father-in-law, and Otylka, Suk's wife. After Dvorak's death in 1904, Suk planned a five-movement symphony and completed the work's first three movements. Tragically, Otylka died just a year later, so Suk transformed his ideas for a fast-paced finale, and composed two slow, adagio movements in her memory. The resulting symphony is, unsurprisingly, a largely gloomy meditation on death and grief.

The work is Mahlerian in its scope and length, as well as its emphasis on musical narrative over conventional structures. The second movement is a warped recollection of happier times, a grotesquely slowed-down and fragmented folk dance. And for all the surface beauty of the orchestration of the scherzo third movement, there is a bitter, acerbic quality to Suk's melodic invention. The glorious tune in the central section of this movement is the only passage in the whole work where Suk allows himself to indulge in the tenderness of his love for Otylka. Mackerras and the Czech Philharmonic responded with playing of open-hearted warmth.

The surrounding movements are the emotional heart of the symphony, and chart the progress of an ominous motto theme from C minor, trombone-laden darkness, to a transfigured, C major light. Mackerras and his Czech players handled this journey with immaculate dramatic timing. But somehow a sense of the emotional precipice on which Suk's Asrael Symphony is built was never fully revealed.

webTitle: Review: ManMoMa: A Thick Bloke Kicking a Dog to Death

fields.headline: Curios, pop art and surrealist outtakes
fields.standfirst:
ManMoMa: A Thick Bloke Kicking a Dog to Death
***
International 3, Manchester
fields.trailText:
ManMoMa: A Thick Bloke Kicking a Dog to Death
***
International 3, Manchester
fields.body:
A joint venture between Work Leisure International and Manchester's annual summer show, this exhibition has one of the most striking subtitles seen for a while. But animal-lovers can rest easy: like most of the work in this show, it is not to be taken literally.

Housed in an orange-brick Victorian corner building, this one-room collection of curios, pop art and surrealist outtakes features the work of local artists, one or two London names, and the likes of Tracey Emin and Jake and Dinos Chapman by way of a sweetener.

Emin's single exhibit, The Calling of St Anthony: the Patron Saint of All Things Lost, shows her penchant for gathering words and objects, here simplified to a framed litany of things you might lose, from integrity to teeth, from magic to marbles. The Chapman brothers' contribution is the 1997 video of a tour of their studio.

Much of the work here is playful to the point of frivolity, but Helen Bendon and Jo Lansley offer more with their enchanting, slightly disturbing look at girlhood. Linger is an autumnal portrait of a girl in tights, her hip-bones protruding. As she lies among the leaves, it is impossible to see her face for hair. There is an air of disquiet rather than repose.

The pair's video work explores further this meeting of danger and delight. The Sweet Smell of Success shows them dressed as schoolgirls, breaking into a house to steal eggs. One passes the eggs through the window to her accomplice, who then fills her tights with them. As she walks away, she appears both funny and grotesque, as if her legs are covered in boils.

As with much Britart at the moment, there is plenty here that is self-reflexively whimsical. Peter Cliff's Being an Artist reminds us that the job involves "total commitment to an activity which everyone else thinks is a complete waste of time", while Dean Hughes's Two Nails, Wire and a Bit of Masking Tape is exactly that. Polish-born Kristin Mojsiewicz uses her native language to mock both its apparent complexity and, more importantly, our response to it. She does this by printing Polish tongue-twisters in an eye-test format of diminishing black letters.

Local artist and musical misfit Edward Barton also makes an appearance, represented by Dog Sorry, a placard smeared in a turd-like paint that spells (smells?) out the work's own title.

fields.headline: Kitsch in sync
fields.standfirst:
Les Gammas
**
Jazz Cafe, London
fields.trailText:
Les Gammas
**
Jazz Cafe, London
fields.body:
It's hard to place jazz trio Les Gammas. One minute they are improvising funky electronics, the next Mark Frank, their singing drummer, is yodelling a cheesy love song and telling 20 people to clap quietly so the band can pretend they are playing to an intimate crowd.

Their stage presence suggests novelty, a kitsch in-joke: they're not wearing glitter, fake fur or bargain-bin platforms but they might as well be. And yet, Frank, Jochen Helfert on the Fender Rhodes and PE Spier on bass are deadly serious. The way they play riffs from 70s jazz and film score maestros such as Bernard Hermann, Antonio Carlos Jobim, Lalo Schifrin and Leone Thomas, you'd think they were young lions at the Village Vanguard instead of an empty Jazz Cafe.

They don't always sound this artificial. Signed to lauded Munich jazz-dance label Compost, Les Gammas have become known for having a twisted ear for super-syncopated clubby grooves. Unfortunately, their live sound barely resembles that of their critically acclaimed, aptly titled debut album, Exercises de Style.

Rhythmically at least, Les Gammas are militant with a minimal swing, and what could have been a set of aggravating plastic funk is occasionally engrossing. That's partly due to Frank's melodic, even catchy sensibility. Twinned with Helfert's fascinating dalliance with Larry Levan-style disco and Spier's dubby basslines on Chasing the Double Six, he gets the band off to a good start. Inevitably, though, they fall in a rut and acid jazz jams follow. Frank, Helfert and Spier's good humour remains the one constant through all these improvising set-ups. But when Frank begins to scat badly throughout See the Sun, the joke is on us.

The strongest songs, Love Unlimited and Austrian Shepherd Dance, are saved for last; but although their monumental grooves are highly infectious, it's too late. The band are not shrewd enough to cloak their shortcomings and finish with another acid jazz session. Still, why worry about something as banal and human as an authentic voice when you've constructed a gallery of masks to hide behind?

fields.headline: Exchange rejects OM offer
fields.standfirst: Germans may launch white-knight bid to kill Swedes' £808m hostile campaign
fields.trailText: The London Stock Exchange found itself fighting a hostile takeover bid yesterday for the first time in its 227-year history, as Sweden's OM Gruppen tabled an £808m offer with a promise to safeguard the future of "Britain's crown jewel."
fields.body:
The London Stock Exchange found itself fighting a hostile takeover bid yesterday for the first time in its 227-year history, as Sweden's OM Gruppen tabled an £808m offer with a promise to safeguard the future of "Britain's crown jewel."

OM, which operates the Stockholm stock market, said its cutting-edge technology could secure London's position as Europe's centre for share dealing. Its plans were given a qualified welcome by some of the City's leading stockbrokers.

Don Cruickshank, chairman of the London exchange, dismissed the proposal as "derisory" and pledged to press on with the planned merger with the Deutsche Börse in Frankfurt, to create the iX exchange.

Mr Cruickshank said: "Their offer does little to advance our strategic goals in Europe. Our customers want European consolidation."

After an hour-long meeting of its 13-strong board, the London exchange agreed to postpone a vote on the iX deal, which was scheduled for September 14.

There was intense speculation that the Deutsche Börse would make a "white knight" offer to be considered alongside the Swedish proposal. OM offered 700p in cash and 0.65 of its shares for each London Stock Exchange share.

The Swedish group specialises in selling systems to exchanges around the world. Per Larsson, president of OM, said: "We believe it's a perfect marriage. OM Gruppen is a leading technology company. Technology is the prime driver behind the reshaping in equity markets."

OM's vice-president, Magnus Karlsson Böcker, admitted that a takeover of the stock exchange would stun traditionalists. But he said: "We're trying to save the crown jewels - we're trying to create something. What's proposed at the moment is to give away the future Microsoft of the UK to the Germans."

As share dealing becomes more international, the Swedish group believes that the exchange with the best technology will end up on top. The management of the London Stock Exchange disagrees - a senior source remarked yesterday that technology required to operate an exchange was "not state of the art, not difficult stuff".

The source said the crucial factor was offering the lowest transaction costs, which would enable the exchange to attract more customers and provide the most price liquidity.

There was a mixed response from the exchange's shareholders. Guinness Peat, the active investment group which has a 1% stake, said OM's offer had "negligible financial appeal", claiming that the shares were worth more than £30 if the London exchange was valued at the same rate as the Australian and Hong Kong exchanges.

Edmond Warner, chief executive of Old Mutual Securities, one of the exchange's largest shareholders, was more positive. Mr Warner, who is also a Guardian columnist, said: "I think it's extremely helpful that the situation has developed into a competitive one. If I was Don Cruickshank, I would consider my response to this very carefully and I would not dismiss this offer out of hand."

Some stockbrokers said the prospect of taking OM's shares was unattractive, as they were valued on a sky-high technology rating and were due for a fall. Brian Winterflood, the widely respected boss of Winterflood Securities, said: "This price is just OM's opening shot. At least it gives us breathing space with the Deutsche Börse deal."

He said it would be "upsetting" for many in the City if the stock exchange was taken over. But he added: "It's not like taking over the British Museum. This is a commercial business."

Bid Points

Founded in 1985, OM Gruppen owns the Stockholm stock exchange and provides transaction technology to banks, brokers and stockmarkets in more than 20 countries.

The company has a market capitalisation of £2.6bn. Its main proposals, outlined in briefings held yesterday in the City of London, are:

Introduce its own Unix-based trading system in place of the London Stock Exchange's existing technology.

OM's systems can handle 5,000 transactions and 20,000 price changes per second .

Offer shares and derivatives on a single trading platform, by exploring opportunities to collaborate with Liffe , the futures and options exchange.

Make annual cost savings of more than £30m within four years, largely from improved computer systems.

Establish low-cost technical access points, or "hubs", in leading cities throughout Europe.

Distribute prices, reference materials and clearing reports by making use of the internet .

Appoint non-executive directors to represent the interests of the London exchange's participants.

Allow the London exchange to remain as a stand-alone operation , regulated by the financial services authority.

webTitle: Reviews: Queens of the Stone Age

fields.headline: Retro bores kill the hype
fields.standfirst:
Queens of the Stone Age
***
Garage, London
fields.trailText:
Queens of the Stone Age
***
Garage, London
fields.body:
Heavy metal fashion may finally be broadening to include the Devil's own music: as if by a strange black leather osmosis, those who have sported distressed threads all year are finally, tentatively, exploring the sounds that spawned the look. And - if recent press is anything to go by - in Queens of the Stone Age they may have their token band. Thus, the crowd at the Garage is a mixture of ironically attired recent converts, and unreconstructed rock warriors.

The hype behind the Queens has certainly been impressive. With pasts in scumbag punks Dwarves and stoner rock legends Kyuss (think Black Sabbath plus largactyl), they have impeccable underground credentials. Reviews of Rated R, their debut album, have portrayed it as a rock milestone as epochal as Guns 'n' Roses' monolithic debut, or Nirvana's Nevermind. With customary understatement, NME ranked them "the best American band living today".

Tonight's headline show does not bear this out. At their best - on two-minute caustic rushes like Cocaine - they are a superb synthesis of the stop-start amphetamine thump of Big Black and the distorted boogie of ZZ Top. Twin frontmen Nick Oliveri (Ramses beard, sporadically clothed, screams) and Josh Homme (pale, porky, screeching guitar) have perfectly captured the dynamics of noise that can make a three-piece powerful. However, like all great guitar bands, they let their lack of imagination run riot. Whether playing A Song About My Mother or A Song for All the Pretty Girls, they follow the same pattern every time, falling uncomfortably between the grinding noise of their past and the narcotic pop of their future.

Ultimately, they lack the ferocity of early Guns 'n' Roses or the invention of, say, Shellac and when they twice lapse into stodgy instrumental workouts, the pace flags badly. Although the closing track, new single The Lost Art of Keeping a Secret, lifts spirits, the crowd are left a little underwhelmed. Guitar music has yet to win the groundbreaking imperative back from Dance music, and the Queens are not the band to do it, no matter how desperately we want them to be.

webTitle: Bias against women won't just go away

fields.headline: Bias against women won't just go away
fields.standfirst:
The way we work: Richard Reeves

Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: The way we work: Richard Reeves
fields.body:
Was it something I said? Last week I published a paper arguing that women lose out at work because they shoulder a disproportionate share of childcare responsibility, and that employers, knowing this, rationally discriminate against them. I therefore proposed that men be offered paternity leave which matches (in time and money) current maternity provision. Women and men would then compete on a level playing field.

The Institute of Directors said the plans would be "devastating" to business; the Telegraph argued that men weren't interested anyway; this newspaper described the scheme as "close to utopian" and "a waste of legislative effort"; the TUC said it amounted to an "attack on a better deal for working mothers"; the Cabinet Office said the report was "nonsense". Most damning of all, the Department of Trade and Industry said it was a "valuable contribution to the debate". Ouch.

Right-wing criticisms are easily dealt with. Yes, there would be some impact on business - although not a large financial one, as I suggest the paternity leave payments be reclaimed from the exchequer, as maternity payments are. The truth is that the shortest-sighted and loudest end of the business lobby have opposed every move to increase time off for workers on the grounds that it would destroy businesses. They are always wrong. They said it about the five-day week, the eight-hour day, paid holidays, extended maternity rights and parental leave.

The other argument made from the right, but also by some feminists, is that a man's place is not in the home because women are intrinsically better carers. Advocates of this view point out that it is widely held; I suppose they mean in the same way that popular opinion was once against female emancipation. The idea that men just aren't built to care for children belongs in the dustbin of history.

The attacks from the left are trickier. Nobody in government, or the trade unions is prepared to say publicly that so long as women take more time off than men, employers have rational grounds for discrimination. Plenty of them agree in private, needless to say, but think admitting it openly would encourage employers in this behaviour. "I agree with you," said one trade union official. "But you can't say it - it plays into the hands of the right." This is an absurd situation. Everyone knows it is happening, but progressives close their eyes to it.

The Cabinet Office said it was nonsense to suggest that employers discriminate against women because of their role as mothers. What employers are the Cabinet Office talking to? Has anybody put a lie detector on them? We have to face up to the real impact of the gendered division of labour in our society, and then do something about it. The bias against women won't just go away, no matter how hard we huff and puff.

The TUC description of my ideas as an attack on a better deal for working mothers was odd to say the least, especially from John Monks, an intelligent, forward-looking man. How does this square with my proposal for a doubling in the amount of time off available to parents, at a cost of around £1bn a year? Helping working fathers is the best way to help working mothers - by reducing their share of the domestic workload. The TUC is an exemplary employer in this area, offering male staff three weeks of paid paternity leave. I simply want fathers who are not fortunate enough to be TUC employees to enjoy the same (or greater) rights.

The best argument against my scheme is that men will not take up the offered leave, and that legislative and political energy should therefore go towards giving mothers more time off; because they'll actually use it for childcare rather than golf. The problem is that every time maternity leave is increased and time off for fathers stands still, the gap between mothers and fathers yawns even more widely. Unless we start equalising the treatment of fathers and mothers soon, the gap will be too wide to even contemplate it. And until we do, women will inevitably be at a disadvantage at work.

In any case, what's to be lost? If the government introduces more generous paternity leave and men shun it, no money or time will have been lost. Business will be as usual. And I will have to eat a large slice of humble pie. But I think I can glimpse a world where women and men meet as equals in the workplace and act as equals in the home. Maybe it is utopian. I can live with that.

Richard Reeves is director of futures at the Industrial Society. You can contact him at rreeves@indsoc.co.uk.

fields.headline: Injuries curse Keegan
fields.trailText: Fair stands the wind for France, although Kevin Keegan's normally breezy mood became a mite blustery yesterday as he began preparations for Saturday's friendly against the world and European champions in Paris with injuries gnawing at his squad and the critics more querulous than ever after England's doleful showing in Euro 2000.
fields.body:
Fair stands the wind for France, although Kevin Keegan's normally breezy mood became a mite blustery yesterday as he began preparations for Saturday's friendly against the world and European champions in Paris with injuries gnawing at his squad and the critics more querulous than ever after England's doleful showing in Euro 2000.

The England coach called Alan Smith, the 19-year-old Leeds forward, into the squad after losing four players - Rio Ferdinand, Gary Neville, Emile Heskey and Steven Gerrard - through injury, while Steve McManaman has flu and Andy Cole and Kevin Phillips did not train yesterday; Cole has a sore achilles tendon but should be available, Phillips is more doubtful with a shoulder problem. Only Michael Owen of the original strikers is fully fit but Smith will come seriously into consideration for selection only if Cole and Phillips drop out.

His presence in the squad is a further sign of a new generation of players making a case for forming part of England's plans for the next World Cup. Yesterday the Leeds manager David O'Leary admitted that last season the youngster's natural aggression had started to get the better of him. Worried that Smith was becoming "a bit of a thug" on the field, O'Leary made a special effort to sort the striker out and on the evidence so far he has been successful.

Certainly Keegan has been impressed. "He's very exciting but in a different way to Michael Owen," the England coach said yesterday. "I think that, like Owen, he's found scoring not too difficult at the start of the season, which is always great for strikers because they need goals. That's what they live off."

The likelihood is that Keegan will pair Owen and Cole up front in the Stade de France on Saturday night as he seeks a new scoring combination after Alan Shearer's retirement from international football. This is the only match the England coach will have in which to assess his side between the premature exit from Euro 2000 and the World Cup qualifiers against Germany and Finland on October 7 and 11.

In terms of team development the biggest disappointment for Keegan yesterday was the recurring groin problem that has forced Gerrard out of the France game and probably the first two World Cup games. The 20-year-old Liverpool player's performance as a substitute against Germany in Charleroi promised to solve England's inability to combine power with imagination in midfield, but the injury that sidelined him against Romania now threatens to leave his international career on hold.

"There is a problem that Liverpool are well aware of," Keegan explained, "and I just hope they sort it out for the lad. He's a tremendous talent. Sometimes the injury will be his groin, sometimes a hamstring, which suggests that the real trouble is in his back." The feeling in Liverpool is that the problem is with the groin, and the likelihood is that he will undergo an operation in the next couple of weeks.

Keegan wanted Gerrard to play for a full 90 minutes against France, when a good performance would have eased some of England's anxieties for the games against the Germans and the Finns. Now the best the England coach can hope for is that his midfield can keep the ball long enough to tell him something about the international form of, say, Darren Anderton or Nick Barmby, which will in turn give the strikers a better opportunity to shine.

Keegan is thinking of using Anderton wide on the right and moving David Beckham inside, where he would have a better chance of exploiting Owen's speed with accurate passes. "The thing you need with David Beckham, certainly if he plays central, is an option to find people with the sort of ball he gave Ryan Giggs at West Ham on Saturday when Andy Cole scored Manchester United's second goal," he said.

England's early progress towards the 2002 World Cup will depend on Beckham and Paul Scholes staying fit and in form along with the new captain Tony Adams, Sol Campbell rediscovering the international qualities he developed under Glenn Hoddle, and the 36-year-old David Seaman quelling growing doubts about his goalkeeping.

As for Keegan, well Johnny Giles, the former Manchester United, Leeds and Republic of Ireland player, has rightly pointed out in his newspaper column that the cheerleading that preceded Euro 2000 can hardly be recycled. Giles thinks the England coach should have resigned by now but yesterday, although Keegan gave his press conference in a hotel in the Chiltern Hundreds, he was clearly not thinking of applying for them.

"The opinions of ex-players and people who've played and managed at the highest level, if it is damning, hurts more than criticism from people who are outsiders looking in," Keegan conceded. "For me success is winning something. It always has been. "I don't necessarily want to be a hero but I don't want to be - what was the word somebody used? - a suspect. I don't think players are suspects. Only criminals are suspects."

A bad performance against France, however, and the media will put out an APB on Keegan, be sure of that.

fields.headline: Round-up
fields.trailText: The bad blood lingering from last season's tempestuous Worthington Cup semi-final was evident in the decision by the Bolton manager Sam Allardyce to boycott the changing rooms at Prenton Park for the First Division clash with Tranmere .
fields.body:
The bad blood lingering from last season's tempestuous Worthington Cup semi-final was evident in the decision by the Bolton manager Sam Allardyce to boycott the changing rooms at Prenton Park for the First Division clash with Tranmere .

He had been unhappy with Tranmere's alleged gamesmanship during the cup tie, won 4-0 on aggregate by the Wirral club, which included providing ball boys with towels to wipe the ball for their long-throw expert Dave Challinor.

Allardyce ordered his players to change into their kit at the Reebok stadium and his unusual approach paid off as Bolton won courtesy of a goal from their captain Mike Whitlow which was celebrated with gusto by players and supporters alike.

When the Tranmere defender Gareth Roberts was sent off for a crude foul on Bolton's Bo Hansen late in the game, tempers flared on both sides.

Tranmere's manager John Aldridge said: "I hope the referee will look at the red card and amend it, but we didn't get what we deserved today. Bolton only had one shot on target and they scored."

Allardyce said: "I'm saying nowt," and along with his players, still wearing their dirty kit, he immediately drove off in the team bus back to Bolton.

Watford 's hopes of bouncing straight back to the Premiership were boosted by yesterday's emphatic 4-1 victory over Sheffield United at Vicarage Road. Graham Taylor's team made light of the absence of Nordin Wooter and the new signing Allan Nielsen, with Heidar Helguson establishing an early lead which Tommy Mooney restored just before half-time after Wayne Quinn's equaliser. Gifton Noel-Williams and Micah Hyde completed the scoring but it could have been more as Watford missed several good chances.

"I had three players who I did not think would last 90 minutes," said Taylor. "All three scored and that certainly helps because they lasted well in the end.

"The funny thing is that after we'd gone 3-1 ahead United had their best spell and we had our worst. Had United scored then we might have been hanging on. I did not relax until the fourth one went in."

West Bromwich Albion responded to a verbal volley from their manager Gary Megson to register their first points. "I decided to give them a real telling-off because I was so angry about the start we had made to our season," he said. "They took the words I threw at them and rammed them down my throat."

Goals from Lee Hughes and Jason van Blerk ended the unbeaten run of QPR, who had gone ahead through Chris Kiwomya.

Bristol Rovers may have lost their sharpshooters Jason Roberts and Jamie Cureton but they still hit Brentford for six.

The Latvian midfielder Vitalijs Astafjevs opened the scoring at Griffin Park after five minutes and Nathan Ellington and Lewis Hogg both scored twice before the defender Scott Jones, on loan from Barnsley, scored the sixth. Paul Evans, from the penalty spot, and Andy Scott were on the mark for the well-beaten Bees.

Bury are up to an unexpected second place after Darren Bullock scored the only goal of the game against Northampton in the 72nd minute at Gigg Lane.

The newcomers Kidderminster moved into the top three of the Third Division with an impressive 2-0 win at Brighton thanks to goals from Ian Foster and Dean Bennett.

Rushden and Diamonds continued their commanding start at the top of the Football Conference with a 4-0 win at home to Southport.

webTitle: Leeds to take Riise out of Monaco

fields.headline: Leeds to take Riise out of Monaco
fields.trailText: Leeds United confidently expect to complete the protracted signing of John Arne Riise from Monaco before the Champions League transfer deadline on Thursday.
fields.body:
Leeds United confidently expect to complete the protracted signing of John Arne Riise from Monaco before the Champions League transfer deadline on Thursday.

The Leeds chairman Peter Ridsdale was in Monaco last night and hopes to tie up a £4.5m deal for the 19-year-old midfielder in the next 48 hours. The French club had been holding out for £6m after rejecting a £4m Leeds bid in June, but a compromise has been reached.

"It would take something special for me to leave Monaco but Leeds are such a club," Riise said yesterday. "I was disappointed when Monaco increased their valuation for me but now I am just excited about the possibility of joining Leeds."

The row between Liverpool and Middlesbrough over the transfer of German international Christian Ziege took a new twist when Boro refused to release the player's registration papers even though he signed a contract with the Anfield club over the weekend.

Liverpool are desperate to complete the paperwork on the transfer before Friday's deadline to register players for the Uefa Cup. But Middlesbrough are unhappy at the way Liverpool went about the capture of the 28-year-old, who cost £4m from Milan at the start of last season.

The Everton captain Richard Gough will learn today whether his career is to be ended by injury. The 38-year-old former Scotland captain is likely to announce his retirement if the knee injury he sustained during Saturday's match with Derby County is diagnosed as cruciate ligament damage. That would necessitate surgery and with Gough scheduled to retire next summer he would be reluctant to undertake a gruelling rehabilitation programme simply to return for the final few matches of the season.

Even if he does not require surgery he will be out for between four and six weeks, which will certainly force Everton's manager Walter Smith into the transfer market. Smith may try to recruit Colin Hendry from Coventry or Soren Colding, Brondby's £2m-rated Danish international.

Barcelona's Ronald de Boer has been contacted by the Manchester United manager Sir Alex Ferguson in an attempt to bring the unsettled midfielder to Old Trafford. "I received a call from United last week, from Alex Ferguson," said De Boer, who made three appearances as substitute for Holland during Euro 2000.

Rangers' Barry Ferguson was involved in a street brawl after his team's defeat by Celtic. A Strathclyde police spokeswoman said the 22-year-old midfielder, sent off during the Old Firm derby, suffered an eye injury in the fracas on Sunday night but did not require hospital treatment.

webTitle: Palace Fan makes Beasant see red

fields.headline: Palace Fan makes Beasant see red
fields.trailText: If this is what happens every time David Platt starts a game, his appearances should come with a health warning.
fields.body:
If this is what happens every time David Platt starts a game, his appearances should come with a health warning.

A remarkable afternoon saw Platt score, Nottingham Forest take a 3-0 lead and somehow hold out in a final minute which featured a red card, a brawl and a substitute goalkeeper saving a retaken penalty with his first touch in league football.

Both clubs can expect a call from the Football Association this week after the melee. And if all that had not provided enough drama, Forest's keeper Dave Beasant insisted his challenge on Fan Zhiyi, which brought his dismissal and the penalty, was neither inside the area nor even a foul. He accused Fan of diving and the referee has promised to look at the video.

The FA will doubtless be reaching for the rewind button a few times as it surveys the confrontation that followed Beasant's angry words at the prostrate Fan. The teams are likely to be charged with mis conduct and could be fined £50,000 each. Fan may also face separate disciplinary action after appearing to throw a punch at Tony Vaughan after the Forest defender lobbed the ball at him. The video could land others in the dock.

A circus had performed on the pitch here at half-time but no one had prepared for this. Forest already face a mandatory £5,000 fine under the new FA guidelines because six of their players were shown cards. Platt, whose first start for 10 months had been brought to an end by the time the trouble flared, played the incident down.

"I thought most of the players running in were doing so to calm it down," he said, though he will view the tape. His Crystal Palace counterpart Alan Smith was more critical of his players. "I'll be reminding the players it's completely unnecessary," he said. "It's something we have got to stop. It's up to managers to say to their team, 'Look lads, we are not having that'. Then the FA don't have to get involved."

Palace would have come away with a point had three of their players not become too involved as Julian Gray took his penalty once the mayhem had died down. Their en croachment into the area meant Gray, who had beaten Beasant's replacement Barry Roche, had to take the kick again. This time Roche guessed correctly and palmed the ball away.

There had been little hint of such drama in a first half dominated by Forest, with Platt in inspirational form. After Andy Johnson headed in a Chris Bart-Williams free-kick, the 34-year-old Platt suggested he had never been away by scoring from eight yards, his first goal since December 1997.

Platt then sent a glorious long ball to Jack Lester, whose cross was turned by Hayden Mullins into his own net. But once the impressive Tommy Black had pulled a goal back for Palace just after half-time Forest began to wobble. Fan made it 3-2 with a header eight minutes from the end and forced Beasant into a fine stop before the real, unwanted action began. If the start of the season is anything to go by, the video panel may be suing for repetitive strain injuries before long.

fields.headline: Boa Morte keeps Fulham flying
fields.trailText: Fulham were made to struggle yesterday but they still made it four wins out of four. Just when it seemed that Norwich were to gain some reward for an afternoon of high endeavour and passionate commitment, Luis Boa Morte snatched all the points.
fields.body:
Fulham were made to struggle yesterday but they still made it four wins out of four. Just when it seemed that Norwich were to gain some reward for an afternoon of high endeavour and passionate commitment, Luis Boa Morte snatched all the points.

There is good reason this season for the long-suffering Norwich supporter to dread every twitch of the teleprinter. Two goals for Craig Bellamy in the space of four days, a pair for Chris Sutton in the Old Firm derby, Darren Eadie's first for Leicester: former Norwich players are finding it easy to hit the net whereas Carrow Road has still to witness a goal from those who are left behind. Three home games, three blanks.

Norwich's determination was signposted in the early seconds when Lee Marshall bundled Rufus Brevett on to the cinder track. When they awoke to John Collins's penchant for finding space and team-mates with equal efficiency, Norwich began to blossom and looked far better value than their position one off the foot of the table.

Iwan Roberts and Darel Russell went close with volleys that screwed just wide. Then when Maik Taylor and Chris Coleman went for the same ball, Gaetano Giallanza, who has the chance to impress after Bellamy's departure to Coventry, could not take advantage of the confusion.

The second half yielded more from Jean Tigana's side and Louis Saha, through with only Andy Marshall to beat, ought to have done better than strike the outside of a post.

Barry Hayles could not find the target when aiming from a similar position to that which saw Chris Llewellyn waste a splendid opportunity for Norwich in the first half. It crossed the minds of a few thousand Canary followers then that Bellamy would have located the net from there.

Still, it looked as though Norwich had at least restricted the First Division leaders to a single point until two minutes from the end when Boa Morte, on as a substitute, finished off a fine move initiated by Sean Davis with a large helping hand from Collins. The Portuguese forward, on loan from Southampton, made a devastating run into space and, when well found by Davis, he coolly side-footed the ball into the corner of Marshall's net.

"Tigana has just said that it was the hardest game they have had this season, but you don't always get what you deserve," said the Norwich manager Bryan Hamilton. "We knew it was going to be a hard start to the season with the quality of the opposition we were up against but we have acquitted ourselves well and it's a shame to think we've only got one point from it."

The referee Mick Fletcher took nine names and had to separate the warring factions after Russell and Hayles clashed angrily. It appeared to be the game's most telling statistic, until Boa Morte struck.

"None of us really played well today and at half-time we said it was a case of digging in and sticking together as a team," Coleman said. "We would have settled for a point and were lucky to come away with the win."

webTitle: Preston owe it to big bad John

fields.headline: Preston owe it to big bad John
fields.trailText: John Hartson underlines the depth of Wimbledon's malaise. Once one of the top division's most threatening finishers, the striker is but a pale shadow of his former self.
fields.body:
John Hartson underlines the depth of Wimbledon's malaise. Once one of the top division's most threatening finishers, the striker is but a pale shadow of his former self.

The same can be said of his club. Wimbledon have not won on their travels for more than 12 months, not tasted victory since March 11, and are clearly finding the adjustment to post-Crazy Gang days difficult.

They had scored only two goals in seven games but in trying to end that run they could not have found more compliant opposition than Preston yesterday.

Home defenders absented themselves five times in as many first-half minutes to leave Hartson with the sort of time and space only dreamt of in the Premiership. But the Welshman, in his second match back after suspension and looking well over his fighting weight, was either too slow or too wayward in his finishing, only once drawing a perfunctory save from Teuvo Moilanen.

"When your top scorer gets in position to score and keeps missing you start to wonder," shrugged the Wimbledon manager Terry Burton. "John would say he should have scored five.

"We knew it was going to take him time to get back to fitness and if he keeps getting in there the goals will come."

It took Peter Hawkins's goalline clearance from Colin Murdock and a full-length Kelvin Davis save from Jon Macken to deny the home side. But after another Hartson miss the centre-half Mark Williams showed his more illustrious team-mate the way when he headed in a Neal Ardley corner in first-half injury-time.

Wimbledon hopes were not elevated for long. The second half was only seconds old when Michael Appleton collected a half-cleared corner 25 yards from goal and unleashed an unstoppable drive into the bottom corner.

There were chances at both ends in an open second half and Hartson, immediately after the Wales manager Mark Hughes departed, almost enjoyed the final word. He met an 82nd-minute cross from Marcus Gayle with an impressive header which careered to safety off the bar.

webTitle: Stringer helps to tie up Rovers

fields.headline: Stringer helps to tie up Rovers
fields.trailText: Judging by the vast expanses of empty seats here last night, life among the hoi polloi has still to catch the imagination of Sheffield Wednesday's supporters. But, as Bank Holiday entertainment went in the old steel city, this certainly beat queuing outside Meadowhall.
fields.body:
Judging by the vast expanses of empty seats here last night, life among the hoi polloi has still to catch the imagination of Sheffield Wednesday's supporters. But, as Bank Holiday entertainment went in the old steel city, this certainly beat queuing outside Meadowhall.

It started with a fan proposing to his girlfriend on the pitch and, by the end, those of Wednesday allegiance could probably harbour the first tempting thoughts that they might just be able to repair their broken relationship with English football's top-flight.

Nevertheless the whiff of pessimism that has enveloped Hillsborough for longer than the club would care to remember was hardly lifted by the fun and games surrounding their latest dabble in the transfer market.

News was relayed around the half-empty stadium that Wednesday had signed Paul Musselwhite as cover for Kevin Pressman, their regular goalkeeper being suspended after his sending-off against Wolves 13 seconds into their opening game of the season.

It was with more than a hint of embarrassment, therefore, when it transpired that the former Port Vale goalkeeper, released at the end of last season, had not been registered in time to play. Wednesday, after all, had had only 15 days to recruit someone.

As ever their indecision was final and that meant a first start for Chris Stringer, a 17-year-old on the first rungs of his career at a time when most of his friends were taking in their exam results.

If the teenager was afflicted by butterflies, however, his role was little more than that of spectator during a lung-bursting opening that saw Wednesday take the lead after little more than two minutes.

It was simple but effective. Matthew Hamshaw drifted a corner to the near post, Andy Booth flicked on and Ashley Westwood ghosted in at the far post to complete the oldest set-piece manoeuvre in the book.

So far so good for Wednesday. But Graeme Souness's Blackburn are made of sterner stuff than previous models. Back they came, with David Dunn and Nathan Blake forcing good saves from Stringer.

Finally, after a concerted spell of pressure, Blackburn equalised three minutes be fore half-time. A statuesque home defence failed to react to Damien Duff's cross and, a couple of ricochets later, the ball sat up nicely for the substitute Martin Taylor to score with a diagonal header.

For Blackburn that was the good news. The downside was that Taylor had been involved only because their centre-half Craig Short had been taken off on a stretcher two minutes earlier after a mid-air collision with Richard Cresswell.

On paper, at least, Blackburn still have the look of a fair to middling Premiership side. But, as their detractors never tire of reminding them, foot ball would be an odd pastime if it were played on paper.

So it was that Blackburn's defenders started making the type of gaffes that must be painfully familiar to those who have witnessed their decline from Premiership champions a mere five years ago.

One such mistake from Tay lor allowed Gerald Sibon the opportunity to restore Wednesday's lead only for Alan Kelly to spare his colleague's blushes with a low save to his left.

Sibon also had a scorching free-kick palmed away by Kelly but, as the game flowed from one end to the other, there was one common theme running through both teams: the lack of a cutting edge.

fields.headline: Francis answers enemies in style
fields.trailText: Trevor Francis said afterwards that reports of his imminent demise as Birmingham City's manager had been grossly exaggerated.
fields.body:
Trevor Francis said afterwards that reports of his imminent demise as Birmingham City's manager had been grossly exaggerated.

"It's a witch-hunt against me conducted by a person who won't be satisfied until he gets his wish," Francis said mysteriously, commenting on a Sunday newspaper report claiming that Steve Bruce was being lined up as his successor.

The mole or malcontent will be faced with some serious work to try to stand up the story now as City followed Saturday's win at Nottingham Forest, their first at the City Ground for 38 years, with this demolition of Dave Bassett's team, last season's play-off finalists.

The convincing scoreline almost made up for City's 4-0 defeat in the play-off semi- final first leg against the same opposition, at the same venue and only last May. More importantly, it was achieved in fine style.

Gone was the leaden-footed humping of the ball forward that was beginning to characterise Francis's team. Instead, with the close-season signing Danny Sonner calling the tune in midfield, they passed the ball to good effect.

The change in style is deliberate, according to Francis, who added: "I made a conscious decision during the summer for us to try and play more football.

"While I don't want us to abandon our strength, which is working hard for one another, I want us to pass the ball more and play with style.

"It worked at Forest on Saturday and again today. It was the best performance from any of my teams in the four years I have been here, and I enjoyed watching it."

So too did most of those at the ground as City managed to put the result beyond doubt only six minutes into the second half.

Peter Ndlovu had begun the process in the ninth minute when, after collecting Sonner's through-pass, he fired left-footed past Kevin Miller. Their second, in the 35th minute, was also a left-foot shot, Martin Grainger thumping home from the penalty spot after Mitch Ward handled.

The third was less clear-cut, though, David Holdsworth doing the necessary after a scramble from a short corner.

Thereafter City, much to the delight of the home crowd, played keep-ball. "It's just like watching Brazil," they sang, unashamedly stealing the Barnsley fans' own anthem.

Matt Appleby, Barnsley's substitute, then showed his prowess with a close-range volley in the 71st minute. It was their first shot on target but the insurrection was brief, Bryan Hughes completing the drubbing in the final seconds.

"We got what we deserved," said Barnsley's manager Dave Bassett. "We were never at the races." At least most of his men went the distance, although Chris Morgan was sent off for collecting his second booking four minutes from time.

webTitle: Claridge hat-trick proves a point or three

fields.headline: Claridge hat-trick proves a point or three
fields.trailText: Steve Claridge took revenge on the club that discarded him after five months when he scored a hat-trick in little more than half an hour yesterday.
fields.body:
Steve Claridge took revenge on the club that discarded him after five months when he scored a hat-trick in little more than half an hour yesterday.

The striker, now 34, spent an unhappy spell at Molineux two years ago in which he failed to score and was pilloried by the fans. Clearly he had not forgotten.

He tore into Wolves with venom, securing Portsmouth their first league victory of the season, and might easily have scored more against a hesitant defence in which Manuel Thetis, on loan from Ipswich, was making his debut.

Afterwards Claridge admitted: "My time at Wolves was not the best. I was disappointed I didn't have the opportunity to show them what I could do. Sometimes I do feel I have a point to prove and maybe now they realise I could have done a job for them. Perhaps it was a case of being the wrong man at the wrong time."

He opened his account in 90 seconds as he capitalised on slipshod Wolves defending. Kevin Harper played a short corner to Nigel Quashie, who produced a curling cross which allowed Claridge a free header which he dispatched from 10 yards.

Wolves, unbeaten in their opening three games, looked out of sorts but pulled a goal back on the stroke of half-time. Darren Bazeley helped on a clearance from Oakes and Temuri Ketsbaia, a £900,000 signing from Newcastle, unleashed a low shot from the edge of the penalty area which gave Russell Hoult no chance.

Claridge continued to torment the defence and nearly added a fourth when, with the outside of his foot, he swerved the ball in from a tight angle only to see it bounce back off the bar with Oakes helpless.

fields.headline: Salisbury recalled at Schofield's expense
fields.trailText: England's immediate faith in the leg-spin of Chris Schofield, so apparent when he was awarded a central contract and a Test debut in the spring, diminished to such an extent yesterday that the oft- rejected figure of Ian Salisbury has been recalled for this autumn's three-Test series in Pakistan.
fields.body:
England's immediate faith in the leg-spin of Chris Schofield, so apparent when he was awarded a central contract and a Test debut in the spring, diminished to such an extent yesterday that the oft- rejected figure of Ian Salisbury has been recalled for this autumn's three-Test series in Pakistan.

England will insist that Schofield's central contract remains a valid recognition of his long-term potential. At 21, that much has not changed. Nevertheless a return to Salisbury, nine years Schofield's senior, would not have been envisaged at the start of the season when his international career was generally deemed to be over. Salisbury, who seemed to have been supplanted as England's most convincing leg-spinner, has with typically sunny disposition formed a partnership with Pakistan's off-spinner Saqlain Mushtaq that has been instrumental in taking Surrey to the verge of a second successive championship.

Salisbury has been entrusted with nearly as many championship overs as Saqlain, taking 40 wickets at 19.47 (Saqlain's 57 have cost 14). Schofield, by contrast, has barely bowled half the overs granted to Lancashire's slow left-armer Gary Keedy and has managed only 23 wickets at 32.30.

Such are the doubts, however, that Salisbury's leg-spin will ever possess the robust ness required at Test level that an even wiser decision would have been to ignore both leg-spinners and call up Phil Tufnell alongside his fellow left-arm spinner Ashley Giles.

"I feel sorry for the guy," said Salisbury of Schofield. "Chris has huge ability and huge talent and I think there is a lack of understanding about leg-spin in this country."

Tufnell suffered primarily because an otherwise decent season does not disguise his failure to take many second-innings wickets, when the onus is on spinners to win matches. Fearing that the days of a specialist spinner, batting at No11 and fielding unpredictably, are fast disappearing, he has been contemplating retirement, albeit vaguely.

David Graveney, England's chairman of selectors, said: "We have opted for Salisbury and Giles because they are multi-dimensional cricketers who can contribute with the bat and in the field as well as with the ball. Both have enjoyed excellent seasons and been particularly effective in the second innings when the pressure is often on slow bowlers to bowl teams out."

Pragmatism colours England's entire 16-strong squad. Kent's wicketkeeper Paul Nixon is the only uncapped player in the party, but he is substantially more battle-hardened than the alternative candidate, Nottinghamshire's youthful Chris Read.

Andrew Flintoff, Matthew Hoggard plus the 12 on duty at the Oval complete the party, although Flintoff will give way to Surrey's Alex Tudor if his bowling fitness is not confirmed in the ICC Knockout Trophy in Kenya in October. The subsequent new year programme in Sri Lanka, involving three Tests and three one-day internationals, may bring an adjustment or two, probably beginning with an additional spinner.

England's one-day 14 for Kenya comprise the 11 who featured in this summer's NatWest Series final win against Zimbabwe, with the addition of Giles, Mark Alleyne and Nick Knight, who is expected to recover from keyhole surgery this week on a knee injury. The one-day squad depart on September 28, with the rest of the Test party scheduled to join them on October 24.

Yorkshire have lost their campaign for Darren Gough to be released for the climax to the championship season. The England and Wales Cricket Board has reasserted that all seven contracted players in the Test and one-day squads will be rested from county cricket from September 5.

The ECB is also considering an imaginative invitation from the West Indies Cricket Board for an England A side to enter the Busta Cup inter-island competition, starting in January, a novel suggestion which should be enthusiastically accepted.

"We did consider Schofield and Read for the senior tours," Graveney said, "but if the Busta Cup proposal goes ahead this will provide a superb opportunity for our leading young cricketers to test themselves against high-class Caribbean opposition."
