fields.headline: Stage set for Stewart clone
fields.standfirst: Paul Nixon is a fitness fanatic who can handle a bat. Sound familiar?
fields.trailText: Paul Nixon is a fitness fanatic who can handle a bat. Sound familiar?
fields.body:
There was a time when wicketkeepers were meant to be modest flunkies, Sancho Panzas for cricket's many Don Quixotes. They were meant to be like England's great Herbert Strudwick and Australia's Bert Oldfield who, after recovering consciousness after a blow on the head from Harold Larwood during the bodyline series, said: "Sorry, it was my fault."

Today, though, wicketkeepers - rather like television chefs and game-show hosts - are expected to be colourful and potty. Paul Nixon, the only uncapped player named for this winter's Test tours to Pakistan and Sri Lanka, certainly qualifies, according to his Kent team-mates.

They called him "Badger" when he arrived at Canterbury from Leicestershire this year because he had cut his hair to near-baldness. That changed to "Mad Badger" before the season had started, because of his habit of going to the gym three times a day and popping vitamin pills at every opportunity.

If you thought Alan Knott and Jack Russell were a little, well, eccentric, think again. During the course of a match Nixon has been known to run up and down the empty terraces to keep himself in trim. He has also on occasions worn a gumshield, as well as a protective grill, when keeping.

His selection could be viewed as a classic case of style over substance, for he has played only one major innings this season - his century last week that won Kent's game against Hampshire - and his keeping has been ordinary.

His influence, however, has been more profound than his individual contribution. Kent's fielding has been sharper this season and, under Nixon's guidance, they have introduced the Leicestershire-style huddle on the field. He is hyper, inspirational and hugely popular.

Nixon was told of his inclusion by the chairman of selectors David Graveney yesterday morning, and could not have made a better start to his preparations for the winter ahead; he kept wicket to Shane Warne and Saqlain Mushtaq while playing for a Paul Getty XI against West Indies. "Keeping to Min Patel this season has really helped my game," he said afterwards.

"When I was at Leicester we never had a real quality spin bowler. The Kent move has been brilliant. It feels great to have people putting impetus into me instead of me putting it into other people, like it was at Leicester."

Nixon will be 30 in a few weeks, but there is not a fitter cricketer in the country. A few years ago Alec Stewart, whose own legendary fitness almost mocks the need for a deputy, nominated Nixon as his successor.

You can see why. They could be soldiers from the same barracks with their short hair, self-discipline and total commitment, both physical and mental. Despite their age they are, with their extreme fitness and dual abilities, very modern cricketers.

The Sussex coach Peter Moores, whose county attempted to sign Nixon last season, said yesterday: "Nico is a good keeper who has the character to improve, technically, once he gets the chance to play at a higher level. That's what happened to South Africa's Mark Boucher. The great thing about Paul is he's a fighter. These days you need skill, talent and some ticker as well. Nico's got this tenacity of character when the chips are down.

"Jack Russell is probably still the best keeper in the country, but his England days are over. Keith Piper is gloving beautifully again and Adrian Aymes, another solid character, would also have been a good pick.

"But Piper, Aymes and Nixon have all been around a while. This is a great time to be a good keeper aged 18 or 19 and I hear good reports about Mark Wallace at Glamorgan."

The Sussex coach Peter Moores, whose county attempted to sign Nixon last season, said yesterday: "Nico is a good keeper who has the character to improve, technically, once he gets the chance to play at a higher level. That's what happened to South Africa's Mark Boucher. The great thing about Paul is he's a fighter. These days you need skill, talent and some ticker as well. Nico's got this tenacity of character when the chips are down. "Jack Russell is probably still the best keeper in the country, but his England days are over. Keith Piper is gloving beautifully again and Adrian Aymes, another solid character, would also have been a good pick. "But Piper, Aymes and Nixon have all been around a while. This is a great time to be a good keeper aged 18 or 19 and I hear good reports about Mark Wallace at Glamorgan."

webTitle: Gibbs let off the hook with six-month ban

fields.headline: Gibbs let off the hook with six-month ban
fields.trailText: The South African batsman Herschelle Gibbs received the equivalent of a slap on the wrist yesterday when he was banned from international cricket until the end of the year for his involvement in match-fixing.
fields.body:
The South African batsman Herschelle Gibbs received the equivalent of a slap on the wrist yesterday when he was banned from international cricket until the end of the year for his involvement in match-fixing.

The leniency of the punishment is sure to bring South Africa's United Cricket Board fierce criticism for missing the chance to stamp on alleged corruption and send a powerful message that match-fixing will not be tolerated in the post-Cronje era.

Gibbs and the fast bowler Henry Williams, who each accepted a £10,000 bribe proposed by the then captain Hansie Cronje to underperform in a one-day match against India, were given retrospective six-month bans which will end on December 31.

As a result the 26-year-old Gibbs - an automatic pick who was ineligible for the recent three-Test series in Sri Lanka - will miss only four more Tests, against New Zealand and Sri Lanka, before being available for South Africa's Caribbean tour next March.

Gibbs was also fined £6,100 and Williams £1,000, but the pair were both cleared to play domestic cricket. A third player, Pieter Strydom, was acquitted of planning to bet on the controversial Centurion Park Test against England last winter.

The UCB managing director Ali Bacher was quick to jump into defensive mode yesterday: "The ultimate findings were unanimous by three top legal experts in South Africa. Who are we to dispute this?"

One of those legal experts, Michael Kuper, also defended the judgment, saying Gibbs and Williams did not carry through their promises, were not eventually paid and had fallen heavily under the wayward influence of Cronje.

"We felt the imposition of a life ban would go beyond what is fair and proper," said Kuper, a member of the UCB's three-man disciplinary panel. "We tried to strike a balance between the interests of cricket and of the players."

Gibbs had told the King Commission in June that he agreed to bat slowly and get out for less than 20 in a one-day game at Nagpur on March 19 because he wanted to give his divorced mother financial support. He instead smashed 74 runs from 53 balls and subsequently claimed he had changed his mind.

However, four days earlier in Faridabad - in a match which Indian police had already identified as dubious based on the evidence of taped phone conversations - Gibbs was dismissed for 19 from 29 balls, prompting speculation that he may have led the King Commission down the wrong path.

Gibbs's agent Dave Richardson, the former Test wicketkeeper, was disappointed yesterday about the ban: "I feel he has done his time."

But the opener himself was repentant. "I have come to appreciate fully my stupidity," he said in a prepared statement. "I have learned my lesson."

webTitle: Exit Trescothick as Sabres are rattled

fields.headline: Exit Trescothick as Sabres are rattled
fields.standfirst: Somerset Sabres 212-8 v Sussex Sharks
fields.trailText: Somerset Sabres 212-8 v Sussex Sharks
fields.body:
Both these sides were hoping to sparkle at Hove, as both have something to prove under lights. Somerset have only played one National League day/night match this season - a no-result - while Sussex, who have had a little more practice, have only managed one win in three.

It was an ideal scenario for the bank holiday crowd, who were also treated to a musical battle between Hove's tinny sound system and a band from Brighton College.

The umpires, Roy Palmer and Alan Whitehead, will not thank Sussex for their own musical accompaniment. They may wear orange-tinted sunglasses to cope with the floodlights, but to make them walk out to Robbie Williams' Let Me Entertain You is a bit much. Still, they looked very smart in their navy jumpers and red ties.

Somerset's batsmen did their best to entertain in running up 212 for eight off their 45 overs. It was Marcus Trescothick's last county outing this season - the Oval Test and central contracts mean he puts his feet up for a while - and he went out with bang, hitting the game's first ball for four. Next he tried to hit the equally baby-faced Robin Martin-Jenkins into the stratosphere and was caught by a tumbling Bastiaan Zuiderent.

The crowd then looked to Jamie Cox for some fireworks. He seems too dinky to be destructive, but whether removing a speck of stray dirt from the pitch or depositing the ball over the ropes he is immaculately exact and powerful. But neither he nor any of the other batsmen could really get going, though Keith Parsons and Rob Turner, with a six apiece, blasted well towards the end.

Matthew Hoggard celebrated his selection for England's touring party with a match-winning performance for Yorkshire Phoenix against Northamptonshire Steelbacks. The 23-year-old paceman snapped up five for 30.

Middlesex Crusaders handed arch-rivals Surrey Lions the Second Division championship after they beat Nottinghamshire Outlaws by 23 runs in a rain-affected match at Richmond.

fields.headline: Sky backs Freud for dot.coms
fields.trailText: BSkyB has resumed its dot.com stake strategy by acquiring 8% of the comedy portal Comedyred.com which is backed by a collection of high-profile entrepreneurs including PR man, Matthew Freud.
fields.body:
BSkyB has resumed its dot.com stake strategy by acquiring 8% of the comedy portal Comedyred.com which is backed by a collection of high-profile entrepreneurs including PR man, Matthew Freud.

The deal, which is tied to the development of the Sky One website (www.Sky.com/one) into a strong entertainment site, represents the first dot.com stake BSkyB has acquired since purchasing an 18% share in teen portal Mykindaplace.com earlier this year.

As part of the non-cash deal, Comedyred.com has been given prominent links from both Sky.com and Sky.com/one. And BSkyB is expected to shortly reveal a sponsorship deal with a Sky One comedy show.

Guy Hornsby, chief executive of Comedyred.com and former ceo of commercial radio group Faze FM, which operates Kiss 102 and Kiss 105, declined to confirm whether a sponsorship deal with a show is on the cards. However, he confirmed that a number of marketing and sponsorship deals are being discussed.

Sky One's autumn schedule includes two new flagship comedy shows: Harry Enfield's Brand Spanking New Show and Al Murray's Time Gentlemen Please. Excite has already signed a £300,000 sponsorship deal with the latter, and Letsbuyit.com is to sponsor the Harry Enfield show.

It is thought that an enhanced TV version of the site will eventually be built into the broadcast stream behind Sky One programming. This will allow viewers to email each other or buy merchandise while watching the programmes.

BSkyB recently increased its shareholding in Sky Digital interactive TV service Open from 32.5% to 80.1% to enable it to boost its interactive and enhanced TV output.

ComedyRed, which offers animated games, listings, news, reviews, a searchable jokes archive, chat events and special webcasts, is backed by restaurateur-turned-start-up incubator Luke Johnson, PR guru-turned-internet entrepreneur Matthew Freud and William Burdett-Coutts, former director of Edinburgh's Assembly Rooms. They clubbed together to provide seed funding for Comedyred.com, which is talking to venture capitalists about first-round funding.

BSkyB's stake in ComedyRed is the seventh it has taken in a dot.com since kicking off its investment strategy in November last year with a 5% stake in Toyzone.co.uk. Other investments include a £10m stake in LetsBuyIt.com, 14% of Streets Online, 5.4% of Sportal and 10% of Gameplay.

webTitle: Tax deals needed to take jobs to the people

fields.headline: Tax deals needed to take jobs to the people
fields.standfirst:
Labour is embarked on its road to the manifesto - and so is the Guardian. In a unique experiment in British journalism, Guardian specialists draw a sketch of what should form Labour's programme for a second term. Readers add their thoughts, and the material is given a "reality check" by former mandarin Sir Peter Kemp. His critiques appear on our website. Today we look at the economy.

Special report: road to the manifesto
fields.trailText: The economy has been growing for nigh on nine years. Unemployment is back to levels not seen for 20 years. Inflation is the lowest in the European Union. So, on the principle of "if it ain't broke, why fix it", Labour might be best advised to leave things on auto pilot.
fields.body:
The economy has been growing for nigh on nine years. Unemployment is back to levels not seen for 20 years. Inflation is the lowest in the European Union. So, on the principle of "if it ain't broke, why fix it", Labour might be best advised to leave things on auto pilot.

But there are reasons for proposing a more activist approach. First, despite the improvement in Britain's economic performance relative to its main rivals, serious problems remain. Second, governments like to be seen doing things.

The idea of Gordon Brown, of all people, sitting with his feet up at the treasury desk defies belief.

That said, the benign state of the economy means that Labour can concentrate on big strategic questions. The government should therefore decide on overall economic aims, identify barriers to achieving them, and devise the necessary policies.

The aims are simple. Labour should seek a higher growth rate, an improvement in the quality of public services, a more even distribution of income, a more cohesive society, and a sustainable economy. Standing in the way are entrenched pockets of deprivation, the systematic neglect of the public realm, a Byzantine tax and benefits system that discourages work and encourages cheating, a corporate elite that pays only lipservice to the notions of social responsibility, and a growth rate that has remained stubbornly at around 2%-2.5% since 1950.

So what should the government do? At the apex of Labour's programme should be a commitment to full employment. This does not mean abandoning control of inflation but recognising that low inflation is only a means to an end. The recent comprehensive spending review said the government was committed over the next decade to getting more people into employment than ever before.

Although this is admirable, it is not a testing target as the proportion of people employed is only one percentage point below its all-time high in 1974 of 75.7%.

The government needs to be much more ambitious if it is to have a chance of hitting its other objective of eliminating child poverty within 20 years. It should set a full employment target of 80% of the workforce in jobs.

Achieving this target will involve both demand and supply policies. The importance of demand - although obvious over the past 10 years - has too often been overlooked. There should be active demand-led policies in areas of particularly high unemployment - what some have called local Keynesianism.

This would involve using the enormous purchasing power of government to favour firms in rundown areas, cuts in both taxes and national insurance for employers, and public infrastructure projects to raise the demand for labour. Having unsuccessfully tried moving people to where the jobs are, Labour should try moving the jobs where the people are.

Next, Labour should turn the debate about public spending on its head, putting the emphasis on what is needed rather than what can be afforded. Public spending should not gyrate in response to the state of the economic cycle; if Labour believes that 10 years of 6% real increases in health and education spending are needed, it should commit itself to finding the money.

Gerald Holtham, the former head of the left-leaning think tank the Institute for Public Policy Research, came up with an elegant solution - a community fund. This would be a lump sum, equivalent to the combined annual spending on health and education, invested in equities which for the past 40 years have seen an annual yield of 6%.

The government has insisted that the £22.5bn received from the auctioning of mobile phone licences should be saved rather than spent: it would be better used as the downpayment on a community fund rather than paying off the interest on the national debt.

The rest of the fund could be provided either by skimming off the government's budget surpluses, increasing inheritance tax which has fallen drastically over the past 20 years, or by imposing a tax on land values.

Even full employment and targeted jobs programmes will not be sufficient to eradicate poverty. Half the children in poverty live in households where the parents might expect to find work but around 1.5m do not. For them, as for pensioners living in poverty, higher living standards means higher benefits.

All of which brings us to the unwieldy tax system, which needs to be streamlined and made more effective. One solution would be to take an axe to the number of goods and services that are either exempt from VAT or are zero rated. Making everything from food to books liable for VAT would raise close on £30bn a year, and in theory it would be possible to compensate those on lower incomes for the higher cost of essential goods.

In practice, that would prove an administrative nightmare, so Labour would be better off picking off the glaring VAT anomalies - the zero-rating of new dwellings (which costs £2.7bn) and international passenger transport (£1.7bn), and the exemption of rent on domestic dwellings (£2.7bn), rent on commercial dwellings (£1.6bn), private education (£900m), private health (£550m) and betting and gaming (£900m). Together these add up to £11bn in lost revenue, most of which amounts to a subsidy to the better off.

As for raising direct taxation, there is a strong case for abolishing the national insurance ceiling (which benefits those on more than £535 per week) and for raising the top rate of income tax to 50% for those earning more than £100,000. Such steps, however, would require some serious political spadework.

Moving the focus of the taxation system would make Britain a better place to live. Over the longer term, taxation should be shifted from labour and on to pollution. The target should be to switch 10% of the tax burden within five years. A US-style community re-investment act, which ensures that banks cannot up and leave communities without a financial penalty, should be introduced urgently.

Labour should push for an international agreement for a tax on financial speculation. Rather than stick to GDP per head as the yardstick of economic performance, Labour should introduce an index of sustainable economic welfare, which would measure poverty, crime and pollution as well as output.

And so, finally, to the euro. There are many good reasons for caution - the fact that Britain would suffer from a one-size-fits-all monetary policy, the ERM experience, the problems currently being faced by Ireland, the unaccountability of the European Central Bank and its obsession with inflation, and the lack of anything approaching real economic convergence.

Labour should also consider whether membership of the single currency is more important than its other goals. If Labour blunders into a referendum on the euro - and (as looks likely) loses it - the result will be an administration as broken as was John Major's after Black Wednesday. With William Hague and Michael Portillo waiting in the wings, it simply is not worth the risk.

Pledges:

1 Full employment target

2 Community re-investment act

3 No to the euro

4 Community Fund to guarantee higher spending on health and education

5 Index of sustainable economic welfare

fields.headline: Changing times
fields.standfirst: Practical training on courses is just as important as academic content, says Jeremy Hoad
fields.trailText: Practical training on courses is just as important as academic content, says Jeremy Hoad.
fields.body:
Postgrad courses have expanded rapidly as students strive to distinguish themselves more in the job market and institutions are responding by increasing the range of courses they offer.

In particular, they are offering more shorter courses, such as postgraduate diplomas and masters. These usually provide a vocational training for a specific area such as social work, law, teacher-training or arts administration, but may also be specifically academic.

Research courses such as the MPhil or PhD are also incorporating a much greater element of training. Doing postgraduate research now is a far more comprehensive experience than it was in the past. You are unlikely to be able to concentrate exclusively on your project for two or three years, as generic training in presentation techniques and analytical and writing skills are included in your course. They can also be a requirement of successful progress.

Training is also set to become much more focused on the individual with the development of student progress files. Part of this initiative is the personal development plan, which offers students an opportunity to identify their learning and training goals.

Taking control of your work is crucial if you are to be successful and enjoy your study. This can be harder on shorter taught courses, as they are likely to be more intensive and with a more specific programme than research courses.

But do not let yourself be driven by the course content alone. There may be aspects of training that are not covered by your course. If this is the case, consider how to expand your training in non-academic areas such as: computing and information technology; project management; presentation; report writing; interview skills; networking; job searching and CV writing.

For research students the agenda is changing as well. Research councils and other funding bodies are increasingly expecting training to be more comprehensive in both academic and personal development. Even if you are not funded by a research council, and the majority of students are not, universities have significantly increased their training provision for postgraduates in recent years. Although this has clear advantages, you must be careful to manage your time effectively to ensure you keep on track with your research. It would be counterproductive to spend so much time on training and personal development that your research suffers.

This increasing focus on training is shown by the expansion of courses such as the Research Council's graduate schools programme. This is a five-day course focusing on four areas: communication; improving your learning and performance; problem solving and working with others. It is free to all students funded by the research councils. For others it costs £450 (plus VAT) but you may be able to get your department to pay.

Student responses to the course have included: "It was the most constructive week of my PhD" and "An entirely new world of possibilities opened up to me". With these comments the quality and breadth of the training provided by universities themselves has to be called into question.

For an academic career, training for teaching is particularly important. For far too long universities have prioritised research over teaching despite the fact that teaching is a core function of higher education. Most postgraduates will do some teaching while they are studying. If you do, then it is the responsibility of the university to provide good training and support. Postgraduates' involvement in teaching will be adressed in more detail next week.

If you are starting a postgraduate course in the next few weeks you need to find out what training is provided by your university. This training may be directly related to your academic work, but do not overlook opportunities for personal development. If you are starting a shorter taught course, explore other training outside your course. If you are starting a research degree, do not limit yourself to thinking exclusively about training in relation to your project.

If you are beginning to think about postgraduate study for next year, focus on training provision when you are choosing your department and university. A good way of doing this is to find out what your current institution provides for its postgraduate students. Talk to some postgraduates and find out what they feel about their experience. How do they feel about the pressures of training while studying and how do they balance the two?

If you are going to undertake postgraduate study, think about your motivations, your training needs and your career intentions. Don't expect your course to provide all your training needs. Your postgrad experience is far more than the course you are on and training is not just for specific skills but also for your development as an individual. Find out where you want to go and get on track with your training.

For information on the Research Council's short courses, tel: 01223 460277 or email gsp@crac.org.uk Jeremy Hoad is general secretary of the National Postgraduate Committee.

Research courses such as the MPhil or PhD are also incorporating a much greater element of training. Doing postgraduate research now is a far more comprehensive experience than it was in the past. You are unlikely to be able to concentrate exclusively on your project for two or three years, as generic training in presentation techniques and analytical and writing skills are included in your course. They can also be a requirement of successful progress. Training is also set to become much more focused on the individual with the development of student progress files. Part of this initiative is the personal development plan, which offers students an opportunity to identify their learning and training goals. Taking control of your work is crucial if you are to be successful and enjoy your study. This can be harder on shorter taught courses, as they are likely to be more intensive and with a more specific programme than research courses. But do not let yourself be driven by the course content alone. There may be aspects of training that are not covered by your course. If this is the case, consider how to expand your training in non-academic areas such as: computing and information technology; project management; presentation; report writing; interview skills; networking; job searching and CV writing. For research students the agenda is changing as well. Research councils and other funding bodies are increasingly expecting training to be more comprehensive in both academic and personal development. Even if you are not funded by a research council, and the majority of students are not, universities have significantly increased their training provision for postgraduates in recent years. Although this has clear advantages, you must be careful to manage your time effectively to ensure you keep on track with your research. It would be counterproductive to spend so much time on training and personal development that your research suffers. This increasing focus on training is shown by the expansion of courses such as the Research Council's graduate schools programme. This is a five-day course focusing on four areas: communication; improving your learning and performance; problem solving and working with others. It is free to all students funded by the research councils. For others it costs £450 (plus VAT) but you may be able to get your department to pay. Student responses to the course have included: "It was the most constructive week of my PhD" and "An entirely new world of possibilities opened up to me". With these comments the quality and breadth of the training provided by universities themselves has to be called into question. For an academic career, training for teaching is particularly important. For far too long universities have prioritised research over teaching despite the fact that teaching is a core function of higher education. Most postgraduates will do some teaching while they are studying. If you do, then it is the responsibility of the university to provide good training and support. Postgraduates' involvement in teaching will be adressed in more detail next week. If you are starting a postgraduate course in the next few weeks you need to find out what training is provided by your university. This training may be directly related to your academic work, but do not overlook opportunities for personal development. If you are starting a shorter taught course, explore other training outside your course. If you are starting a research degree, do not limit yourself to thinking exclusively about training in relation to your project. If you are beginning to think about postgraduate study for next year, focus on training provision when you are choosing your department and university. A good way of doing this is to find out what your current institution provides for its postgraduate students. Talk to some postgraduates and find out what they feel about their experience. How do they feel about the pressures of training while studying and how do they balance the two? If you are going to undertake postgraduate study, think about your motivations, your training needs and your career intentions. Don't expect your course to provide all your training needs. Your postgrad experience is far more than the course you are on and training is not just for specific skills but also for your development as an individual. Find out where you want to go and get on track with your training. For information on the Research Council's short courses, tel: 01223 460277 or email gsp@crac.org.uk Jeremy Hoad is general secretary of the National Postgraduate Committee.

fields.headline: Cars, Calls and Column inches
fields.trailText: JUMPED UP
fields.body:
JUMPED UP

Liverpool players of the mid-to-late Nineties were renowned for the sense of discipline instilled in them by Roy Evans - wasn't it unjust how they ended up without any trophies to show for their efforts while those gadabouts down the East Lancs Road spawned their way to a load of medals? So it comes as something of a shock that two alumni of that spicy scouse side are facing police charges after a night of Loaded-style high jinx.

Phil Babb and Mark Kennedy were arrested this morning in Dublin after allegedly jumping around like a pair of ill-educated spoilt oafs on a parked car. Amusingly, they were reportedly collared in the city centre's Harcourt Square by the owner of said vehicle, a female police officer (who is presumably not on x thousand pounds per week and is aware of the value of money). The two eejits, who are in Ireland to "prepare" for the Republic's World Cup qualifier against Holland on Saturday, quickly found themselves up before the beak, who accused them of causing criminal damage, causing a breach of the peace and being drunk and disorderly.

They were then freed on bail - after payment on their own sureties of IR£950 each, procedure fans - which meant they could be about their business. Sadly, this business will not now include playing World Cup football, because despite apologising profusely in a press conference, they've been expelled from the Irish squad by manager Mick McCarthy. Do you think Big Mick might have lost his temper with them?

PRAISE BE!

This morning, Leeds chairman Peter Ridsdale was a very happy man. A very happy man indeed. Because not only were his team - inspired by Pastor O'Leary O'Leeds's heavenly 4-3-3 formation and the born-again Alan Smith - still unbeaten, but he had also managed, at long last, to persuade Norwegian teen firebrand John Arne Riise to say no to sunny Monaco, no to beaches and buxom blonde babes, and yes, yes, yes to the earthy pleasures of West Yorkshire!

Of course, the Fiver doesn't know exactly how Ridsdale did it - does anyone? - but last night a smitten Riise was cooing: "It would take something special for me to leave Monaco but Leeds are such a club." However, barely had the young buck packed his dog-eared copy of Wuthering Heights when a hard-nosed Monaco official called the deal off. Again. So it was left to a clearly disappointed Risdale to break the news: "John Arne Riise is not coming to Leeds," he admitted. "I spoke to the club yesterday and they reiterated he is not for sale at any price."

But before the whole of Elland Road could sink into a full-scale clinical depression, up popped a joyous Pastor, with a tambourine in one hand and a song-sheet for Kum-By-Ya in the other, to announce that the born-again Smith had been called up into the England squad for Saturday's friendly against France. "England have suffered a number of injuries to the forward department, so [Kelvin Koogan] has called him up to the squad," O'Leeds announced. "I'm absolutely delighted for him and I know he won't let [Koogan] down." Which is more than you can say about some members of Koog's current squad.

QUOTE OF THE DAY

"I still believe that we did underperform and the challenge for the players and myself is to perform to our ability. When we do we are a match for everybody." - Kelvin Koogan keeps believing. Well, somebody's got to.

I HEARD (AND THEN MADE UP) A RUMOUR

Over the bank holiday weekend, it was reported that Sol Campbell and Ronald de Boer would both be wearing Manchester United's unique new woollen woollysportsweater (©, TM, etc.) come the end of the week, just in time to make the registration deadline for Big Cup. Sadly for United fans, the Fiver must report that this does not appear to be the case.

According to the Star - and we have total faith in them - sources close to Campbell insist that there has been no contact with the Old Trafford club regarding a £9m move, despite claims in the Mirror to the contrary. And although the excellent De Boer had been quoted on onefootball.com as saying he had "received a call from United last week from Alex Ferguson", his own website today contradicted this report: "These rumours simply aren't true. This weekend I have spoken to both Barcelona's coach and president with a view to sorting out my present situation with the club."

Who can you trust? A disillusioned Fiver can't tell you - we don't know. Mind you, onefootball.com haven't done too badly in terms of free publicity - it's well worth getting it wrong if a major international footballer pooh-poohs your report in front of the world's media. Well, we're not adverse to a bit of a leg up either, so here goes. "Alex Caldwell, the manager of Elgin City, gave me a quick tinkle on the old dog and bone last week," an excited Zinedine Zidane told the Fiver over the phone about, er, five minutes ago. "I don't know what will happen yet, but I can tell you this for nothing - I'm well interested!" Now, when do we start counting our column inches?

THE RUMOUR MILL

Diego Maradona could be about to return to competitive football after provisionally signing for Argentine Second Division side All Boys. The club's vice-president told the newspaper Clarín: "If he receives the all-clear from the medics in Cuba, he could be playing for All Boys. So now he could end his career playing, which is his main dream."

Boudewijn Zenden has flown to Rome to undergo a medical prior to signing for Lazio - who look likely to sign the Dutch striker for £8m despite late interest from Fiorentina.

Rangers are closing in on 22-year-old Espanyol striker Raul Tamudo and hope to complete a £12m deal before the Big Cup deadline.

NEWS IN BRIEF

Former Middlesbrough defender Willie Maddren has died at the age of 49 after a brave battle against motor neurone disease. Maddren, who was diagnosed as suffering from MND in 1995, died peacefully in his sleep at Butterwick Hospice in Stockton earlier today. He leaves a wife, Hilary, and four children. The centre-back made more than 350 appearances for the club in a career spanning 10 years. He returned to Ayresome Park as manager between June 1984 and February 1986 after having his playing career cut short by a knee injury at just 26.

Jaap Stam and Marc Overmars have been ruled out of Holland's World Cup qualifier against Ireland on Saturday.

Leicester midfielder Muzzy Izzet will miss Turkey's game against Moldova on Saturday through injury.

Sheffield United are having discussions with Inverness Caledonian Thistle about a partnership arrangement which could see Bramall Lane players being farmed out to the Scottish First Division club.

Dunfermline have transfer-listed Andy Tod and Owen Coyle.

TONIGHT'S TV AND RADIO

ITV: Football Extra (12.35am)
And it's still never enough.

Sky Sports 1: You're On Sky Sports! (10pm, 2.30am)
McCaff presents, a shaven-headed Rodney Marsh guests. Both look ridiculous, although only one can cite extenuating circumstances.

Sky Sports 3: Inside Scottish Football (6.30pm, 11pm SS1, 1.30am SS1)
Note a distinct lack of bowler hats being thrown in the air in celebration.

British Eurosport: Football (7pm)
After hours of research, we've found out that this programme is about Big Cup. Don't say we don't try.

Radio 5 Live: 5 Live Football (7pm)
Alan Green moaning about the exact temperature of his tea, perhaps finding some time for a bit of football commentary.

webTitle: How the subject league tables were compiled

fields.headline: How the subject league tables were compiled
fields.byline:
Professor Linda Thomas, Pro Vice-Chancellor, and Rosa Scoble, Researcher to the Dean, Faculty of Science
Brunel University
fields.body:
The production of league tables implies the acceptance of the principle of ranking and therefore the concept of "better" and "worst". The results of ranking are very different depending on which of the many facets characterising the provision of ITT courses are selected and how these are treated. These tables focus on what are commonly perceived as the main objectives of ITT providers:

a) to attract trainee teachers with the best possible qualifications

b) to provide a high quality course of training and

c) to ensure that all trainee teachers enter the teaching profession.

The tables utilise the data gathered by the TTA and published in their annual report of performance Ð the Performance Profiles. The TTA profiles include, for each provider, background and performance indicators. The background indicators include studentsÕ statistics on gender, ethnic grouping and disabilities. The performance indicators show entry qualifications, Ofsted inspection grades and studentsÕ employment in teaching.

The TTA Profiles are organised by: provider and level (i.e. primary, key stage 2/3 and secondary). Performance indicators are also organised by subject with the exception of primary Ofsted inspection grades. These are given at primary level not primary subject. This type of data structure reflects the differences between primary and secondary levels and between subjects at secondary level. We have chosen to respect and preserve these distinctions partly to provide useful information for individuals who want to enter the teaching profession and also in recognition that the availability of students in some secondary level subjects, compared with other subjects, makes attempts to combine subjects misleading.

Entry grades and employment rates are subject to further discrimination by mode of study and are provided for undergraduate and postgraduate students. The same level of discrimination is not available for Ofsted inspection grades; these tables therefore make no distinction between modes of study. StudentsÕ entry and employment indicators are averaged across undergraduate and postgraduate provision. Key stage 2/3 courses are not included in these tables because the scale of provision is small. Subjects with less than 7 students are omitted since the small number of students would distort the results.

The Model

The description that follows shows how the data sets have been used and for what reason, thus giving the reader the means fully to understand the implications of the tables. In general, the method has been to compare an individual providerÕs selected performance indicators with the optimal outcomes for those indicators in order to produce percentage scores.

Undergraduate entry qualifications. The selected performance indicator is the average A level points score, since this reflects the average standard of applicants. This is then compared with the notional maximum score achievable of 30 (3 A-levels graded A).

Postgraduate entry qualifications. The performance indicator provided in the TTA data set is the percentage of students with entry degree qualifications of 2.1 or above. No further calculation is necessary since this is already expressed as a percentage of the maximum achievable of 100% of students with a 2.1 or above.

Undergraduate and postgraduate employment rates. The number of students in teaching posts is compared with the number of students eligible for award. This is based on the assumption that students who have not been awarded a degree and those who are not in a teaching post fail the providerÕs objective of full teaching employment. This needs no further transformation since it is already expressed as a percentage of the maximum achievable of 100% employment in teaching posts.

Note: Students with unknown destinations are redistributed using the subject average employment rate (calculate as the number of students in teaching posts over the number of students eligible for award).

Ofsted inspection grades. Grades are compared with the maximum grade achievable of 1 so that a grade of 1 = 100%, 2 = 66.7% and 3 = 33.3%. They are of two types: the first 3 relate to standards while the other 2 relate to design and delivery. The standards grades are commonly accepted as the most influential set of indicators, therefore they have a higher weighting (25% each) compared to the design and delivery ones (12.5% each).

Calculating the final score. To achieve a final score for each provider at the primary level and for individual subjects at secondary level, the indicators are weighted and aggregated. The Ofsted inspection grades are identified as the most important and are therefore weighted at 60% of the final grade while the entry grades and the employment rates are each weighted at 20%.

Conclusion

With these tables we hope to provide a comprehensive yet clear indication of the "best" providers by level and subject. The definition of "best" is linked to the particular context of this analysis and therefore not absolute, but while we do recognise the different needs that an ITT course can fulfil, we want to emphasise the overarching obligation to provide the best trained and qualified teachers. These tables can be seen as both a source of information for individuals that want to enter the teaching profession and for providers to assess their level of achievement.

webTitle: Campaign to scrap selective schools revives

fields.headline: Campaign to scrap selective schools revives
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: The campaign against grammar schools is to be relaunched this week, after the government bowed to presure to make it easier for parents to abolish the surviving 165 selective schools.
fields.body:
The campaign against grammar schools is to be relaunched this week, after the government bowed to presure to make it easier for parents to abolish the surviving 165 selective schools.

Campaigners in Kent, which has the largest number of grammar schools, 33, will on Friday reactivate the petitioning process they were forced to abandon this year. The government is to relax some of the technical regulations to make it easier for campaigners to collect the signatures they need to force a vote among parents.

But the education secretary, David Blunkett, is expected to face fierce criticism of Labour's policy on grammar schools at a fringe meeting at the party conference at the end of next month. It has been accused of "sitting on the fence" by letting parents decide the schools' fate.

Speakers on the highly sensitive issue will include Lord Hattersley, a former Labour deputy leader, who is still outraged over Mr Blunkett's claim this year that his "read my lips" comment about being opposed to selection was a joke.

The campaign in Kent was suspended at the end of March because of "political confusion" over the issue, the complexity of the rules governing petitions and ballots, and a tight deadline. Campaigners needed to get 46,000 signatures of eligible parents for a vote to take place but are understood to have secured fewer than 7,000.

Their decision came hard on the heels of a vote in Ripon, North Yorkshire, where a two-thirds majority voted to retain their grammar school - the oldest in England - in the first ballot under legislation introduced by Labour.

Ballots are triggered by support from 20% of eligible parents. In Ripon it took campaigners six months to obtain the 1,800 signatures needed.

In Kent the parents of all children at the 600 primary schools are eligible to vote. The Stop the 11-plus (Step) campaign will on Friday ask the Electoral Reform Society for a threshold figure for the number of signatures they need in 2000/2001.

A Step spokesman, Martin Frey, said it had been told not to reprint the old petition forms, suggesting that changes were likely. A spokesman for the Department for Education and Employment confirmed technical changes such as allowing space to include up to 10 names on a petition form, rather than only three.

He said Mr Blunkett, in a Commons debate in June, had recognised the need for some practical changes, but there would be no amendments to the ballot system as enshrined in primary legislation.

Mr Frey said: "We are hoping for some meaningful changes that will make our Herculean task a little easier. Anything less than this and there will be hell for Mr Blunkett at the party conference."

The selective structure in Kent was damaging standards, not raising them, he added. "As the GCSE results showed last week, there are some comprehensives that are doing magnificently well, despite having some of the best pupils creamed off to the grammars."

He pointed to little-known changes that meant the "loss" of around 500 places from Kent grammar schools next year.

In addition, the 11-plus test is being changed, with a pass/fail-on-the-day format being introduced and consultation due to take place to bring it forward from January to September, when nearly all children would be only 10.

A Step spokesman, Martin Frey, said it had been told not to reprint the old petition forms, suggesting that changes were likely. A spokesman for the Department for Education and Employment confirmed technical changes such as allowing space to include up to 10 names on a petition form, rather than only three. He said Mr Blunkett, in a Commons debate in June, had recognised the need for some practical changes, but there would be no amendments to the ballot system as enshrined in primary legislation. Mr Frey said: "We are hoping for some meaningful changes that will make our Herculean task a little easier. Anything less than this and there will be hell for Mr Blunkett at the party conference." The selective structure in Kent was damaging standards, not raising them, he added. "As the GCSE results showed last week, there are some comprehensives that are doing magnificently well, despite having some of the best pupils creamed off to the grammars." He pointed to little-known changes that meant the "loss" of around 500 places from Kent grammar schools next year. In addition, the 11-plus test is being changed, with a pass/fail-on-the-day format being introduced and consultation due to take place to bring it forward from January to September, when nearly all children would be only 10.

fields.headline: Endangered species
fields.standfirst: In the first of a four-week series on postgraduate issues, Lee Elliot Major explains why social sciences and humanities are losing academic talent because of financial pressures
fields.trailText: In the first of a four-week series on postgraduate issues, Lee Elliot Major explains why social sciences and humanities are losing academic talent because of financial pressures.
fields.body:
Academic bodies are to produce a list of endangered subjects in the social sciences and humanities, which are seeing young academic talent dry up as UK undergraduate students turn away from poorly funded masters and PhD courses at universities. Societies and subject associations are to highlight the problem specialisms as part of an investigation into the state of graduate studies launched by the British Academy earlier in the summer.

The academy says there is a growing body of anecdotal and statistical evidence indicating that postgraduate numbers are falling and that many of the best students are turning away from graduate studies. In some disciplines and institutions, what used to be a predominantly British cohort of students has been replaced by a predominantly overseas one.

The extent of the crisis in some subjects was revealed last year when a shock government-sponsored report concluded that UK student numbers enrolling for economics PhDs were down to almost zero. The report alarmed Treasury civil servants, who are facing problems recruiting economic advisers for the government. It also prompted calls for universities to be privatised and to be given more freedom to pay academics higher salaries.

Commissioned jointly by the Economic and Social Research Council, the Royal Economic Society and the Government Economic Service, the report confirmed the economics research community's worst fears: the supply of UK academic economists has almost dried up. Only about 10% of new PhD students enrolled in the UK's top research-rated economics departments in the last year were from the UK. Some academics estimate that there were fewer than 10 economics graduates with first-class honours applying to do PhDs in the last academic year.

Economics represents an extreme example of a problem now emerging in many disciplines: lucrative jobs are attracting students away from poorly funded studentships - particularly those already facing hefty debts after paying tuition fees and maintenance during their degrees.

The Economic and Social Research Council has also raised concerns over the dearth of graduates entering the social sciences with mathematical and quantitative training as well as more qualitative skills. A recent overhaul of the council's training support schemes, meanwhile, means that fewer masters courses will now receive funding.

The recruitment of students in the social sciences is a complex issue, with many courses still oversubscribed. The government's recent announcement of minimum PhD stipends for research students in the sciences will go some way to ameliorate the problem. But the extra grants only apply to a tiny percentage of the 400,000-strong postgraduate community in UK universities. And in the humanities, there is no extra money at all.

Despite covering a large range of academic communities, the recently established Arts and Humanities Research Board controls a much smaller budget than the six government research councils that support graduate students in the sciences. The board can only support a relatively small number of postgraduates in universities. There are now many thousands of students on masters and PhD courses without any government support.

The British Academy says the review will produce the first comprehensive picture of the graduate student recruitment trends in the social sciences and humanities - by gathering statistical data covering a 10-year period and consulting widely within the academic community. The review will also look at the implications of the current state of graduate studies on the health of various academic disciplines. The recruitment and retention of the next generation of staff in UK universities will also be scrutinised.

As part of the study, the reviewers will: analyse the proportion of home-based students and the sources of their funding; consider the present financial arrangements and any particular factors that act as a disincentive to postgraduate study; and make relevant international comparisons.

In his presidential address at the last annual meeting of the British Academy, Sir Tony Wrigley said: "It is a truism that the future health of the humanities and social sciences in this country depends in large measure on the quality and quantity of each successive generation of graduate students embarking on research.

"The current situation is unsatisfactory and the prospective situation in a few years' time deeply alarming. Undergraduates are completing their studies with a heavy and increasing load of debt. Many are reluctant to add to their burdens by embarking on three to five years of graduate work. It requires an unusual degree of dedication to tip the balance in favour of beginning graduate study."

This month the academy asked subject associations and academic societies to identify concerns about sub-fields within their subject areas which they believe might be endangered. The final report by the academy will be published in the summer of 2001.

fields.headline: Lure of money
fields.standfirst:
The addition of finance to accounting courses 
is proving popular, says Graham Wade
fields.trailText: The addition of finance to accounting courses is proving popular, says Graham Wade.
fields.body:
Finance degrees have not taken off in the same way that accounting awards have, partly because the former possess no clear, well defined path of professional development. The latter, of course, lead to accountancy and the possibility of becoming a chartered accountant.

Degrees with finance in the title are usually taught within business schools and the subject can often be studied as part of a wide range of business programmes. Portsmouth University's business school, for instance, offers BA accounting with finance and BA international finance and trade.

Michael Page oversees the provision of degrees in this sphere, which all include the option of a year's work placement. This year's target intake of undergraduates is about 120, around a quarter of whom are being recruited in clearing. Professor Page says: "Our standard entry requirement is 18 points, which falls to an average of around 12-14 in clearing. I should point out that we admit students as individuals, so whatever their exam profile is, it's still worth contacting us if a specific course appeals to them.

While the bulk of his first degrees continue to reflect a bias towards accounting, he notes that the introduction of the BA accounting with finance has attracted a lot of students. "It reflects a slight shift of emphasis in the marketplace. That degree gives people the possibility of careers in the City or financial services, while still holding out the traditional route into accountancy," he says.

The BA accounting with finance allows holders extensive exemptions from professional accounting exams and its sandwich year can be spent abroad. On the finance side, students are required to take courses dealing with business finance, banking and financial structure, and international financial management.

The BA international finance and trade has been running since 1995 and is designed for those aiming at careers in international financial services or with firms that control significant interests abroad.

Prof Page says that roughly half of those graduating from Portsmouth's accounting and finance degrees eventually qualify as professional accountants. About 60% of students are male and across all courses roughly a third of undergraduates opt for the year's work placement, a proportion that has declined since the abolition of grants and the introduction of tuition fees. Most students now wish to complete their courses as quickly as possible to minimise debt.

At Thames Valley University, finance can be taken as the minor element in a combined degree with a wide variety of other disciplines. The most popular is the BA business with finance, in which the latter counts for about a third of content. Head of accounting Paul Wilson says: "Most students still prefer to register for accounting degrees because they ease the pathway open to professional accountancy."

In clearing, a candidate aiming for the BA business with finance would generally be expected to possess at least eight points at A-level. No particular subjects are required, although applicants will be questioned on their motivation and commitment.

Wilson explains that the finance element of the combined degree focuses on both personal and corporate aspects. "In personal finance students will look at planning an individual's finances bearing in mind issues such as capital versus income, tax considerations, insurance and pensions. Corporate finance covers the stock market, company borrowing, treasury management and other topics."

Relatively few other first degrees in the UK offer students the chance to study personal finance in such depth, yet it is a fast-growing employment sector for banks and insurance firms. Graduates often find jobs with them and also with credit card operations and pension funds. Some work as financial consultants.

Often the key to selecting the right course in this confusing field is to rigorously assess whether the qualification will lead you in the employment direction you have in mind. Always ask any admissions tutor where recent graduates have found work and pin them down on what exemptions, if any, the award will give you in any future professional exams.

fields.headline: Rumours Unlimited
fields.standfirst: All today's rumours taken on a trip to Farringdon Road in an open-top bus, especially for National Cleavage week.
fields.trailText: Peter Risdale has admitted that Leeds won't be signing Norwegian international John Arne Riise from Monaco - despite every paper insisting today that the deal was about to go through. "John Aarne Riise is not coming to Leeds," Ridsdale told anonova.com "I spoke to the club on Monday and they reiterated that he is not for sale at any price. He is a player that we have expressed an interest in but they always consistently said he is not for sale. I'd prefer not to say how much we bid - but the price is not the issue, the issue is whether he was for sale or not."
fields.body:
Peter Risdale has admitted that Leeds won't be signing Norwegian international John Arne Riise from Monaco - despite every paper insisting today that the deal was about to go through. "John Aarne Riise is not coming to Leeds," Ridsdale told anonova.com "I spoke to the club on Monday and they reiterated that he is not for sale at any price. He is a player that we have expressed an interest in but they always consistently said he is not for sale. I'd prefer not to say how much we bid - but the price is not the issue, the issue is whether he was for sale or not."

Another manager who seems likely to be disappointed is Alex Ferguson. According to the Mirror, the Manchester United boss has been working like the clappers to complete a £13m triple transfer swoop for Sol Campbell, Ronald de Boer and Winston Bogarde before Friday's Champions League deadline. But the Star reckon that "sources close" to Campbell insist that there has been no contact with Old Trafford - despite the Mirror's claims. And Ronald de Boer - according to onefootball - has also poured cold water over a possible move to United: "These rumours simply aren't true," he said. "This weekend I have spoken to both Barcelona's coach and president with a view to sorting out my present situation with the club."

Onefootball says that Rangers are closing in on 22-year-old Espanyol striker Raul Tamudo and hope to complete a £12m deal before the Champions' League deadline. Tamudo's agent, Tomás Durán, has confirmed that the offer "is firm," and that "they [Rangers] are very thrilled to be able to contract the player".

Meanwhile the Mirror reports that Newcastle have dropped their interest in Roma defender Sergei Gurenko. The Belarus international was due to have a two week trial with the Magpies but manager Bobby Robson said: "Roma wanted guarantees about the fee and we were not prepared to give them any."

Fiorentina have agreed a fee with Barcelona for Boudewijn Zenden - but the Dutch winger is yet to be convinced of a move to Florence, reports onefootball. "The agreement with Barcelona is already there," Fiorentina coach Fatih Terim has admitted. "Now it's just a case of convincing Zenden to come to Florence. For that reason, I'll give him a call in the next few hours. For me he's the ideal player to strengthen this squad."

Steve McManaman has turned down a move to Middlesbrough and could be off to Italy. According to the Express, Lazio president Sergio Cragnotti has confirmed he has made an £8m bid for the player.

fields.headline: Week two: the expert's view
fields.standfirst: Last Friday, our pundits placed their second round of bets in our weekly gambling game, in association with Blue Square. Now they learn where they went wrong.
fields.trailText: Paul MacInnes
fields.body:
Paul MacInnes

Treble: Arsenal to beat Charlton 2/7, Newcastle to draw with Tottenham 9/4 and Wimbledon to draw with Watford 11/5. (£6)

One swallow does not make a summer as I believe the proverb goes and Mr MacInnes would do well to remember this as last week's success seems to have gone to his head.

As I will never tire of saying, it is a marathon not a sprint. Mr MacInnes decried his healthy £11.12 profit last week as 'very little' but in the long run it is the slow accumulation of money rather than the one-off big wins that keep the bankroll going.

This week, in search of the big hit, he went for a treble, a mistake in itself (although in this case, because one leg was a Nationwide league match, he was forced to do so by the no singles rule), but more so when you consider its component parts.

Backing any team at 2/7 seems a doubtful course of action on the whole - if you have the 7 why do you need the 2 - but at this stage of the season, while players are still getting used to each other and the relative strengths of the opposing sides is still comparatively uncertain, it seems even more unwise. By backing a team at 2/7 you are effectively saying that if the game was played 9 times your team would win at least 7 of them (8 to for you to make a profit). Okay, so Arsenal won this time but would they win 7 times out of 9? This looks like the classic case of putting in the cert to make up the third leg of a treble, a practice that has a long and noble history of going horribly wrong.

The second leg of the treble, Newcastle and Spurs to draw, isn't my idea of a bet, particularly given Mr MacInnes's self-justification. I'm not a big fan of backing draws generally but in matches where I expect goals this counts double; the more goals are scored in a game the less likely it is to end in a draw. If goals are expected, a better bet might be 4 or more goals (also 9/4), all you are giving up is 0-0 (an unlikely score given your reading of the game) and 1-1 and yet you get 3-1, 1-3, 2-3, 3-2 and any number of other high scores in return. The only time a draw can be value, to my mind, is in a match neither team can afford to lose (European, International or Cup matches typically) or a match between two teams that look unlikely to score against each other, and in both these cases it is almost certainly better value to back 0-0 (or rather no goalscorer so we have own goals for free) than it is the draw.

Thus the third leg of Paul's treble, Wimbledon and Watford to draw, is another bet I would have avoided (though in this case it came up). With two winners and one loser, the trouble with trebles once again becomes clear. What could have been a good weekend turned into a losing one through pure naked greed. Patience is the key.

Andy Knott

Manchester City v Coventry: Goals scored 4 or more 2/1 (£10)

I don't totally disagree with this bet - at least by doing a single Mr Knott gave himself a decent chance - but I'm not convinced it was value with both defences likely to be improving match by match as they get to know their teammates and neither attack as potent as might appear from the midweek results.

It is actually surprising how few Premiership games involve four or more goals (though 4 out of 10 games did at the weekend) - assuming an average game, the true price would be much nearer 3/1 than 2/1 - so to have a bet at 2/1 an exceptional match must be anticipated. It's not a bet I would have made but with three goals scored it was a close thing.

Scott Murray

Arsenal v Charlton: Half time - Full time Arsenal - Arsenal 4/7 (£10)

Early in the season I'd much rather be taking long odds on there being a surprise than taking short odds that the established order is confirmed. This looks like one of those bets where Mr Murray just thought 'this is going to happen' rather than really asking himself if it represented value.

If the game was played 11 times would Arsenal be leading at half time and fulltime in at least 7 of them? If they would, then Mr Murray was just plain unlucky but I don't think so. For a start, Charlton's loss to Everton hinged on the sending-off of Carl Tiler in the first half and even after that Charlton played some good football. For a second, if Arsenal have been profligate thus far the likelihood is they will stay profligate, its no good just saying it 'can't continue'. But most importantly Mr Murray's bet is unlikely to be value because the bookies have him sussed.

Generally speaking in a game where there is a short priced favourite the value in half-time/full-time betting is far more likely to be found in backing draw/favourite than in backing favourite/favourite, because the cunning bookmakers, knowing which outcome is always backed, artificially shorten favourite/favourite.

In this case the odds on draw/Arsenal were 4/1, surely better value than the 4/7 on Arsenal/Arsenal, though obviously less likely to come in. The actual result, Charlton/Arsenal, was 28/1, but you would have had to be a clairvoyant to pick that one out.

Sean Ingle

Newcastle v Spurs (Asian handicap bet) Spurs + ½ a goal at 8/11, Manchester City to beat Coventry (11/10), East Fife to beat Montrose (4/6), and Birmingham to beat Nottingham Forest (7/4). Four trebles at £1, one accumulator at £1.

Mr Ingle, I see, has stuck doggedly to the tried and tested formula that proved so unsuccessful last week, namely picking four selections and combining them in multiples. And again, as last week, it has cost him money. His two winners, mind you, were from the English first division and the Scottish third division and as such could not be placed as singles anyway, so he has an excuse.

His first selection, Spurs (+½) on the Asian handicap, is interesting. This is definitely a market I will be looking at closely this year as it can give you a opportunity to back against teams you don't fancy without having to worry about the dreaded draw coming along to spoil the party, as so often seems to happen. In this case I'm not so convinced that Mr Ingle was getting value, effectively through his bet he is laying Newcastle at 11/8 to win at home. And though undoubtedly Newcastle had injury worries it is important to remember that the bigger the club the less effect injuries will have on performance. For, Man Utd, for example, only the really key players such as Keane and Beckham would be a major loss because their squad is such that there is always a good player waiting to slot into the vacant position. For Newcastle, though to a lesser extent, the same thing applies.

The other three selections also all seem fair enough though none stand out as 'must bets', which strictly speaking should be our criteria before we place a wager (though how dull life would be if we stuck to this). 11/10 about Manchester City beating Coventry seemed about right to me and in retrospect it certainly looks as though it was the Charlton result rather than the Sunderland result that will prove the truer reflection of City's form this season.

The 4/6 about East Fife at Montrose - and I do think there is value to be had by THOROUGH research into Scottish lower division football - may prove to have been a shade of value though it's a bit early in the season to be forming judgements about the relative strengths of such unknown quantities. I don't generally approve of backing teams at odds on away from home but it must be said that in the lower Scottish divisions home advantage does not seem to count for much. Finally, Birmingham at Forest is a game I probably would have steered clear of. I have little respect for David Platt or Trevor Francis, it was just a case of which manager could waste the talent at his disposal most effectively.

So a pretty poor week all round for our punters, but its still only August they have plenty of time to learn from their mistakes, as do we all dear punters, as do we all.

Andy Knott Manchester City v Coventry: Goals scored 4 or more 2/1 (£10) I don't totally disagree with this bet - at least by doing a single Mr Knott gave himself a decent chance - but I'm not convinced it was value with both defences likely to be improving match by match as they get to know their teammates and neither attack as potent as might appear from the midweek results. It is actually surprising how few Premiership games involve four or more goals (though 4 out of 10 games did at the weekend) - assuming an average game, the true price would be much nearer 3/1 than 2/1 - so to have a bet at 2/1 an exceptional match must be anticipated. It's not a bet I would have made but with three goals scored it was a close thing. Scott Murray Arsenal v Charlton: Half time - Full time Arsenal - Arsenal 4/7 (£10) Early in the season I'd much rather be taking long odds on there being a surprise than taking short odds that the established order is confirmed. This looks like one of those bets where Mr Murray just thought 'this is going to happen' rather than really asking himself if it represented value. If the game was played 11 times would Arsenal be leading at half time and fulltime in at least 7 of them? If they would, then Mr Murray was just plain unlucky but I don't think so. For a start, Charlton's loss to Everton hinged on the sending-off of Carl Tiler in the first half and even after that Charlton played some good football. For a second, if Arsenal have been profligate thus far the likelihood is they will stay profligate, its no good just saying it 'can't continue'. But most importantly Mr Murray's bet is unlikely to be value because the bookies have him sussed. Generally speaking in a game where there is a short priced favourite the value in half-time/full-time betting is far more likely to be found in backing draw/favourite than in backing favourite/favourite, because the cunning bookmakers, knowing which outcome is always backed, artificially shorten favourite/favourite. In this case the odds on draw/Arsenal were 4/1, surely better value than the 4/7 on Arsenal/Arsenal, though obviously less likely to come in. The actual result, Charlton/Arsenal, was 28/1, but you would have had to be a clairvoyant to pick that one out. Sean Ingle Newcastle v Spurs (Asian handicap bet) Spurs + ½ a goal at 8/11, Manchester City to beat Coventry (11/10), East Fife to beat Montrose (4/6), and Birmingham to beat Nottingham Forest (7/4). Four trebles at £1, one accumulator at £1. Mr Ingle, I see, has stuck doggedly to the tried and tested formula that proved so unsuccessful last week, namely picking four selections and combining them in multiples. And again, as last week, it has cost him money. His two winners, mind you, were from the English first division and the Scottish third division and as such could not be placed as singles anyway, so he has an excuse. His first selection, Spurs (+½) on the Asian handicap, is interesting. This is definitely a market I will be looking at closely this year as it can give you a opportunity to back against teams you don't fancy without having to worry about the dreaded draw coming along to spoil the party, as so often seems to happen. In this case I'm not so convinced that Mr Ingle was getting value, effectively through his bet he is laying Newcastle at 11/8 to win at home. And though undoubtedly Newcastle had injury worries it is important to remember that the bigger the club the less effect injuries will have on performance. For, Man Utd, for example, only the really key players such as Keane and Beckham would be a major loss because their squad is such that there is always a good player waiting to slot into the vacant position. For Newcastle, though to a lesser extent, the same thing applies. The other three selections also all seem fair enough though none stand out as 'must bets', which strictly speaking should be our criteria before we place a wager (though how dull life would be if we stuck to this). 11/10 about Manchester City beating Coventry seemed about right to me and in retrospect it certainly looks as though it was the Charlton result rather than the Sunderland result that will prove the truer reflection of City's form this season. The 4/6 about East Fife at Montrose - and I do think there is value to be had by THOROUGH research into Scottish lower division football - may prove to have been a shade of value though it's a bit early in the season to be forming judgements about the relative strengths of such unknown quantities. I don't generally approve of backing teams at odds on away from home but it must be said that in the lower Scottish divisions home advantage does not seem to count for much. Finally, Birmingham at Forest is a game I probably would have steered clear of. I have little respect for David Platt or Trevor Francis, it was just a case of which manager could waste the talent at his disposal most effectively. So a pretty poor week all round for our punters, but its still only August they have plenty of time to learn from their mistakes, as do we all dear punters, as do we all.

webTitle: Meet Shaiza Khan, the Pakistan women's captain

fields.headline: Meet Shaiza Khan, the Pakistan women's captain
fields.trailText: Sajjid Shah, Pakistan's 12-year-old middle-order bat, starved herself for a week until her parents allowed her to tour Ireland this summer. But her captain, Shaiza Khan, took it in her stride - family arguments are nothing to a woman who has suffered death threats for her sport.
fields.body:
Sajjid Shah, Pakistan's 12-year-old middle-order bat, starved herself for a week until her parents allowed her to tour Ireland this summer. But her captain, Shaiza Khan, took it in her stride - family arguments are nothing to a woman who has suffered death threats for her sport.

Shaiza, now 32, has been the Pakistan captain since their first international - against New Zealand in 1997. She also the opens the batting and bowls legspin. She and her younger sister, Sharmeen, were educated in England - at Shrewsbury School and the University of Leeds - but went back to Pakistan in 1988 and decided to try to set up a national team. In a country where there was no serious national organisation for women players, it wasn't easy.

"We didn't really know how the country worked. It had been a childhood dream of ours to play for Pakistan and we thought that we could just start up a team. We didn't have proper knowledge. Benazir Bhutto had just taken over the leadership of Pakistan and people were worried that women were going to take over everything."

The sisters were initially opposed by some religious groups until Shaiza had a meeting with a fundamentalist leader in Karachi. She agreed that they would never play against a male side and the opposition was dropped. Shaiza, who is a Muslim, said: "It was not that big a sacrifice to make."

Since then, their main problems have been with the Pakistan Cricket Board - whether through irritating bureaucracy or things more sinister. Shaiza also feels that the Board have not treated them fairly financially. "The government of Pakistan sanctioned 20 million rupees to us, a year and a half back. It went to the cricket board, but we've never heard of it since."

Luckily Shaiza's father, Mohasaid Khan, is an extremely wealthy businessman and a big cricket fan, and can afford to fund both her and her organisation, the PWCCA, which already has 5000 members. When the women found the price of hiring a practice ground mysteriously rising, Mohasaid installed three turf pitches within the gates of his carpet factory in Karachi. He also provides equipment and accommodation for visiting players.

"I'd like to thank my parents who have encouraged me - morally and financially," Shaiza says. "My mother Fauzia has always been a great fan of cricket - she postponed her wedding for two weeks because the 1960 England side were touring. She was worried about our involvement in cricket at first because of the prevailing culture, but now she is 100 per cent behind us."

The team also, perhaps surprisingly, have had a lot of support from the Pakistani media - they get far more coverage than the England women's team in the British press. "We are often in the national papers and magazines and there was a page feature about us in Newsweek in June. We get stopped when we are out - we are minor celebrities really."

The team have yet to win a game, and their defeats tend to be on the heavy side - during the last World Cup, in India in 1997-98, they were bowled out by Australia for just 27, a record. Their poor run continued in Ireland, but Shaiza is not downhearted. "It is a learning process. There is no-one back home to compete against, so any practice is good for us. And I think that we made a good impact."

The team will fly over to New Zealand to watch the World Cup (the mismatches of the last tournament mean that only the top eight teams will play this time) and then they will entertain the Dutch team in March - the first time an international women's team has ever toured Pakistan. Maybe that will at last give them the recognition from the board that they deserve.

Tanya Aldred is assistant editor of Wisden Cricket Monthly. To read last week's Women's Page, by Catherine Hanley, on the Anston women's team, click here.
