fields.headline: Million catch noisy carnival spirit
fields.trailText: More than a million people partied along to the carnival spirit yesterday as Britain staged two of Europe's biggest Afro-Caribbean festivals.
fields.body:
More than a million people partied along to the carnival spirit yesterday as Britain staged two of Europe's biggest Afro-Caribbean festivals.

In London, heavy rain failed to dampen the enthusiasm of almost a million revellers at Europe's largest festival, the 36th Notting Hill carnival. And in Leeds more than 75,000 people celebrated a similar event.

Despite a downpour at midday just as the colourful parade of floats, flamboyantly dressed dancers and Caribbean steel bands was about to start, the streets of west London were packed with spectators.

The event, which featured more than 75 costume bands and two live stages, has its roots in a 1964 street procession aimed at bringing together an Afro-Caribbean community blighted by racism and prejudice.

Police said that there had been 145 reported crimes mainly theft, pick-pocketing, assault, drugs offences and drunkenness resulting in 69 arrests, including one for possession of firearms.

There had also been two stabbings one of which resulted in a man being taken to St Mary's hospital, in Paddington, west London.

Inspector Rod Charles said: "I'm disappointed by any crime that takes place in the carnival but we had half a million people here yesterday and I think it went very well."

An enormous purple scorpion costume was among the more spectacular creations worn by carnival dancers.

Sheryl Henry who has painted children's faces at the carnival for the last seven years was busy painting 10-year-old Dimitri James in dark mauve war paint.

She said: "Carnival may be more commercial but that's not necessarily a bad thing. There is much less violence and it has become more of a family-orientated event. As long as it doesn't lose its spirit carnival should be a place for everybody.

"The loud sound systems are what the younger kids come for today. It is their way of celebrating carnival."

The streets along the route were dotted with 42 speaker rigs which attracted hundreds on every street corner.

Gavin, whose 25,000 watt system was one of the smaller rigs, said: "We have had hundreds of people squeezed around our speakers dancing for hours. People come to hear new music which they can't get in commercial night clubs.

Meanwhile in Leeds, more than 75,000 people thronged the streets for a three-hour procession and open-air reggae festival.

Groups from the Chapeltown and Harehills areas, where the carnival was born 33 years ago, a year after the first event in Notting Hill, swopped saris for Afro-Caribbean costume and vice versa.

The switch was designed to symbolise unity in the local community, which has seen tensions in the past between Asian and Afro-Caribbean groups over drugs and street violence.

White and Asian residents have played an increasing part in recent years in the carnival, which has become a leading tourist fixture.

The Leeds parade was trouble-free in mixed weather, with the long procession led by 16-year-old Sarai Campbell, who beat 15 rival finalists to be crowned carnival queen.

Her winning costume on the theme of Caribbean Paradise was tailor-made to fit her exactly, from hundreds of swatches of material, sequins and tinsel.

webTitle: MP joins attack on visa appeal fee plan

fields.headline: MP joins attack on visa appeal fee plan
fields.standfirst: Special report: refugees in Britain
fields.trailText: Government plans to charge immigrants whose visa applications have failed up to £580 to appeal have been sharply criticised by the National Association of Citizens' Advice Bureaux (Nacab) and a senior backbench Labour MP.
fields.body:
Government plans to charge immigrants whose visa applications have failed up to £580 to appeal have been sharply criticised by the National Association of Citizens' Advice Bureaux (Nacab) and a senior backbench Labour MP.

Under proposals for legislation which could be introduced this autumn, appellants would be charged £280 for written appeals and £580 if the rejection is contested in person. The government, which is reintroducing the right to appeal abolished by the last Conservative administration, said the charges were intended to cover court costs and had been insisted upon by the Lord Chancellor's Department. The Home Office and the Foreign Office have agreed not to charge for their services.

Richard Dunstan, of Nacab, welcomed the restoration of the right to appeal but criticised the fees. "The issue is that the value of the right of appeal will be seriously undermined by the imposition of fees because they will deter some wronged applicants from exercising that right," he said.

"There is no guarantee [of winning an appeal] even if you believe your case to be a strong one. There is a risk therefore, and some of those who are wrongly refused cannot afford to risk that sum of money. I hope very much that ministers in the Lord Chancellor's Department will consider their decision again."

He said the number of appeals per year was likely to be in hundreds rather than thousands, "so the total cost to the government would be relatively small".

He said: "The only reason that the government has put forward in justification for imposing fees is that there is, in its own words, no new money for these visitor appeals. That reason evaporated last month with the chancellor's announcement of £600m for immigration control."

Labour MP David Winnick, a member of the Commons home affairs select committee, yesterday joined in criticism of the proposals.

"I would rather have a system where no payment was involved at all," he said. "But if there is to be payment the charges should be moderate. The sums which have been mentioned are certainly not moderate. I would imagine most Labour MPs would certainly be opposed to anything like £500."

He said he believed that some ministers were unhappy about the charges, and that the lord chancellor "would have a very limited knowledge of what happens at our surgeries and in our correspondence about constituents who are very keen for close family members to visit the UK".

The row over visa appeals comes after an immigration bond scheme which would have forced certain visitors entering the UK to pay a returnable deposit of around £3,000 was dropped by the government after angry reactions from anti-racist and immigration support groups.

A spokesman for the Lord Chancellor's Department said it would be examining the points raised by Nacab.

The sums which have been mentioned are certainly not moderate. I would imagine most Labour MPs would certainly be opposed to anything like £500." He said he believed that some ministers were unhappy about the charges, and that the lord chancellor "would have a very limited knowledge of what happens at our surgeries and in our correspondence about constituents who are very keen for close family members to visit the UK". The row over visa appeals comes after an immigration bond scheme which would have forced certain visitors entering the UK to pay a returnable deposit of around £3,000 was dropped by the government after angry reactions from anti-racist and immigration support groups. A spokesman for the Lord Chancellor's Department said it would be examining the points raised by Nacab.

fields.headline: Step into the ring
fields.standfirst: She doesn't want to admit it, but Betty Clarke is knocked out by the US contingent of loud, dumb rock bands at the Reading festival
fields.trailText: She doesn't want to admit it, but Betty Clarke is knocked out by the US contingent of loud, dumb rock bands at the Reading festival.
fields.body:
It was a fight not to be missed. The setting: the Reading festival. The contenders: homely, unthreatening UK dadrock bands versus fully merchandised, horror-tactic throwing, US punk metal heroes. And it all started with Limp Bizkit.

While it is easy to despise a band whose guitarist paints himself red and white, Limp Bizkit and their simplistic rap for rock fans prove more than worthy of attention. "I'm just a dumb American," singer Fred Durst acknowledges, instantly finding a place in our hearts, as glitter fills the lunchtime sky. You know you shouldn't like it and you wouldn't tell your friends, but their mindless rhythms get us in the party mood.

Masked and boilersuited, Slipknot take to the vast Reading stage and are met by an atmosphere of car crash curiosity. As the nine members of the band make white noise in a choreographed rock out, you suddenly wonder why they are bothering. As each indecipherable rant follows another, it is clear it's not about the songs - it's about the swearing, the jumping up and down till you pass out, about playing with a bad attitude rather than having one. As they tell us how much they love us, Slipknot reveal themselves to be sweet freaks who love their moms and can't believe they're playing their favourite festival.

Our UK heavyweights seem like cabaret by comparison. Primal Scream and their swaggering funk rock fusion get lost outdoors, their intensity and power diluted, proving that a good light show and sexy singer just aren't enough. The Stereophonics - that's pub-rock to anyone under the age of 25 - wheel on Tom Jones for a bit of excitement. Sadly, it works. So it's up to Pulp to restore faith in our chart heroes: they elegantly rework their classics and reveal a more mature, richer sound.

Optimism is suddenly in the air, but it's up to Placebo to give some much-needed muscle to events. Brian Molko visibly grows in stature as he tears into the new material, looking into the crowd and singing in a voice that is either full of nicely embittered wonder or sounds like nails being scratched down a blackboard, depending on your point of view. As they acquire the services of a Californian rapper on one track, the possibilities for Placebo suddenly become endless and delight spreads over Molko's impish face as he thrusts a red fingernailed hand in the air.

But in the end it's a US victory thanks to ... And You Will Know Us by the Trail of Dead and their frantic punk antics. As guitars are smashed amid a wall of feed back, they're the Who covering the Clash in a garage in Austin, Texas and the most exhilarating performance of the weekend. A complete knockout, in fact.

webTitle: Leader: Labour basks; the Tories fail to score

fields.headline: Spending summer
fields.standfirst:
Labour basks; the Tories fail to score
Special report: Tories in opposition
Special report: New Labour in power
Paul Whiteley: Euro choice
fields.trailText: Political events in August must not be over-interpreted. The season is not called silly without cause. Every summer a paradox is exposed. Politics is supposed to be ever less important in our collective life, yet when parliament is not sitting and ministers are away from Whitehall, we say there is "no news" - as if public money did not go on being spent or policy implemented. Or the values which underpin political activity quietly affirmed.
fields.body:
Political events in August must not be over-interpreted. The season is not called silly without cause. Every summer a paradox is exposed. Politics is supposed to be ever less important in our collective life, yet when parliament is not sitting and ministers are away from Whitehall, we say there is "no news" - as if public money did not go on being spent or policy implemented. Or the values which underpin political activity quietly affirmed. That, surely, has been one thing happening this past month. With John Prescott on the bridge, no longer tempted by Peter-the-crab jokes, Labour has basked in rediscovery of its identity as the spending party. It has felt much better about itself since Gordon Brown's grand slam in July. The proposition from Philip Gould's focus groups still stands: Labour needs to dress right if it is to win convincingly once again. Doubtless Mr Gould has been up and down to the parlours of Watford and will have spent his summer writing lengthy hard-line memoranda to the prime minister (though he may now be more careful about how he disseminates them). But the atmosphere has changed. As important as the headline figures in the Mori poll published last week was the finding that Labour supporters are much firmer than they were in their intention to turn out and vote. The spending plan, plus a perception of the government's competence, must have helped.

Yet, as Paul Whiteley points out, people seek confirmation of political messages from their own experience. The risk in Gordon Brown's apparent generosity is that over the next few months people will once again be looking intently at schools and surgeries for signs of beneficial change; of course his largesse does not start to flow until April 2001 at the earliest.

Here, you might think, is an ace of an opportunity for Labour's political opponents - pointing up the gap between promise and delivery. Ministers sit in Whitehall offices far removed from the action. Even those, such as Alan Milburn, surrounded by superior new planning devices have a far from firm grip on what happens at the sharp end, on the beat, in the wards, in the classrooms. Mr Brown has inadvertently redefined the task of his colleagues. They must now become super-managers, masters and mistresses of implementation. Unfortunately it is a role for which few if any of them are trained. Services are managed a long way from the centre.

But the Tories seem unable to avail themselves of the opportunity to score. It is partly that they have not come to terms with their own past. A would-be Tory philosopher writes disparagingly in the Spectator this week of a Labour council contracting out the management of its schools; he of course was silent when contractorisation began under Thatcher. As policy-makers, Hagueite Tories are Bourbons, condemned to forget and learn nothing. The point is made by the latest fuss over Liam Fox's insistence on language tests for "overseas" (ie non-white) doctors. The racism is Hague's opportunism - do or say anything that will win a headline in a right-wing tabloid. The missed opportunity is providing some Tory (or even conservative) thinking about the public services. For a party that believes in the market, you might imagine the principles of supply and demand would suit. Hospitals must recruit abroad because they do not pay enough to attract staff from home. But to say that with conviction would require the Tories to take on their anti-tax shibboleth and, Thatcher's children still, that is something they cannot yet do.

webTitle: Ventriloquism: Ken Campbell's History of Comedy

fields.headline: Gastromancy and other animals
fields.standfirst: Ken Campbell has a new show at the National Theatre - but he'd rather tell  Brian Logan about dogs that talk and sucking spirits up your bottom
fields.trailText: Ken Campbell has a new show at the National Theatre - but he'd rather tell Brian Logan about dogs that talk and sucking spirits up your bottom.
fields.body:
Ken Campbell's conversation is as curlicued as those unmistakable eyebrows. We're supposed to be talking about ventriloquism, the subject of his latest one-man show at the National Theatre. So why is he telling me about storytelling pets? "This dog was owned by a Nottinghamshire miner - its name was Dustbin. It told us a story about ghosts, and a story about rabbits ..."

Ventriloquism is the theme of Ken Campbell's History of Comedy: Part One. "I don't know how many parts there will be," says Campbell. "But Gibbon's Decline and Fall of the Roman Empire was written like that." History of Comedy was commissioned - well, agreed to - by Campbell's old sparring partner and current National boss Trevor Nunn. Having famously hoaxed the media and theatre worlds that the Royal Shakespeare Company, after Nunn's hit 70s production of Nicholas Nickleby, was to ditch Shakespeare in favour of Charles Dickens, did Campbell ever think he would one day work for Nunn at the heart of British theatre? "It's wonderful, isn't it?" he winks.

The brains behind the Ken Campbell Roadshow, formed in 1971, has come a long way. Campbell, Bob Hoskins, Sylvester McCoy and some ferrets touted that manic variety spectacle around the kinds of venue - pubs, working men's clubs - that the arts had deserted. Campbell later founded the Science Fiction Theatre of Liverpool, the major offering of which was Illuminatus!, an 11-hour epic that opened the National's Cottesloe space back in 1978, and introduced set designer Bill Drummond to the text that would later inspire his band, the KLF.

Since being visited onstage at the Nottingham Playhouse by an angel who warned him "I'd been taken off the list of those who are called to the Drama", Campbell has concentrated on autobiographical one-man shows. In 1993, he colonised the Cottesloe with his Bald Trilogy - Furtive Nudist, Pigspurt and Jamais Vu - named to counter the David Hare trilogy unfolding in the theatre next door. The way Campbell tells it, however, the past 30 years were but a digression from his first and real love: ventriloquism. A teenage enthusiast, Campbell's passion for voice-throwing was rekindled last summer, when he attended a ventriloquists' conference in Kentucky.

"You've got to bear in mind that we're a culture that decided not to have ventriloquism. But in the US they carried on with it. It's a scandal over there if you're a father or an uncle and you can't do a bit of ventriloquising." Some 60% of American ventriloquists, reckons Campbell, use the skill for educational rather than entertainment purposes - in schools, say, or even churches. "It has been shown that a lot of folk get the message sharper from a ventriloquist's doll than they do from some berk talking to them."

Such revelations amounted to a conversion for Campbell, who returned to Britain determined to proselytise for this domestically dormant art - and to resume its practice himself. He launches into a potted masterclass halfway through this interview: "A friend of mine made up a phrase which contains all the difficulties in the ventriloquist's book: 'Who dared to put wet fruitbat turd in our dead mummy's bed? Was that you, Verity?' " For five minutes, Campbell contorts his features and further strangulates his buzzsaw Essex vowels in an effort to demonstrate how "h" can become "wh", "ng" become "m", and the magic of Keith Harris be forever demystified. But of course, as he concludes, "a lot of ventriloquists simply grow beards and keep away from the most difficult six letters as best they can".

Campbell's interest, though, derives at least as much from ventriloquism's dummy-free origins as from its modern practice. The word comes from the Latin "venter", meaning stomach, and "loqui", meaning to speak - those who practised speech from the stomach tended, in 16th-century England, to be burnt at the stake as agents of Satan. The first named ventriloquist, however, was a pygmy called Bizou, court jester to an Egyptian pharaoh some 4,500 years ago. Today's pygmy cultures, says Campbell delightedly, still practice much of Bizou's art, hence his contention that "you can't really write about the history of comedy without having lived with the pygmies" - which he intends, in the near future, to do.

His favourite phase in the development of ventriloquism went under the name of gastromancy. "You'd call in a gastromancer," he explains, "if you moved house in ancient Egypt. There would obviously be spirits and demons left lurking there by the people who lived there previously. Now, gastromancers walked with sticky-out arses," he continues, suddenly waddling around with a protuberant backside. "What they do is they hoover the spirit that's in your house up their bottoms - oops! - then you can listen and talk to it in the gastromancer's stomach." It's a far cry from ventriloquism as entertainment, I venture. "I should think," counters Campbell, "it was very entertaining indeed."

His love for the art is transparent, which may be why he's irate that Britain has written it off as naff. "There was this thinking that things like farce and music hall would be all right, and that what needed financial backing were the things that you wouldn't do simply because they were fun. So now it's all gone. The scouts don't do gang shows any more. Huge amounts of money get given to worthy projects. But nobody comes to me and says, 'Wow, that's a fantastic idea, which will give a lot of people a lot of pleasure, here's half a million.' "

This perception, that popular forms of theatre were at some point hived off from what was considered respectable art, has animated Campbell's career. "Foolishly," he says, "when nobody was looking, some things have gone. There's a lot of baby gone out with the bath water." In light of his continuing ardour on this point, does he miss the days when he took bustling, chaotic, popular performance to the people? Six years ago he told one paper: "I think the solo work might be coming to an end." It hasn't yet - although he is to join the cast (angels permitting) of the West End hit Art, alongside old pal and In Sickness and in Health co-star Warren Mitchell. Does the great iconoclast worry that, having performed one-man shows at the National Theatre for more than a decade, he's becoming venerable, "an institution"? The verbal torrent subsides. He shifts uncomfortably.

Campbell, who holds forth incessantly on obscure subjects, is extremely ill-at-ease when asked about perhaps the most obscure of all: himself. "I don't particularly miss anything," he says, eventually. "If I miss it, I can nostalge on it, relive it in my shows." Then, after a pause, "Nah, I'm not bothered. I just get on with my bit. I leave those kind of worries to people like you."

He's not the first clown to seek to avoid being seen to take things seriously. Whether it's by design or by instinct, who knows, but a zany prattle rises from Campbell's stomach whenever conversation threatens to reveal the hidden Ken. That compulsion to digress, of course, is related to the indefatigable fund of ideas with which Campbell has long brightened British theatre - so we should be thankful for it. "That was the only department where I had any value," he says, in a reflective moment, "looking at what exists to see what is missing, to see what people had forgotten about. It's been worrying me for 30 years, since I heard about it, that people don't pad their arses any more ..." And with that he's off again, the gadfly gastromancer, ventriloquist and dummy rolled into one.

Ken Campbell's History of Comedy - Part One: Ventriloquism is in rep at the National Theatre, London SE1 (020-7452 3000), till September 9.

webTitle: Comment, Peter Hain: The International Criminal Court

fields.headline: Calling all tyrants
fields.standfirst:
The International Criminal Court spells the beginning of the end for oppressors, we must give it our support

Special report: Pinochet on trial

Special report: war crimes in the former Yugoslavia
fields.trailText: The International Criminal Court spells the beginning of the end for oppressors, we must give it our support
fields.body:
Dictators and torturers across the world may be sleeping a little less soundly these days. Not because of a sudden attack of conscience, but because Labour - through its recently published draft legislation - is helping to tip the international balance away from impunity and toward justice.

Our draft bill will put Britain's full weight behind the establishment of the International Criminal Court (ICC) which will be a giant step forward for human rights and the rule of international law. For the first time there will be an international body to try individuals responsible for the worst crimes known to humankind. Future Pol Pots and Pinochets should be warned: merchants of oppression, atrocity and genocide, however powerful or feared in their own country, can be brought to justice. And through scrupulously fair trials which can place the blame on individuals rather than communities, the ICC will promote peace and reconciliation.

Based in The Hague, the ICC will build on the model and jurisprudence established to try Nazis in Nuremberg and the current war crimes tribunals for Rwanda and the former Yugoslavia. But uniquely, the ICC will have a forward-looking and potentially global mandate.

The ICC will deal with three clearly defined offences: genocide, war crimes and crimes against humanity. It will have jurisdiction over crimes committed after its establishment - not over past atrocities. The main responsibility for punishing crimes will remain that of nation states. The ICC will only intervene if the countries concerned have proved unable or unwilling genuinely to investigate the crimes themselves. This might happen where conflict has led to the collapse of the local judicial system or where a dictatorial government refuses to punish its own abusers.

Except when the UN Security Council refers situations to the court, the ICC will only have jurisdiction over crimes committed in countries which have ratified the court's statute, or by their nationals. It will look to states to provide evidence, arrest suspects and enforce the sentences it passes down.

Like any body which emerges from many years of extensive negotiation involving the international community, the ICC will be neither a magic wand nor an all-powerful Big Brother. But because it is the product of international agreement, rather than unilateral initiative, the ICC's decisions will represent the will, and demand the respect, of the whole world.

Under Labour, Britain has already proved itself one of the court's strongest supporters. We proved it by our pivotal role at the successful Rome conference that adopted the ICC Treaty. We proved it by helping to give the court the power to punish not only those who massacre civilians but also those who commit sexual violence or use child soldiers. And we continue to prove it by doing our best to mobilise international support for the court, including by lobbying reluctant countries such as the US.

The legislation will enable Britain to provide maximum assistance to the ICC. For example, it will allow the law-enforcement authorities to identify, arrest and, through a streamlined process, surrender war crimes suspects to The Hague. It will allow us to gather evidence, freeze assets and enforce court sentences.

And it will empower our courts to prosecute war crimes, crimes against humanity and genocide committed here or by UK nationals overseas. This means that we will always be able to fulfil our responsibility to prosecute such crimes.

Our ambition is to be one of the court's founding members. The bill will enable Britain to ratify the Rome statute of the ICC and so push up the number of ratifications towards the 60 countries needed for the statute to come into force and for the ICC to begin its work.

We are publishing the bill in draft for comments by October 12 because we want to maximise agreement before its parliamentary introduction, especially among those with particular interests or expertise. There is widespread, cross-party support for the ICC. That will also depend upon cooperation between government and opposition parties. I have written to them and to a wide range of parliamentarians asking for their comments on the draft. We are genuinely open to suggested changes which improve the bill without destroying it. Our draft bill will put Britain's full weight behind the establishment of the International Criminal Court (ICC) which will be a giant step forward for human rights and the rule of international law. For the first time there will be an international body to try individuals responsible for the worst crimes known to humankind. Future Pol Pots and Pinochets should be warned: merchants of oppression, atrocity and genocide, however powerful or feared in their own country, can be brought to justice. And through scrupulously fair trials which can place the blame on individuals rather than communities, the ICC will promote peace and reconciliation. Based in The Hague, the ICC will build on the model and jurisprudence established to try Nazis in Nuremberg and the current war crimes tribunals for Rwanda and the former Yugoslavia. But uniquely, the ICC will have a forward-looking and potentially global mandate. The ICC will deal with three clearly defined offences: genocide, war crimes and crimes against humanity. It will have jurisdiction over crimes committed after its establishment - not over past atrocities. The main responsibility for punishing crimes will remain that of nation states. This might happen where conflict has led to the collapse of the local judicial system or where a dictatorial government refuses to punish its own abusers. It will look to states to provide evidence, arrest suspects and enforce the sentences it passes down. But because it is the product of international agreement, rather than unilateral initiative, the ICC's decisions will represent the will, and demand the respect, of the whole world. fields.headline: All's fair in love and war
fields.standfirst: Last night's TV: Gareth McLean
fields.trailText: EastEnders/Gladiators: The Brutal Truth/Steps Into Summer
fields.body:
Is it safe to sit Pat from EastEnders (BBC1) at an emergency exit on an aeroplane? What if, in the event of a landing on water, one of her jumbo earrings got caught in the door mechanism and jammed it, consigning everyone on board to death by drowing? And if that did happen, who would be to blame? Pat herself? Big Melinda's Jumbo Jewellery Jamboree just off Walford High Street? Or the airline stewardess who didn't notice the potential danger attached to Pat's earring excesses, not to mention her penchant for voluminous botanically-themed chiffon blouses, which could quite easily become a fire hazard under the wrong circumstances? Of course, the biggest potential danger attached to Pat's jewellery is Pat herself. Or rather her amazing sexual allure, which has once again intoxicated Frank, who, after see ing her flamenco, is all set to throw caution to the wind and attempt to cast a net over Pat's heart.

However, the sexual intrigue and love parallelogram between Fat Pat, Coy Roy, Frank Frank and Peggy (who isn't as leggy as to justify it as her nickname) are just sideshows to the main event in Spain: Irene's Alicante existential angst.

When Irene first appeared in Walford - ex-sister-in-law of Kathy, mother to the swinging-like-a-weathervane Tony and Sarah "Eyebrows" Hills - she was a harpie in a satinette dressing gown. But last night, her transformation into sympathetic, thwarted heroine was complete. Never entirely happy with Terry - and even less so since her plundering of Troy - finally it was the teabags that broke the camel's back. And when it broke, the torrent of rage, frustration, self- loathing and self-doubt that Roberta Taylor unleashed was undeniably moving.

By containing the action within the three couples, the Spain special avoided past "EastEnders on tour" disasters, with no crass stereotypes (the Fowlers' Oirish adventure, say) or comedy capers. While the script was cliché-ridden and a tad heavy-handed - Pat is an R Kelly fan? - so is life, and we can give writer Tony Jordan the benefit of the doubt. One thing that was weird though: is Alicante the land of the midnight sun or had Frank and Pat stayed out at dinner for a whole 24 hours?

In case you weren't sure, Gladiators: The Brutal Truth (BBC2) put paid to the scurrilous rumour that the gladiators of ancient Rome were animal-loving, child-friendly, dab-hands-at-macramé types, the Blue Peter presenters of ye olden times. According to Terry Jones - and you might have missed this bit in Ridley Scott's Gladiator, presumably the phenomenon which got this project the go-ahead - gladiators killed people. In horrible ways. With big swords.

And they didn't spend their days making daisy chains at all. The Bafta Award for Stating the Obvious goes to... Actually, Gladiators: The Brutal Truth wasn't that bad - as history programmes for 10-year-olds go. As he scampered around the ruins of old Pompeii, Jones warned that the Romans had nice houses but "that doesn't mean they shared our values". (Doesn't it? So the Nazis, who built such nice motorways, weren't nice either? Surprise, surprise.)

Instead of really homing in on and exploring the issue of how the public of Rome were the driving force behind the gladiatorial battles, the public executions, the lions and tigers and bears (oh my) ripping Christians to bits, the blind fury and loathesome power of the mob was a footnote, not the central plank of the documentary. Intelligent musing lost out to spectacle, and hence we were treated to Jones in a mini-toga fighting a wooden pole instead of an examination of how the public is the fiercest predator of all.

And speaking of wooden performances, Steps Into Summer (BBC1) was so beyond bad, it wasn't even so-bad-it's-good. It was just bad. There were so many lowlights it'd be difficult to pinpoint one exactly, but the version of I Know Him So Well made me yearn for Mel and Sue on Stars In Their Eyes. Yet the fivesome are so incredibly liked, selling bucketloads of records. It can only be the Jane McDonald syndrome: how we Brits like the plucky amateurs or at least the amateur-sounding, the faux humble, the celebs we can imagine down the pub doing karaoke. Like redcoats on ketamine, Steps embody everything cheesy and awful about British culture.

On a plane with that lot, you'd want Pat by the emergency exit.

fields.headline: Hear this
fields.trailText: New World Of War/ The Sixties
fields.body:
In the New World Of War (8.0pm, Radio 4), Gerry Northam considers an unpleasant aspect of the human genome project.Our new knowledge of DNA may help cure many intractable diseases. But it could also open the door to some horrifying biological weapons. Years ago the white South African regime tried developing a strain of bacteria lethal only to its black population. Now, even more precise chemical targeting may be just over the horizon.

With the help of Mary Quant, Peter Hall, Mary Whitehouse and others, Julian Pettifer launches a five-part history of The Sixties (9.0pm, Radio 2) which makes me wonder if I simply failed to pay proper attention at the time. The whole scene sounds so much more gripping now than it ever felt as it unfolded. What we failed to understand, of course, was that tape recorders and television were archiving the decade as never before. Like prehistoric insects, we became the first generation caught in electronic amber.

webTitle: Comment, Yvonne Roberts: Our young people need a champion to protect them

fields.headline: Our young people need a champion to protect them
fields.standfirst:
Why is England without a children's rights commissioner?

Special report: child protection
fields.trailText: Why is England without a children's rights commissioner? The issue of children's rights has to be addressed properly in a democratic society.
fields.body:
The right for a baby, conceived after a father's death, to have his name on the birth certificate; the right for young people in care (and not in receipt of child benefit) to have a nest egg from the Treasury when they become adults; and that most tortured of decisions, the right of "Mary" not to be separated from her Siamese twin, "Jodie", even though this may mean death for both - supported by the twins' parents but rejected by Mr Justice Johnson - all are issues which highlight, yet again, that it is not just in the aftermath of a child abuse scandal or some terrible misdemeanour by "bad" boys and girls that the issue of children's rights have to be addressed properly in a democratic society.

Over 100 organisations, including the National Confederation of Parent and Teacher Associations and several dozen MPs had hoped that this summer, after more than a decade of campaigning, spurred on by Sir Ronald Waterhouse's report on abuse in Welsh children's homes, the government would appoint a children's commissioner for England. A commissioner is on the agenda for Scotland while Northern Ireland's Human Rights Commission has a remit which covers the young.

Eighteen commissioners or ombudsmen are in place around the world including those in Australia, Guatemala and Denmark. In Spain, the city of Madrid has had an ombudsman since 1996 with wide powers including the clout to investigate individual cases and the ability to issue warnings (for instance, on inaccurate images of the young in the media). Issues tackled include immigrant and marginilised children; children's free time and the development of children's councils in the city. (Perhaps one way of encouraging adult participation later in the democratic process?) So how do we measure up in England?

Labour is, of course, committed to building a human rights culture and modernising government. It has invested hugely in childcare and alleviating child poverty. It even promised a commissioner and a minister for children in its 1992 manifesto. All of which makes its bout of midsummer madness on the establishment of an English commissioner all the more inexplicable.

Under the new Care Standards Act, England will have, instead, a children's rights director. He or she will be concerned only with the 200,000 children living away from home, for instance, in residential care and boarding schools. The other 11m young people under the age of 18 will remain without an equivalent representative voice. The government also tried to foist a director with slightly wider powers on the Welsh Assembly but to its credit, it is having none of it. Instead, the assembly is pushing for a commissioner with a role closer to that defined by its health and social services committee earlier this year.

The Welsh commissioner, as defined by the committee, would promote the UN Convention on the Rights of the Child (which includes political, and economic goals); require impact statements to assess the affect of policies on the young; conduct an annual audit on the state of Wales's children; encourage research; monitor government actions; raise the profile of the young and act as champion, watchdog and whistleblower. A commissioner would also have the power to inquire into breaches of children's rights and demand action. "At the heart of our need for a commissioner," the committee concluded, "Is the need for all of us to listen to all children and young people; to have a genuine commitment to reflecting their views."

It sounds like common sense - so why has the government backed off in England? Does an ombudsman require too much administrative upheaval? Or can it be fear of a certain section of the population who view children's rights as a euphemism for infant anarchy and adults wronged? Those who believe that "rights" basically boils down to smacking - and that's nobody's grown-up business but their own?

Moira Rayner, a New Zealand lawyer with international experience in children's rights, now has three years to challenge such head-in-the- sand ideas - and to add to the pressure on government to appoint an English commissioner with strong statutory powers. Rayner is director of the newly created Office of the Children's Rights Commissioner for London.

One of the least publicised promises made in the mayoral election was to appoint "a children's champion" in the assembly. Livingstone has yet to fill the post. Nevertheless, Rayner's work (guided by a panel of young people and partly funded by the lottery) is already underway. She is preparing a report on the state of London's children and (with Livingstone's officers) drawing up a strategy. "If London can get it right for children," runs her argument. "Any major city can."

"Children's rights are often confused with civil rights - for instance, the right to freedom of association," Rayner says. "What they're actually about is social rights - the right to a decent quality of life. And the right for a child's views to be treated seriously when important decisions are made about the society in which we all live. They don't cancel out adult responsibility but they do encourage fair play and cooperation."

London has 1.74m young people under 18. Twice the national proportion live in workless households. But Rayner is keen that the government's obligations aren't restricted to minimising risk and tackling poverty, important though those goals are. What also matter, she argues, are positive measures to stimulate the well-being of the young, for instance, in transport, the environment and health. (The NSPCC too has long argued for well-being indicators to establish a coordinated national measure of child development.)

In July, with little fanfare, the government established a children's unit to coordinate efforts. Instead of being anchored in the Cabinet Office alongside the women's unit and the social exclusion unit, as organisations such as the NSPCC had hoped, the children's unit has been sited in the Department of Education and Employment, backed by a cross-governmental committee chaired by Paul Boateng, at the Home Office.

The government has also said it will monitor the progress of the Welsh Children's Commissioner before taking a decision on an English equivalent - although the worldwide evidence already exists. A clear strong voice is missing. As Sir William Utting, former Chief Inspector of Social Services, says, "Governments are dominated by the pushes and pulls of an electorate in which only grown-ups have votes, and issues about children are, as a result, continuously overshadowed... Children need a strong independent office to represent their interests comprehensively and to ensure that public and private agencies deliver what law and public policy require."

That is understood and accepted in Scotland, Ireland and Wales - why not in England too?

fields.headline: Answer me
fields.standfirst: Getting personal with ... Clive Anderson
fields.trailText: Getting personal with ... Clive Anderson
fields.body:
Full Name:

Clive Stuart Anderson

Have you ever adopted a pseudonym and, if so, why?

William Hague, so I could lead the Conservative Party.

Have you ever lied about your age and, if so, why?

I pretended I was 17 so I could fight in World War Two, but I was under the age of 14 and couldn't persuade them.

How would you describe yourself in a lonely hearts ad?

Dishonestly.

What was the last illegal thing you did?

It's impossible to drive a car without breaking the law, and I did take part in the Brinks-Mat robbery.

What was the last kind-hearted thing you did?

I do everything with a kind heart, but sometimes you have to be cruel to be kind.

Who's the nicest person you've ever worked with?

That's a hard one, I've only worked in the legal and TV professions.

What are the initials of the most unpleasant person you've ever worked with?

AA

Has a critic ever made you cry?

Gasp yes, cry no.

What would you advertise without a fee?

The Charity Card.

What would you never advertise?

I don't advertise, but never say never.

What wakes you up screaming at four in the morning?

I don't get to sleep before 4am.

What takes you to a "happy place"?

A dram of whisky after dinner.

Clive Anderson presents Hypotheticals tonight and this Thursday on BBC2 at 11.20pm.

webTitle: Leader: Labour cannot ignore its family pledge

fields.headline: Justice is priceless
fields.standfirst:
Labour cannot ignore its family pledge
Special report: refugees in Britain
fields.trailText: In opposition the words could not have been bolder. It was time for government commitment to families to be extended to immigration and asylum procedures too. These were not just bold but brave words in an election atmosphere in which the Tories, playing the race card with a 1996 Asylum and Immigration Act, prompted the Economist to declare they deserved "contempt, not votes, for proposing (such a) nasty little bill".
fields.body:
In opposition the words could not have been bolder. It was time for government commitment to families to be extended to immigration and asylum procedures too. These were not just bold but brave words in an election atmosphere in which the Tories, playing the race card with a 1996 Asylum and Immigration Act, prompted the Economist to declare they deserved "contempt, not votes, for proposing (such a) nasty little bill". Labour was unequivocal: "It is in no one's interest that close family members are divided by arbitrary and unjust regulations." And it was quite specific about the need of families to be together for special events - weddings, births and funerals. The appeal procedure for people refused a visitor's visa for such events, abolished by the Tories in 1993, would be restored.

One year into government, restoring the right of appeal was still being upheld, but by then justice had a price, which charging appeal fees could recover. Three years on from the election, the precise cost to the government of an appeal has been calculated: £280 for a paper decision and £580 for an oral hearing. In a new consultative document, ministers are proposing applicants should be required to meet this cost over and above their own legal fees. If an appeal succeeded, the fee could be returned, but as the National Association of Citizens Advice Bureau (Nacab) noted yesterday, many applicants would not be able to afford such a risk. Given the reputation of our hardline immigration procedures, who would want to rely on receiving a fair deal? One out of five appeals in the old system succeeded, but that meant four out of five failed.

Labour should go back to first principles. They were right to emphasise the importance of supporting families. They were right to recognise the bonding which special events achieve. There was never any suggestion in the old system of charging appellants. Why are Labour ministers introducing it in the new? The only explanation has been that there is no new money for such appeals but, as Nacab has noted, this reason evaporated last month with the chancellor's announcement of £600m extra for immigration control. One Labour MP, David Winnick, has already protested. Others should follow in his wake. The government's proposal is mean, dishonest and in breach of civil liberties. It should be rejected.

fields.headline: Watch this
fields.trailText: Gandhi/Shakespeare In Love/Black Rain
fields.body:
Gandhi

(Richard Attenborough, 1982)

7pm, Sky Cinema

An epic biography, charting the life of the Mahatma from his London studies to confrontation with the apartheid regime of South Africa, and the main contest: the non-violent rebellion against the British rulers of his native India ("You have been guests in our home for long enough. Now we would like you to leave"). The crowd and massacre scenes are hugely impressive, but at the core is screen debutant Ben Kingsley's majestically understated performance. His best actor Oscar was one of eight the film garnered, includ ing best director and best picture. Great cast includes Candice Bergen's American admirer, Edward Fox's brutal English colonel, Geraldine James as a disciple, and the stalwarts: Gielgud, Mills, Hordern and Howard.

Shakespeare In Love

(John Madden, 1998)

8pm, Sky Premier

Some critics bemoaned its lack of intellectual stringency, but Madden's robust comic romance plays handsomely to the masses in the pit rather than the highbrows in the gallery. Much of the fun is down to Tom Stoppard's typically witty, literate script that melds major life events of the Bard with his attempts to write Romeo And Juliet (first draft entitled Romeo And Ethel, The Pirate's Daughter). There are wicked puns, pratfalls, rhetorical flourishes, tears and laughter, and a cast that revels in it all, from Joseph Fiennes's winsome, feckless Will to Gwyneth Paltrow's Viola, his love and muse.

Black Rain

(Ridley Scott, 1989)

11.25pm, Sky Premier

Stylish culture-clash thriller with maverick American cops running rampant in Japan: Pollack's The Yakuza as pop video. Michael Douglas gets vengeful when buddy Andy Garcia loses his head and joins forces with by-the-book local detective Ken Takakura. He, of course, learns to play the all-American way. All very stereotypical, and with a misfiring mud-and-blood finale at odds with the clean-cut, gleaming mayhem that precedes it.

webTitle: TV: A new family for Eastenders

fields.headline: Easy come, easy go
fields.standfirst: A new family moves into Albert Square next month, replacing the late unlamented di Marcos. Establishing families in soaps is always a tricky task for producers. But what went wrong this time? Ex-EastEnders scriptwriter  Matthew Baylis  explains
fields.trailText: A new family moves into Albert Square next month, replacing the late unlamented di Marcos. Establishing families in soaps is always a tricky task for producers. But what went wrong this time? Ex-EastEnders scriptwriter Matthew Baylis explains.
fields.body:
Thank heaven for off-screen uncles. As we saw during the hurried departure of the di Marco family from Albert Square, there's nothing like a fictitious relative when you need to get characters off the screen, fast. Peggy has "Aunt Sal" and Frank his daughter "Claire" for the same reasons. We soap viewers tolerate these tricks - we believe in our Peggys and Franks, but we also understand that they are actors. They get sick, they go on holiday, and sometimes, they get sacked.

The di Marcos' departure had its dodgy elements. A hitherto unheard-of uncle needs help in his restaurant, so the whole family ups sticks. Including Teresa - who'd always fought for independence from her family? Rosa, who presumably owned the house she'd transformed into something resembling an Imperial Palace, is suddenly prepared to leg it with a couple of suitcases? There was plenty that didn't ring true. But few viewers minded. There was, if anything, more sympathy for the programme-makers, trying valiantly to dispose of this singularly unpopular family while retaining an element of drama.

There's a story about two Italian-Americans, having an argument. One shouts at the other, "If you had a restaurant, I wouldn't eat at it!" From the modest outcry that followed the di Marcos' banishment, it would seem that this is how most viewers felt about them. But why?

They were not unconvincing characters. Setting aside the grandparents (whose "foreign" mannerisms would have gone down great in any production of Fiddler On The Roof), the di Marco family was played by skilled professionals. Mark Bannerman was superb as an arrogant lecher, who lacked the brains or the courage to leave the shelter of Mama's apron. In her early days, seducing married men and corrupting innocents, Leila Birch's Teresa was redolent of the poisonous Lucy Ewing in Dallas.

The least convincing di Marco is the one who's staying - Beppe. He seemed far too gentle to have been a vice cop, and it's still hard to list any adjectives that describe his character. Try asking someone in the street. Ten to one they'll say something like, "Handsome. Erm. Small beard."

Looking at Beppe's flaws highlights the problem that dogged the whole family. They had an ambiguity, heightened by the job they did. Soapland has no place for grey areas. Bad things happen to bad people. They also happen to good people, of course, but not for very long. To make this predictable universe work on the screen, you need characters who are relatively stable (even if they are unstable). The writers and the viewers buy into a myth that people aren't particularly complex, that the full range of their feelings and actions can be revealed in a few hours on the TV. And a quick, visible way of revealing characters is to mirror them in their occupation. Thus we have Pauline Fowler, long-suffering drudge and matriarch. What better job than folding pants all day in the launderette? Or Peggy Butcher - tough but fun-loving and gregarious. So she runs the pub. But what attributes spring to mind when we think of Italian restaurants? Fond of pasta, perhaps? Permanently overworked? The job never provided an easy route into understanding the di Marcos' characters.

Another way soaps let us inside their characters is by showing them in interaction with others. It's easy to see what Janine is like because she's installed in the café, dealing shrewishly with a stream of customers in every episode. The same goes for the market traders and everyone who ever pulled pints in the Vic. The most visible jobs tend to be taken by the strongest, most vivid characters.

Confined to their restaurant, the di Marcos could only become involved in Walford life when other characters came over to eat a carbonara. And how often do working-class East End people do that? If any di Marco wanted a night out, a pint in the Vic, a clandestine liaison, then an excuse had to be found as to why they weren't working. Transforming Giuseppe's into a daytime sandwich bar, and sending Teresa onto the market were bold rescue attempts, but they came too late. The viewers had already decided they didn't much care. Beppe has been given a family in a bid to render him real. As a vice cop, always away on shadowy missions, and now running the night-club, he's always inhabited a twilight world. Accordingly, his character is vague - if he's to stay, he has to be given an extra dimension.

Because of their jobs, the di Marcos became a largely self-contained unit. Rosa had her friendship with Irene. Gianni had his love affair with Steve's sister, Jackie. But these were small Peroni compared to the complex spider-webs surrounding Pauline and Peggy. The di Marco most embedded in the Square was teenage Nicky - with her links to Sonia and Martin, members of big-league families. But - since we are not in Neighbours territory - she could hardly stick around without her family.

It's too early to say much about the di Marcos' replacements. With luck, they will be well-drawn, convincingly acted and popular with the audience. But if they try opening a restaurant, it won't be long before they're heading off to their uncle.

fields.headline: Passport control
fields.standfirst: Who's in town and why
fields.trailText: Who's in town and why
fields.body:
Men in tights ... Well, it might be wise to gird your loins as the stentorian figure of top-heavy US wrestler Goldberg grunts and yells his way through customs en route to a three-day British tour plugging the charms of World Championship Wrestling. Which is, of course, an entirely different proposition to the World Wrestling Federation, home of The Rock, et al . GOT THAT? GOOD. Anyway, as you probably surmised, our boy's not afraid of RAISING HIS VOICE, so anyone in Manchester tomorrow, Birmingham on Thursday, or London on Friday would be best advised to keep their ears covered and their heads down. Or, failing that, risk the wrath of a man whose official blurb breathlessly describes how "this muscle mass of intensity has exploded on WCW with incredible force - Disposing of opponents with viper-like swiftness, he strikes with awesome devastation utilizing the Spear and the Jackhammer to lift opponents overhead before crashing them to the mat." Oh, and he also "strongly supports the Make-A-Wish Foundation and other children's organizations". GOT THAT? GOOD.

Sparks will fly ... Which is, sadly enough, our way of saying that Ron and Russell Mael, aka perennially odd synth duo Sparks, are pitching up in the country later this week in time for a one-off gig at the Shepherd's Bush Empire this Friday. In case you were wondering, they're promoting their 18th album, titled, equally tragically, Balls.

Vice squad ... But if you thought that was unfortunate, how about the arrival this Sunday of Phillip Michael Thomas, better - in fact, only - known as Detective Ricardo Tubbs from quintessentially 80s cop opera Miami Vice. Which, predictably, is the reason someone's actually paid for his flight, as he strolls down memory lane in honour of the series' forthcoming transmission on Granada Sky Broadcasting. May saints preserve us.

webTitle: New York's Museum of Modern Art

fields.headline: A Picasso's place is beside the temporary cafe
fields.standfirst: New York's Museum of Modern Art is arranging its contents by theme rather than by period or school - just like Tate Modern. But, says  Jonathan Jones, it's at the expense of the collection
fields.trailText: New York's Museum of Modern Art is arranging its contents by theme rather than by period or school - just like Tate Modern. But, says Jonathan Jones, it's at the expense of the collection.
fields.body:
If you want to see Picasso's 1907 masterpiece Les Demoiselles d'Avignon, pride of the greatest collection of modern art in the world, the Museum of Modern Art in New York, you have to sidle into a strange sin-bin just above the temporary cafe. This is where Picasso's explosive assault on reality has been relegated, like an embarrassing elderly relative, in a rum show called Collection Highlights.

Moma, the institution that is synonymous with the very idea of modern art, is going through a convulsive change. Collection Highlights is one product of that change as the museum undergoes a year-long, three-part rehang which culminates in the autumn with Moma's first full survey of contemporary art since 1960. This promises to be the most dramatic new display in its history, one that abandons its infamous linear narrative of modern art in favour of a year-long series of collage-like shows.

Founded by wealthy Manhattan art lovers in 1929 when Picasso was at best the butt of cartoonists' "three-eyed girlfriend" gags, this museum has championed the modern movements from surrealism to pop, given a home to European artists and artworks in exile - Picasso's Guernica was cared for here throughout the Franco dictatorship - and made modernism distinctively American. Along the way it has acquired the most comprehensive and imposing collection of modern art that is ever likely to be assembled anywhere.

Moma founded its reputation on high-handed certainty. It was revered and feared for the way it determined the history of art. It devised the evolutionary story of modern art as a succession of "isms". Alfred H Barr, director of the museum in the mid-20th century, saw the history of modern art movements as a linear progress toward the supreme goal of abstraction. A rehang in 1993 maintained this story of modern art in which you walked from Monet's lily pond to Cézanne's Mont St Victoire to Picasso's brothel.

But now the museum has had a breakdown. Not that you can blame it. For 30 years academic critics have been deconstructing modernism. And when they pick apart the history of modern art, they attack modern art's most powerful institution. Moma has even been outed as a front for the CIA in the 50s, when its international touring shows of American art were supposedly little more than Cold War propaganda exercises.

The museum has capitulated; it has shoved scores of great paintings into the background to make way for photographs, home movies, outsider art and the cute suburban realist Norman Rockwell. The year-long changing displays collectively entitled Moma 2000 tell a story of pluralism, and the wishy-washy consequences of this are revealed in the names of the sections of the hang: Making Choices, to be followed by Open Ends.

The assumption behind Moma's reshuffle, like the Tate's, appears to be that to continue creating, we have to free ourselves from a burdensome history. Picasso has to be put in his place. Less well-known currents of 20th-century art have to be given more weight. But was the grand narrative of modern art ever so oppressive?

Moma is a monument to the creative value of bigotry. In the middle of the 20th century it set itself up as guardian of an unarguable truth. It claimed to speak for the high tradition of art in our time and demanded new art live up to it. According to the current curatorial consensus, this ought to have been disastrous. Art in New York in the shadow of Moma ought to have shrivelled. But that is not what happened.

In the few rooms at Moma given over to Collection Highlights, you turn a corner and Jackson Pollock's One (No 31, 1950) dances in mid-air, a rapturous, inexhaustible frieze. Pollock painted with Moma's history of modernism before his eyes. He was not intimidated. Art in New York in the 40s, 50s and 60s was more creative than anywhere else in the 20th century except Paris before the first world war. And it was creative because artists had something to sharpen their teeth on.

This is the lesson the collection of the Museum of Modern Art really teaches: that a sense of history is essential to the making of art. The lesson is conveyed in the Collection Highlights room that focuses on 50s New York. Across from the Pollock is a painting that could not be more different, yet could not have existed without it. Jasper Johns's Target with Four Faces (1955) is the work of a young artist who wanted to make an impact in a New York dominated by Pollock's followers in the abstract expressionist school - how better than by doing the opposite of Pollock?

Where Pollock's painting is rangy, splashy, spontaneous, Johns' Target is uptight and laboriously thought out. Johns used a method of painting - encaustic, an ancient wax-based technique - that enabled him to build up his image in dense, static layers. Instead of flowing like Pollock's expressive drips, it is set like wax. The painting includes four macabre cast faces that heighten the chilly surrealism. Under the paint are collaged newspaper stories; you can make out a title from a book-review page entitled "History and Biography".

So different, yet the Pollock and the Johns are similar. They both speak of encoded, inarticulate memory; whatever history and biography may lie concealed in Johns' Target, there is the same sense of secret history in Pollock's art. This is a creative, healthy dialogue of artists. The picture of Moma as modernist oppressor is also undermined by the fact that Alfred H Barr, high priest of -isms, bought three of Johns' postmodern paintings for the museum, including Target, from his first solo exhibition at the Castelli gallery in 1958. He also wanted to buy Flag (1954-5), but was afraid the trustees would see it as anti-American, so he got the architect Philip Johnson to buy it and present it to Moma later as a gift.

The deficiencies of the new, softer history of modern art are obvious when you go from this room to the version of 50s Manhattan as presented in the new displays. Here we are told that art in 50s New York was wildly divergent in approach. Divergent in quality, too, it appears. Second-rate abstract expressionists, realists, the idiosyncratic Louise Bourgeois and the almost-pop Larry Rivers are hung together in a display that completely fails to capture the excitement of the period. What is missing right through the new-look Moma is a sense of urgency. Some of the displays are better than others, but always you feel infra-academic games are being played and this great collection is not being shown off.

A comparison with Tate Modern is hard to avoid. The Tate has done a similar display with far more style, perhaps because it has fewer inhibi tions; the Tate owns about one fifth of the great art Moma does so it can afford to take risks. Conversely, where Moma 2000 does score is in being more extensive than the Tate. A section called Walker Evans and Co, treats the documentary photographer of the 30s as a hidden influence on artists from Robert Rauschenberg to Sherrie Levine and places photography at the heart of American art. It is a major exhibition in itself and juxtaposes such gems as Robert Frank's 50s photographs of the American heartland and Edward Hopper's painting of a sad usherette in a Manhattan movie theatre. A display dedicated to Alfred Jarry and the College of Pataphysics is astonishing, and the museum's stores have been ransacked for treasures such as an Angus Calder model of the Universe and what feels like the entire early work of Louise Bourgeois. But this very scholarly thoroughness - in contrast to Tate Modern's infectious populism - adds to the sense of a slightly jaded exercise by curators whose main aim is to impress their colleagues. As for the rest of us, we can go see the Collection Highlights.

The fact is that for most of us, modern art is still provocative. Picasso is still provocative. Pollock is still provocative, and so are the contemporary artists Moma will be showing in depth in September, including Rachel Whiteread, Robert Gober and Charles Ray. The oldest museum of modern art in the world naturally wants to reinvent itself so it will influence the art of the 21st century as decisively as it did the 20th. The museum is already preparing for a massive building project that will almost double its exhibition space. It will close its doors for much of the process, which will be complete in 2004-5. Doubtless when it reopens its current hesitancy will give way to the customary hectoring manner. Meanwhile the home of modern art appears to be London.

Less well-known currents of 20th-century art have to be given more weight. But was the grand narrative of modern art ever so oppressive? Moma is a monument to the creative value of bigotry. In the middle of the 20th century it set itself up as guardian of an unarguable truth. It claimed to speak for the high tradition of art in our time and demanded new art live up to it. According to the current curatorial consensus, this ought to have been disastrous. Art in New York in the shadow of Moma ought to have shrivelled. But that is not what happened. In the few rooms at Moma given over to Collection Highlights, you turn a corner and Jackson Pollock's One (No 31, 1950) dances in mid-air, a rapturous, inexhaustible frieze. Pollock painted with Moma's history of modernism before his eyes. He was not intimidated. Art in New York in the 40s, 50s and 60s was more creative than anywhere else in the 20th century except Paris before the first world war. And it was creative because artists had something to sharpen their teeth on. This is the lesson the collection of the Museum of Modern Art really teaches: that a sense of history is essential to the making of art. The lesson is conveyed in the Collection Highlights room that focuses on 50s New York. Across from the Pollock is a painting that could not be more different, yet could not have existed without it. Jasper Johns's Target with Four Faces (1955) is the work of a young artist who wanted to make an impact in a New York dominated by Pollock's followers in the abstract expressionist school - how better than by doing the opposite of Pollock? Where Pollock's painting is rangy, splashy, spontaneous, Johns' Target is uptight and laboriously thought out. Johns used a method of painting - encaustic, an ancient wax-based technique - that enabled him to build up his image in dense, static layers. Instead of flowing like Pollock's expressive drips, it is set like wax. The painting includes four macabre cast faces that heighten the chilly surrealism. Under the paint are collaged newspaper stories; you can make out a title from a book-review page entitled "History and Biography". So different, yet the Pollock and the Johns are similar. They both speak of encoded, inarticulate memory; whatever history and biography may lie concealed in Johns' Target, there is the same sense of secret history in Pollock's art. This is a creative, healthy dialogue of artists. The picture of Moma as modernist oppressor is also undermined by the fact that Alfred H Barr, high priest of -isms, bought three of Johns' postmodern paintings for the museum, including Target, from his first solo exhibition at the Castelli gallery in 1958. He also wanted to buy Flag (1954-5), but was afraid the trustees would see it as anti-American, so he got the architect Philip Johnson to buy it and present it to Moma later as a gift. The deficiencies of the new, softer history of modern art are obvious when you go from this room to the version of 50s Manhattan as presented in the new displays. Here we are told that art in 50s New York was wildly divergent in approach. Divergent in quality, too, it appears. Second-rate abstract expressionists, realists, the idiosyncratic Louise Bourgeois and the almost-pop Larry Rivers are hung together in a display that completely fails to capture the excitement of the period. What is missing right through the new-look Moma is a sense of urgency. Some of the displays are better than others, but always you feel infra-academic games are being played and this great collection is not being shown off. A comparison with Tate Modern is hard to avoid. The Tate has done a similar display with far more style, perhaps because it has fewer inhibi tions; the Tate owns about one fifth of the great art Moma does so it can afford to take risks. Conversely, where Moma 2000 does score is in being more extensive than the Tate. A section called Walker Evans and Co, treats the documentary photographer of the 30s as a hidden influence on artists from Robert Rauschenberg to Sherrie Levine and places photography at the heart of American art. It is a major exhibition in itself and juxtaposes such gems as Robert Frank's 50s photographs of the American heartland and Edward Hopper's painting of a sad usherette in a Manhattan movie theatre. A display dedicated to Alfred Jarry and the College of Pataphysics is astonishing, and the museum's stores have been ransacked for treasures such as an Angus Calder model of the Universe and what feels like the entire early work of Louise Bourgeois. But this very scholarly thoroughness - in contrast to Tate Modern's infectious populism - adds to the sense of a slightly jaded exercise by curators whose main aim is to impress their colleagues. As for the rest of us, we can go see the Collection Highlights. The fact is that for most of us, modern art is still provocative. Picasso is still provocative. Pollock is still provocative, and so are the contemporary artists Moma will be showing in depth in September, including Rachel Whiteread, Robert Gober and Charles Ray. The oldest museum of modern art in the world naturally wants to reinvent itself so it will influence the art of the 21st century as decisively as it did the 20th. The museum is already preparing for a massive building project that will almost double its exhibition space. It will close its doors for much of the process, which will be complete in 2004-5. Doubtless when it reopens its current hesitancy will give way to the customary hectoring manner. Meanwhile the home of modern art appears to be London.

fields.headline: Side lines
fields.body:
Alas, gentle reader, we are nearing summer's end and the season of mists and mellow fruitfulness is almost upon us. As Sidelines hangs up her diaphanous shift dress and reaches for the sensible slacks, she ponders her most memorable summer moments. The cornfield at dawn? The badger sett at dusk? The Magnum advert?

What a relief, then, that as the autumn chill sets in across the country, temperatures will be rising elsewhere. The Ann Summers chain is set to open its first Middle Eastern outlet in Dubai next month, followed by a dozen others across the region, including one in the holy city of Mecca. Palpitations at the arrival of mango-flavoured massage oil are bound to ensue, though whether on the grounds of religion or refinement, it remains to be seen. Any excuse not to end up with a comedy gift of sequined nipple tassles, eh ladies?

On the other hand, perhaps that's just what Liz Hurley's after. Despite allegedly describing her sex life with Hugh Grant as "less than adequate", Hurley was snapped enjoying a holiday clinch in Sardinia with her recent ex. Isn't it a marvel? While most of us are reaching for the breadknife during the first few months following a break-up, the pair are exhibiting an enviable maturity. Trading childish insults with friends, drinking buckets of gin and listening to Nanci Griffith's Anyone Can Be Somebody's Fool on a loop may seem like a good idea at the time, but it won't get you in the papers.

fields.headline: 'Cheer up, love. It might never happen!'
fields.standfirst: Only it does, all the time. And it's worse in summer.  Julie Myerson on harassment in the street
fields.trailText: Only it does, all the time. And it's worse in summer.  Julie Myerson on harassment in the street.
fields.body:
Yesterday morning, a sixtysomething man approached me outside Superdrug on Clapham High Street. Wide-eyed, unshaven, clean but slightly shabby, he tottered towards me brandishing a scrap of paper. Why? I didn't wait to find out. No sooner had he made eye contact than I muttered a quick "No!" and moved snappily out of his path. It was only as I walked away, relaxed, took stock, that I realised I'd almost certainly just rebuffed a tired, slightly confused old man, asking for directions on a busy London street.

Sadly, in the past few years I've lost my urban spontaneity and joy. Out there these days, I'm tense, careful and mistrustful. It wasn't always this way. I used to walk about like a puppy in the sunshine, enjoying the air, the buzz of being alive and out in the city. So what's changed? Just the tawdry fact that I can no longer walk alone down these south London streets without being harassed by men.

Young men, old men, sober, drunk, clean, filthy, black, white, in cars, vans, lorries or out of them. Almost every day, at any time of day, I am yelled at, leered at, snarled at, lip-smacked at. I have had my bottom pinched, my clothes grabbed - even, on one occasion, my breast squeezed.

Some do it menacingly, fixing me with their eyes and muttering graphic, sexually suggestive things. Others - just as oppressive if not so obviously intimidating - verbally assess my hair, clothes, demeanour. "Hello, love ... Smile, my darling! ... Love the hat!" If I don't respond, they raise the volume: "Hey, Blondie, I'm talking to you!"

If challenged (not that I've ever dared), this type would act innocent, swear they meant no harm. But they know exactly what they mean. "Hello, love, don't imagine you can walk down this street in peace: you're up for grabs, you're mine to fiddle with, this space is not yours but mine to step into as often as I want. You're here for my amusement, sunshine."

Constant low-level harassment of this sort ensures I finish the 10-minute walk to my workplace feeling angry, hostile, flushed. I resent this. It's not how I want to feel or how I want to live. Why should I start each day in combat mode, adrenaline flowing, just to guard my right to be me?

But it's not just the men on the pavement or up ladders. Most sinister of all, perhaps, are the ones in their cars - not lorries but Fords and Astras and Volvos. These are the sneaky cowards who, snug and slimy in their tin boxes and bored attraffic lights, catch your eye and roll theirs, jiggle their eyebrows at you, make thrusting movements with their tongues.

These men - and we're talking men in suits, white-collar workers - probably also like to think they are good sorts. They like to have a laugh, go down the pub, watch the game on TV, then go home to wives or girlfriends. If someone made a sexually suggestive comment to their woman, they'd be outraged. But the stranger's fair game. Safely anonymous in their cars, they leer and taunt like execs at a peep show. And why not? What rap will they have to take? Road rape? Don't be silly. It's just something to do when you're stuck on red.

So what are they looking at? An averagely OK-looking, 40-year-old mother of three. Yes, tallish, blondish, fashionably dressed, but I don't think looks come into it that much. I'm there. When I complain to my (wholly sympathetic) partner, he points out that I (1) look happy, (2) do my hair and make-up every morning, (3) tend not to travel in the rush hour, so am often on the streets when few other groomed working women are.

I point out that I mostly wear jeans and am nothing like as young and cute and fresh-looking as I was in my 20s when I seemed more or less to walk along in peace. So why me? Why now? Why so much?

The answer is, I can't possibly be the only one. Plenty of women living in cities are putting up with this sort of hassle just as I do, day in, day out. Talking to friends, we reckon only two things really stop you getting hassled: driving everywhere or walking around with kids, especially in pushchairs. Motherhood still seems to equal sexual anonymity - though it has to be said that the only time I ever received a serious proposition from a stranger was when I was eight months gone with my third.

But my kids are at school all day and I don't want to be forced into a car. Getting a dog seemed a good idea and certainly in winter, with my Border collie in tow, I became less a woman, more a dog walker - someone with a purpose rather than a helpless floozy flaunting her sex. In winter, with my long coat, hat and sunglasses, dog and I got minimal hassle. I was hopeful. Too hopeful, it seems. Now, in August, minus the coat, "Give us a stroke, darling" comes the wretched cry from lorries.

The boy who grabbed my breast was a jaunty 15 or 16-year-old - well-dressed, good-looking, Walkman on his head, hands hanging loose by his side. It was a sunny May morning when our paths crossed. He made me jump and hurt my breast. By the time I got over the shock and realised I'd been assaulted, he'd disappeared.

I called the police who listened sympathetically while admitting there wasn't much they could do. That night, a policewoman phoned me at home to take "further details".

"It's funny," she said, "but I had the same thing happen recently, in the same area - could be the same lad."

"Did you catch him?" I asked.

"I couldn't report it."

"Why not?" I said, surprised.

She lowered her voice. "I'd have been teased at the station. You know. Anything to do with breasts. They'd have thought it was funny."

"What? Your fellow officers?"

"Don't tell anyone I told you that." At the time I didn't, but I'm telling you now because her admission was sad, ridiculous, terrifying, amazing but also because it seems to me it's a dreary clue as to why she, I and to some extent all of usare grimly, quietly tolerating the intolerable.

So if you're a man and you think this piece is funny or silly or a fuss about nothing, think again. Imagine you're in a hurry, on your way somewhere, personal stuff on your mind, and I stop you on the street and ask politely where the nearest Superdrug is. Or imagine that I don't. Imagine I start to ask you that question and then scan your body with my eyes and demand to know what colour your underpants are. Or pinch your nipple. Or grope your testicles. Feeling a little tense now, are you? Oh come on, where's your sense of humour? It was only a bit of fun.
