fields.headline: Glasgow galleries crave renaissance
fields.standfirst:
Heritage: City lacks cash to preserve renowned collection

Museums in crisis
Local museums facing a slow death by a thousand budget cuts
New Walk Museum, Leicester
Norton Priory
fields.trailText: In store rooms across the city, the careful touch of the Renaissance masters is flaking. Cracks appear on 15th century canvas, and first aid maintenance is the best that can be applied. Alongside lie other works, gradually deteriorating.
fields.body:
In store rooms across the city, the careful touch of the Renaissance masters is flaking. Cracks appear on 15th century canvas, and first aid maintenance is the best that can be applied. Alongside lie other works, gradually deteriorating.

No one is certain of the extent of the malaise. Only one point is irrefutable: it cannot continue like this.

The wealth that once made Glasgow the second city of the empire has slipped away. Its legacy, however, remains: one of the great city collections of Europe, with eight main museums and galleries bulging with 1.5m objects. But from Old Masters to rusting armour the problem is constant: how to preserve and utilise the collection when inadequate funding has brought it to crisis point.

"Of all the cities in Europe, Glasgow was the one that led the way in changing its international standing and perception through tourism based on museums," said Neil McGregor, director of the National Gallery in London. "If Glasgow is in crisis now, what does this bode for the rest of Britain's municipal museums - and tourism?"

Polly Smith, the city's senior conservator, admits she has no idea what state many of the 3,500 canvases are in. The results of a survey now under way may make uncomfortable reading. Ms Smith is Glasgow's only fine art conservator, and she does what she euphemistically calls "prioritising". A blunter phrase is fire-fighting.

Renaissance works by Montagna, Pessellino and Dossi are deteriorating. It takes weeks, sometimes months, to conserve a painting. The decay of other paintings comes to light from time to time. When the Tate in London asked to borrow three paintings by William Blake, staff were shocked by their condition.

"With a reduced staff, the quantity of work we carry out has to be reduced," said Ms Smith. "I can prioritise and save important paintings, with first aid treatment, from deteriorating irrevocably. But say if a painting is on display with a discoloured varnish, the public is not seeing what the artist intended.

"There are also problems with maintenance. With more resources we could properly assess and deal with the needs of the collection."

The problem does not lie merely with conservation. A report by city councillors on council museums has shown that Glasgow spends only 10% of what it should on museum education; staffing levels are less than half those in national museums; and curatorial work has been cut to the bone.

There is little appetite for blaming the council, however. With huge problems in housing, education and social work to be tackled, it is no surprise that the museum budget is squeezed.

"If we go on for another couple of years like this, we will be in very grave danger of losing some of the collection," said John Lynch, vice convenor of Glasgow's culture and leisure committee.

The councillors' report can see only three ways out of problem: to ask the Scottish executive for an extra £2.2m; to transfer some museums - notably the Burrell collection, jewel in the city's year of culture crown - to a trust, although this would still leave a big hole in funding; or to seek national help, developing a partnership between central and local government.

"It's something that has to be addressed imminently," said Chris Mason, the councillor who chaired the report group.

In 1986, when Liverpool reached the depths of its troubles and Margaret Thatcher abolished Merseyside council, the new Liverpool city council gave its museums up to national control, and they have thrived. Liverpool has a collection on a par with Glasgow's, but it has 40 conservators compared with Glasgow's 13. The National Museums and Galleries on Merseyside is about to spend £34m improving three museums; Glasgow's entire budget for the year is £16m.

But this is unlikely to be the solution for Glasgow. "It would be washing our hands of the situation," said Mr Lynch. "Glaswegians feel an affinity with their art collection; there is little to be gained from breaking that bond. What we want to do is encourage the socially excluded to use the museums by making them aware of their ownership."

The Scottish executive, too, has no desire to take responsibility for Glasgow's problems.

Ministers are aware of the crisis, but money will not flow in immediately. The national cultural strategy was published last week, and an audit of all Scotland's museums has been ordered.

The city council has requested an urgent meeting with the Scottish executive.

Dr McGregor said: "In Germany, France and Italy, museums are funded by arrangements between local and national governments. Perhaps that is the model for Glasgow.

"What we have to realise, though, is that we cannot continue to be so blasé with our national heritage. We need to decide now how we are going to maintain it - and how we are going to pay for it."

fields.headline: 'Killer mouse' warning on Arctic islands
fields.trailText: A tiny field mouse, so tough it is one of only four land mammals that can survive the cold of the high Arctic, has struck fear into the remote Norwegian archipelago of Svalbard.
fields.body:
A tiny field mouse, so tough it is one of only four land mammals that can survive the cold of the high Arctic, has struck fear into the remote Norwegian archipelago of Svalbard.

Microtus epiroticus, which lives alongside polar bears, reindeer and arctic foxes, has been dubbed the "killer mouse" because of tiny tapeworm larvae it carries that are harmless to its host but kill humans by causing liver cysts.

Two scientists who were studying the arctic fox have tested positive for the presence of the larvae. If the larvae develop into adult tapeworms, they could prove fatal.

So alarmed is Lasse Loennum, who directs university studies on Spitsbergen, the largest of the Svalbard islands, that he is writing to 100 former students who took part in a research study on the mouse, urging them to have similar blood tests.

fields.headline: Geoffrey Page
fields.standfirst: Fighter ace who received pioneering plastic surgery
fields.trailText: When the phoney war turned real in May 1940 with the German invasion of the low countries and France, the ambition of Geoffrey Page, who has died aged 80, to move from being a flying instructor to a frontline RAF fighter pilot was at last granted and he was posted to Fighter Command's 56 Squadron, which flew Hawker Hurricanes.
fields.body:
When the phoney war turned real in May 1940 with the German invasion of the low countries and France, the ambition of Geoffrey Page, who has died aged 80, to move from being a flying instructor to a frontline RAF fighter pilot was at last granted and he was posted to Fighter Command's 56 Squadron, which flew Hawker Hurricanes.

Page was soon in the thick of the dogfights over south-east England. But in an attack on a bomber formation, a German round hit the forward fuel tank, which engulfed the cockpit in burning petrol. Despite serious burns to his face and hands, Page parachuted into the sea.

Two years of great pain and complex operations, supervised by the pioneering plastic surgeon Sir Archibald McIndoe, followed. From hospital at East Grinstead, Page suffered the twin agonies of pain and frustration as Spitfires passed on their way to attack targets in France. He described this vividly in his autobiography, Tale of a Guinea Pig (re-published in 1999 as Shot Down in Flames).

Page became a founder-member and first chairman of the Guinea Pig Club, a group of McIndoe's wartime patients whose life president was the surgeon himself. But his sole concern during two years of treatment was to confound those who said he would never fly a fighter again. Eventually he talked his way back into combat, determined to shoot down an enemy plane for every one of his 15 major operations. He made no bones about his feelings: "I enjoy killing," he wrote to a friend before he was injured.

Passionate about flying from boyhood, Page had been advised by his uncle, the aircraft manufacturer Sir Frederick Handley-Page, to study aeronautical engineering rather than become a pilot. On leaving Dean Close school in Cheltenham, he dutifully went to Imperial College, London, where he was too busy proving himself an exceptional pilot in the university air squadron to pass his examinations.

Called up with the RAF reserves in 1939, he took advanced flying training at the RAF college at Cranwell. It was because he did so well that he was earmarked as a flying instructor - to his own desperate disappointment. Then came combat.

Singlemindedly vengeful on his return from surgery, Page was allowed to fly his Spitfire on marauding missions over occupied France, after which he switched to a North American Mustang fighter with its far greater range. In Mustangs he shot down five German planes over central France. He won the DFC in 1943, and a second when his tally of enemy aircraft shot down reached 10.

After D-Day, Page, by then a squadron leader and commanding 122 squadron, was shot in the leg. But he returned quickly to combat missions and, while providing air support for the disastrous assault at Arnhem, in the summer of 1944, he shot down his last plane, a Messerschmitt Me-109. By that time he had passed his target tally of 15, but a few days later he was finally grounded when he crash-landed and fractured his back. Post-war another 15 operations were to follow.

He went to America to boost Anglo-American relations by lecturing in 1945. While there he met the English actor Nigel Bruce (Dr Watson in several Sherlock Holmes films), who was so impressed by Page's fortitude that he persuaded his daughter Pauline to become his pen-friend. They married in 1946, and she and their two sons and one daughter survive him.

On demobilisation he continued his work with the Guinea Pig Club, started the Battle of Britain Trust and became a test pilot. When he finally gave up flying he worked for international aviation organisations.

 Alan Geoffrey Page, pilot, born May 16, 1920; died August 3, 2000

fields.headline: Tatiana Riabouchinska
fields.standfirst: Exceptional ballerina who escaped the Russian revolution and was described as 'the most unusual dancer of her generation'
fields.trailText: Tatiana Riabouchinska, who has died aged 83, will be remembered as one of the three "baby ballerinas" whose youth and exceptional artistry did so much to establish and ensure the success of the Ballet Russe de Monte Carlo, the company which, after the death of its founder Sergei Diaghilev, kept the art of ballet alive throughout the 1930s and beyond.
fields.body:
Tatiana Riabouchinska, who has died aged 83, will be remembered as one of the three "baby ballerinas" whose youth and exceptional artistry did so much to establish and ensure the success of the Ballet Russe de Monte Carlo, the company which, after the death of its founder Sergei Diaghilev, kept the art of ballet alive throughout the 1930s and beyond.

The "baby ballerinas" - the others were Irina Baronova and Tamara Toumanova - were émigré Russians discovered by George Balanchine when he was helping to form the company. All three came from the Paris studios of those great teachers, all former ballerinas of the Imperial Russian Ballet, whose teaching formed generations of the best dancers in Europe. Baronova and Toumanova, the youngest, were pupils of Olga Preobrajenska, but Riabouchinska was a pupil of Mathilde Kschessinska, former ballerina assoluta and mistress of the Tsarevich Nikolai, later Tsar Nikolai II.

Tatiana's father was banker to the Tsar and therefore not spared during the Russian revolution. The whole family was put under house arrest and tied up while the house was ransacked. They all expected to be shot. However, their own servants released them and helped the mother and four children to escape. They left Russia via a route through the Caucasus, arriving eventually in the south of France and thence to Paris.

Tatiana's first teacher in Paris was Alexander Volinine, Bolshoi trained, one time partner of Anna Pavlova, and a teacher famous for his ability to develop elevation. She then went to Kschessinska, an old friend of her family from Tsarist days. At 14 she was chosen by Nikita Baileff to join his fashionable Russian variety show, the Chauve Souris, and appeared as Diana the Huntress in a costume created by Schiaparelli. Balanchine saw her in this and signed her for Monte Carlo.

In the company's first season of 1932, she created the role of the Child in Leonide Max Massine's Jeu d'enfants, created roles in Balanchine's Concurrence and Le Bourgeois Gentilhomme, and danced the role of the Mistress of Ceremonies in his lovely and haunting Cotillon.

At the very beginning of her career, Riabouchinska inspired first Balanchine and then Massine. She created roles in the first three of Massine's famous (at that time controversial) "symphonic" ballets: Frivolity in Les Presages (Tchaikovsky's Fifth), the third and fourth movements in Choreartium (Brahms' Fourth), both 1933, and Reverie in Symphonie Fantastique (Berlioz) 1936. She also danced an enormous number of roles in the Ballet Russe repertoire and when Fokine joined the company between 1937 and 1939, he made the roles of the Golden Cockerel in Le Coq d'or, the title role in Cendrillon, and the Florentine Beauty in Paganini especially for her.

Working with Fokine she had the opportunity to be coached by the choreographer himself in Les Sylphides and Le Spectre de la Rose. Her dancing of the Prelude in Les Sylphides became legendary, and she was to retain this role throughout her career. Her lightness, her soft soaring jump, her exquisite footwork, combined with her innate musicality, lifted the simple dance to a new, utterly poetic plane.

Riabouchinska created many roles in ballets by David Lichine, the dancer and choreographer whom she married in 1943 - among them Le Pavillon (1936); La Creation, for Les Ballets des Champs-Elysees (1948); and, perhaps happiest and most charming of them all, the Romantic Girl in Graduation Ball (1940). With Lichine she made guest appearances with many companies after they left the Ballet Russe and, thanks to Anton Dolin, Riabouchinska danced in London with the Festival Ballet in the early 1950s. Thus a younger generation was able to appreciate her rare quality.

In retirement, the Lichines devoted their energies to their dance academy in Beverly Hills and to founding several small companies. Alas, Riabouchinska's dream of establishing a permanent company in Los Angeles was never realised - sponsorship simply was not forthcoming.

Described as "the most unusual dancer of her generation", Riabouchinska won plaudits from tthe most distinguished critics of the day. The Guardian's James Monahan, who witnessed most of her career, early described her speed and quick footwork as "an embodied scherzo".

Let the American critic and poet Edwin Denby have the last word: "Her naturalness in action comes from the fact that she shows you so clearly the sustaining impetus, the dance impulse which carries her lightly through from beginning to end. Because the impetus is exactly right she strikes you as dancing her whole number on an impulse, spontaneously for the joy of it."

I saw Riabouchinska only towards the end of her career, but that quality of joy is the one I recognised and the one which stays with me.

 Tatiana Riabouchinska born May 23, 1917; died August 24, 2000

fields.headline: Peace claim bombs
fields.trailText: I agree with Patrick Magee (Brighton bomber says he started peace process, August 24): the role of both republican and loyalist terrorists in creating the peace process has been vastly underestimated.
fields.body:
I agree with Patrick Magee (Brighton bomber says he started peace process, August 24): the role of both republican and loyalist terrorists in creating the peace process has been vastly underestimated. Without their 25 years' bombing and shooting, there would indeed be no peace process, just plain boring peace. Thank goodness for the IRA.
Gautam Borooah
Berkeley, USA

 Were Richard Branson to spend more time in this country (Letters, August 28), then English company law would ensure the public were aware of the remuneration he received from the companies he controls and any personal share dealings in those companies. To look on the bright side, maybe he could be persuaded to spend the rest of the year abroad as well.
Jim Cattran
Bristol

 Instead of creating "2,500 new millionaires", the People's lottery should award maximum prizes of £100,000 to more people. What a spread of wealth and happiness this would bring. Many families would be lifted out of poverty.
Norman Wigg
West Molesey, Surrey

 Surely there is a flaw in the People's Lottery bid: the notion of paying an extra £1 for an extra number and thence a guaranteed £1,000,000 for six numbers. This would be unsustainable if the numbers 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6 occurred, as 10,000 people choose these every week. Can any business "guarantee" paying out £10bn?
Fraser McIntosh
Edinburgh

 As with your correspondent (Letters, August 28), I regularly saw the sign "horse-meat for human consumption" in Church Street, Preston, in my childhood. On account of the medical terminologies of that place and time, I long believed horse-meat was a cure for tuberculosis.
Ian Flintoff
London

webTitle: Leader: August is the silly season

fields.headline: Seasonal silliness
fields.standfirst: August is always the same
fields.trailText: The American government is planning to impose a tax of the equivalent of 5p on every email; Posh Spice went into a Woolworth store in Oldham; Tara Palmer-Tompkinson was spotted reading a book; and giant crop circles were discovered in a wheat field in Wiltshire. These stories have nothing in common except that they hit the media in the month of August, when the absence of "real" news creates a vacuum into which all sorts of ephemera are sucked.
fields.body:
The American government is planning to impose a tax of the equivalent of 5p on every email; Posh Spice went into a Woolworth store in Oldham; Tara Palmer-Tompkinson was spotted reading a book; and giant crop circles were discovered in a wheat field in Wiltshire. These stories have nothing in common except that they hit the media in the month of August, when the absence of "real" news creates a vacuum into which all sorts of ephemera are sucked. The creators of Channel Four's Big Brother must be delighted with their decision to run the series in the summer - it enabled a bunch of obscure people to fill the spaces in the newspapers normally occupied by news.

The Silly Season, which can be traced back at least to 1861, is one of the more enduring legacies of the Victorian era. It may now be about to enter a more serious phase. The BBC has started recording the phenomenon. The corporation's website has been inviting people to submit their favourite silly stories so that a top 10 chart can be compiled each week - candidates include the story in the Sun about Baldrick the snow-white magpie which learned to scare off cats with its impression of a dog (an experience which can now be shared through a premium rate phone call). Curiously, the BBC itself does not seem to feature in its own silly season charts. But that did not stop a Daily Telegraph columnist yesterday from wondering whether the BBC's decision to lead its own news bulletin with its plans to delay its Nine O'Clock news bulletin by an hour was something to do with August. Who knows? The distinction between reality and fiction gets ever more blurred.

The story about taxing emails resurfaced this August but has been doing the rounds for years. It is not true - but the more one hears it, the more it sounds like an idea whose season has come. Good job Gordon Brown has been on holiday in August.

fields.headline: Diary
fields.trailText: A remarkable letter is doing the rounds, a copy of an ancient memo sent by Roger Lyons, now the highly popular general secretary of the MSF union. Marked "private and confidential", the letter to his boss Clive Jenkins was written by a young Roger in 1967, when he was a regional officer in Liverpool for the Asset union, a forerunner of the MSF.
fields.body:
A remarkable letter is doing the rounds, a copy of an ancient memo sent by Roger Lyons, now the highly popular general secretary of the MSF union. Marked "private and confidential", the letter to his boss Clive Jenkins was written by a young Roger in 1967, when he was a regional officer in Liverpool for the Asset union, a forerunner of the MSF.

"Though I obtain excellent job satisfaction," writes Roger, "I do not find the Liverpool area very congenial." Oh dear. He then whinges about how much work he was doing but soon returns to the Liverpool motif: "I am living in an area well-known for its insularity and parochial outlook, and this I have found in abundance." But what about the famous Scouse wit? "Compared with London, I must now conclude that Liverpool is depressing from a political, cultural and social point of view". But Roger, this was Liverpool in the Swinging Sixties: the Beatles ... the Cavern Club ... Cilla Black ... hmmm. "I now know I cannot survive in Liverpool," is Roger's plaintive cry. Thankfully he stuck with it, or the union movement would have been so much the richer.

Good news - there's still time to register for the highlight of this or any other year: the Third International Yak Congress in Lhasa, starting on September 4. "The aim of the meeting is to provide a forum for delegates from yak-raising and non-yak-raising countries to explore multi-disciplinary aspects and approaches to sustainable yak production," according to the organisers. "It is the third time that the conference has been held in China, the most important yak-rearing country." Any readers attending should get in touch with a full report.

For those of you who can't make it to Lhasa (which is in Chinese-occupied Tibet after all, and so may be boycotted by pro-Tibetan yak-fanciers), there are plenty of attractions a little closer to home. "If you should ever find yourself in the Norwegian town of Bergen on Good Friday," writes Ian Reeve, "you will find that all that is open is the Leprosy Museum." Indeed.

"And let's not forget the Sala family's very impressive Museum of Sausages in the Catalonian village of Castellfollit," says Tony Henderson of South Bank University in London. But not all our readers spend all their time in places like the Museum of Sausages or the (by now) famous Pencil Museum of Keswick. Some visit the exciting new and highly fashionable Colette store on Rue Saint-Honore in Paris. "A place where fashion, design, art, photography and music, as well as new technological breakthroughs can interact," according to the shop's website, "a sober, ever-changing, light-filled space." Sober indeed: a feature of the store is "un water-bar offre des eaux venues du monde". Waters from around the world! Mmmm ... water.

Those looking for news of the Diary Summer Roadshow 2000 "Live in Leeds" (sponsored by Rolls-Royce and Gerald Kaufman) will have to wait until tomorrow. The photos are still being developed, and the bail conditions finalised after the fracas outside the West Yorkshire Playhouse.

But speaking of that Titan of parliament, Gerald Kaufman Month is sadly drawing to a close. So it is time to announce the winner of our latest competition, where readers had to complete the sentence "I love Gerald Kaufman because ..." in 12 words or less. First prize, a magnificent Billy the Bass singing fish (the one that delights Mr Tony Blair so much that he keeps it in his office at No 10) goes to Godfrey Gudgeon of Brixton. Godfrey's winning entry was: "I love Gerald Kaufman because of his thick, rich curly hair, stain free reputation and generous spirit." And a special mention to Luke Jacks of Hull, for his runner-up entry: "I love Gerald Kaufman because of his taste: three parts oil to five of vinegar."
fields.bodyText: A remarkable letter is doing the rounds, a copy of an ancient memo sent by Roger Lyons, now the highly popular general secretary of the MSF union. Marked "private and confidential", the letter to his boss Clive Jenkins was written by a young Roger in 1967, when he was a regional officer in Liverpool for the Asset union, a forerunner of the MSF. "Though I obtain excellent job satisfaction," writes Roger, "I do not find the Liverpool area very congenial." Oh dear. He then whinges about how much work he was doing but soon returns to the Liverpool motif: "I am living in an area well-known for its insularity and parochial outlook, and this I have found in abundance." But what about the famous Scouse wit? "Compared with London, I must now conclude that Liverpool is depressing from a political, cultural and social point of view". But Roger, this was Liverpool in the Swinging Sixties: the Beatles ... the Cavern Club ... Cilla Black ... hmmm. "I now know I cannot survive in Liverpool," is Roger's plaintive cry. Thankfully he stuck with it, or the union movement would have been so much the richer. Good news - there's still time to register for the highlight of this or any other year: the Third International Yak Congress in Lhasa, starting on September 4. "The aim of the meeting is to provide a forum for delegates from yak-raising and non-yak-raising countries to explore multi-disciplinary aspects and approaches to sustainable yak production," according to the organisers. "It is the third time that the conference has been held in China, the most important yak-rearing country." Any readers attending should get in touch with a full report. For those of you who can't make it to Lhasa (which is in Chinese-occupied Tibet after all, and so may be boycotted by pro-Tibetan yak-fanciers), there are plenty of attractions a little closer to home. "If you should ever find yourself in the Norwegian town of Bergen on Good Friday," writes Ian Reeve, "you will find that all that is open is the Leprosy Museum." Indeed. "And let's not forget the Sala family's very impressive Museum of Sausages in the Catalonian village of Castellfollit," says Tony Henderson of South Bank University in London. But not all our readers spend all their time in places like the Museum of Sausages or the (by now) famous Pencil Museum of Keswick. Some visit the exciting new and highly fashionable Colette store on Rue Saint-Honore in Paris. "A place where fashion, design, art, photography and music, as well as new technological breakthroughs can interact," according to the shop's website, "a sober, ever-changing, light-filled space." Sober indeed: a feature of the store is "un water-bar offre des eaux venues du monde". Waters from around the world! Mmmm ... water. Those looking for news of the Diary Summer Roadshow 2000 "Live in Leeds" (sponsored by Rolls-Royce and Gerald Kaufman) will have to wait until tomorrow. The photos are still being developed, and the bail conditions finalised after the fracas outside the West Yorkshire Playhouse. But speaking of that Titan of parliament, Gerald Kaufman Month is sadly drawing to a close. So it is time to announce the winner of our latest competition, where readers had to complete the sentence "I love Gerald Kaufman because ..." in 12 words or less. First prize, a magnificent Billy the Bass singing fish (the one that delights Mr Tony Blair so much that he keeps it in his office at No 10) goes to Godfrey Gudgeon of Brixton. Godfrey's winning entry was: "I love Gerald Kaufman because of his thick, rich curly hair, stain free reputation and generous spirit." And a special mention to Luke Jacks of Hull, for his runner-up entry: "I love Gerald Kaufman because of his taste: three parts oil to five of vinegar."

fields.headline: Too loyal to republicans
fields.trailText: Roy Greenslade (Mad Dog has them foaming, Media, August 28) criticises other columnists for lack of historical context, then shows his own adeptness.
fields.body:
Roy Greenslade (Mad Dog has them foaming, Media, August 28) criticises other columnists for lack of historical context, then shows his own adeptness. He repeats the assertion the Provisional IRA only arose in response to Protestant attacks - a myth demolished by Malachai O' Docherty's The Trouble With Guns - and makes the bizarre statement on IRA drug rackets that "the RUC have tried and failed to make this claim stick" - disproved by a rudimentary grasp of policing. Why is it that republican violence can always be explained by reference to community feeling, tradition, or repression, but loyalist violence is always the result of plain thuggery?
Jon Moran
Liverpool John Moores University

 Many Loyalists are antediluvian thugs. Rather more are misguided and out of touch with reality. But there are subtle, sophisticated Protestants as well, and a deal of good will among ordinary unionists inside and outside of the ghettos. Greenslade should try talking to some of the moderate majority before he next sounds off about the essential decency and honour of his IRA muckers.
Walter Ellis
London
walter_ellis@lineone.net

Too often the media use put-downs, caricatures and bias in dealing with Irish people and affairs. If you are fed up with the way the media routinely makes a mockery of us and often uses other Irish to do so (Letters, August 26), please email me.
Seamus Carey
London

fields.headline: ... and who is in control
fields.trailText: Mark Atkinson is right to question the hype surrounding information and communication technology and the world's poor (Poor need penicillin before Pentiums, August 28).
fields.body:
The exclusion of billions who are poor, illiterate, rural or non-English speaking from the evolving global information infrastructure has serious effects and the digital divide is fast becoming a critical issue for developing countries. Mark Atkinson is right to question the hype surrounding information and communication technology and the world's poor (Poor need penicillin before Pentiums, August 28). The rhetoric of political and corporate leaders on digital divide must be matched by responding to real needs and not exacerbating global inequity. The challenge is to ensure that both the growing worldwide digital divide and initiatives to address it do not compound the existing gap between rich and poor.

The internet can and should be harnessed for sustainable development. OneWorld.net, the world's largest online community of NGOs, works with hundreds of grassroots groups in poor countries who tackle hardship head on. Many of those working with and on behalf of the poor now use the internet, connecting with individuals and organisations in the west and developing countries to share knowledge and take action on poverty and human rights. New technology, when used appropriately, is a vital new tool to promote global justice and to support programmes that aim to meet the basic needs of the most disadvantaged peoples in our world.

Access to the internet is not more important than alleviating hunger or providing access to shelter, healthcare, clean water and education, but it can no longer be separated from these concerns.
Glen Tarman
OneWorld
media@oneworld.net

 I was dismayed to see you joining the clamour for "free" internet for all (Leader, August 23). What is so special about this electronic medium of information exchange? The argument that we must not tolerate social exclusion holds no water. If it did, why not free travel, post, phones, newspapers, et al? The net represents a staggeringly large capital investment that deserves its entrepreneurial return. The old adage that there is no such thing as a free lunch holds here just as anywhere else - if it is free, is it worth anything?

Most net surfing is just that, idle scanning for trivia or titillation. Genuine information searches and business transactions make up a tiny percentage of logged on time. Let those who must, pay. By all means rein in monopoly players such as BT, but if information (or entertainment) has value then it must surely warrant a cost.
Adrian Bates
Micheldever, Hants

fields.headline: Corrections and clarifications
fields.trailText: A panel on air crashes, page 3, August 26, needs clarification. Contrary to the heading (Still missing), wreckage from a 1947 South American Airways crash has been located, as stated in the text. Contrary to the text and headline, the wreckage has also been found from a US air force A10 whose pilot crashed into a Colorado mountain in 1997.
fields.body:
A panel on air crashes, page 3, August 26, needs clarification. Contrary to the heading (Still missing), wreckage from a 1947 South American Airways crash has been located, as stated in the text. Contrary to the text and headline, the wreckage has also been found from a US air force A10 whose pilot crashed into a Colorado mountain in 1997.

A piece on the new musical director of Glyndebourne opera, Vladimir Jurowski, seemed to say his Welsh National Opera production of Hansel and Gretel was staged in Edinburgh (page 8, August 26), whereas it was put on in Covent Garden and Cardiff.

The piece also looked ahead to a revival of "Sir Peter Paul's famous 1985 production" of Albert Herring. That is, Sir Peter Hall.

A mislabelled photograph was used instead of the correct one with the obituary of Sir Lynden Pindling, the former Bahamas prime minister, yesterday, page 16.

The word not was inadvertently dropped from a letter, page 27, August 26. It asked what the surprise was that all candidates at some selective schools passed five or more GCSEs at grades A* to C, and suggested it would be more informative for the Guardian "to 'name and shame' those grammar schools that do not manage to achieve this".

It is Guardian policy to correct significant errors as soon as possible. Please quote date and page number. webTitle: Letters: Should politics in the US be looking to Europe?

fields.headline: New networks of power
fields.trailText: Polly Toynbee writes about "hate mail" from the US (Comment, August 25) in response to her previous article (The lesson from America is that Europe is our only hope, August 23).
fields.body:
Polly Toynbee writes about "hate mail" from the US (Comment, August 25) in response to her previous article (The lesson from America is that Europe is our only hope, August 23). But I doubt very much that it is representative of American opinion. The language and tone of the email she quotes is that of a fairly extreme minority. Most Americans would not even be aware of her article. By far the most likely explanation for this "avalanche of emails" is that her column was posted on the internet in forums read by people of strongly anti-liberal views. (It was in fact posted to at least one, the newsgoup alt.politics.liberalism.)

An interesting story is the way the internet can generate "campaigns", including very unrepresentative ones, because it makes it easier for those with extreme views to find, encourage, and support each other. Another is the way the media are unprepared for the effects of the internet on their ways assessing opinion.
Jeff Dalton
University of Edinburgh
J.Dalton@ed.ac.uk

 I liked Polly Toynbee's analysis in her original article. During the previous weeks I too watched the US presidential campaign - the entire party conventions live on TV, in the UK. I am not sure why so much TV time is given to events in America. I did not realise, until I experienced it, the amount of attention that the media gives to the US in UK. I wish the US was able to do the same about the events in Europe and the world. Our children know every detail about football players in America, but ask them where Hong Kong is and they may well say Latin America.
Steven Kadivar
Woodside, USA
skadivar@hotmail.com

 Europe alone cannot act as a counterweight to the US. Only the concerted authority of the rest of the world, acting through the UN, can stand up to overweening might of the US. To strengthen the rule of international law we need "coalitions of the willing", involving developing countries and Europe working together, as over the statute for the International Criminal Court and the landmines ban. We also need a robust system of democratic accountability at a global level, so that all countries and international agencies can be challenged to live up to their commitments under the UN charter, the Universal Declaration of Human Rights and international law.

Next month world leaders meet in New York to discuss the future of the UN. This is an opportunity to strengthen democratic accountability in international decision-making, so that no country, however powerful, is above the law. This is our only hope for tackling global climate change, nuclear proliferation, third world debt and poverty.
Titus Alexander
Chair, Charter 99
info@charter99.org

 It's sad but entirely predictable that Polly Toynbee's excellent article should produce such an ill considered and rude response. The highly selfish nature of US politics is down to two main reasons, the highly flawed "democratic" system, in which power is wielded by corporate America, rather than the people; and the complacency of a large proportion of the population, who cannot see the difference between economic, technological and military world leadership, and moral world leadership - despite the appalling record the US has on environmental issues, arms control, gun laws and so on.

It is not a case of "my Europe right or wrong". We can build a Europe that is strong, democratic and environmentally responsible, and must do if the world's major problems are to be dealt with internationally.
Joe Charnock
Boston, USA

webTitle: Letters: Health and Safety Executive on track

fields.headline: On track
fields.trailText: Professor Steve Tombs describes the Health and Safety Executive as a "mouse" behaving uncharacteristically when it drew the attention of London Underground to a number of concerns in a robust manner (Letters, August 19).
fields.body:
Professor Steve Tombs describes the Health and Safety Executive as a "mouse" behaving uncharacteristically when it drew the attention of London Underground to a number of concerns in a robust manner (Letters, August 19). As one of HM Inspectors for 27 years I have lost count of the number of prosecutions I have taken and enforcement notices I have issued. Is it the action of a "mouse" to have prosecuted the British Railways Board following the Clapham junction accident? Or Great Western Trains following the Southall accident (£1.5m fine)? Or Railtrack following the death of a passenger? We have always used our powers and prosecuted when warranted. The leaked letter simply shows how we have taken up safety issues with London Underground, it is not about public-private partnership.
VP Coleman
Chief Inspector of Railways

webTitle: Council tenants warned to keep child footballers off the streets

fields.headline: Council tenants warned to keep child footballers off the streets
fields.trailText: Thousands of children have been banned from playing football in the street and council chiefs are threatening to evict the parents of any child caught breaking the ban.
fields.body:
Thousands of children have been banned from playing football in the street and council chiefs are threatening to evict the parents of any child caught breaking the ban.

Bradford council announced the crackdown after complaints that footballs were flying into gardens and banging against windows. Officers from the tenancy enforcement team will patrol the streets.

Yesterday the council was accused of being too harsh. Tenants leader Mike Stocks said: "It's like using a sledgehammer to crack a nut. Football is really popular at the moment especially in Bradford now that we have a team in the Premier League.

"The trouble is every kid thinks they are David Beckham or Michael Owen and he or she will try to kick the ball with all their might. Balls do bang against windows, walls and gardens and I sympathise with anyone who has got to put up with this sort of nuisance. The real problem on most estates is that there is nowhere for children to go and play football.

The council's 27,000 tenants are required to sign agreements promising to obey strict guidelines which state tenants must be good neighbours and not harass other residents. The guidelines also make it clear that parents are responsible for their children.

Kris Hopkins, the council's executive member for housing, said: "We've all kicked balls accidentally into people's gardens but things can get out of hand."
